story:
Kuamamoto x Fukushima Kids Dolphin Camp 


Greeting to all brothers and sisters, 
We are Team Fukushima Kids Dolphin Camp from Japan. We have started Dolphin Camp to support children in Fukushima since 2014. We are pleased to announce to have third annual dolphin camp this year. 

This is a radiation free camp for children in Fukushima who have been affected by 2011 Tohoku Earthquake and Tsunami and also a support program for children who have been suffered from recent Kumamoto Earthquake in last April. We give them an opportunity to encounter with wild dolphin in remote island of Japan to release the stress of radiation exposure and disaster.

This camp is organized by 100 % volunteers, and we need your support.



The camp will be held at Miyake Island in Japan which is 200 km off shore from Tokyo.  We will have a boat to go to Mikura Island from Miyake Island to meet wild dolphins where about 130 friendly bottlenose dolphins inhabiting. Children will use full of their five senses including seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting and feeling during the camp. They will encounter with wild dolphins for the first time of their life. And they will play in the nature all day with no stress from the radiation fear during this camp.


2016 Camp Schedule:
Date: July 25 - 29, 2016 (4 nights 5 days)
Participants: 20 children from Kumamoto and Fukushima
Place: Miyake Island, Japan

Day 1 (July 25): Departing from Takeshiba Port in Tokyo at night.  Dolphin slide show/workshops in the ferry to Miyake Island. 

Day 2 (July 26): Arriving in Miyake Island in the morning. Morning yoga, snorkeling practice, hiking to the guardian trees in Miyake Island, nature workshop.

Day 3 (July 27): Morning yoga, hiking to the mountain, campfire on the beach and star watching.

Day 4 (July 28): Morning yoga, dolphin swim, drawing their imaginary dolphin on a huge white sheet, BBQ, firework, presentation of experience in the island, music and dance. 

Day 5 (July 29): Morning yoga, visiting the view point in the island and thank to the god of island, catching ferry back to Tokyo. Arriving Tokyo at night. 


Visit our Gallery for more pics from 2014 & 2015 Dolphin Camp.


(2014 Fukushima Kids Dolphin Camp Documentary, 24 mins)

What we need:

We need approximately $15,000 for the total cost of camp which includes transportation (train, ferry to the island, and rental car at the island), dolphin swimming boat (costs about $150 per person), foods, accommodation, insurance and etc.

We have saved donation throughout the year by having various fund raising events. But we still need $5,000 more for this year's camp. We need your support. 

Our perks includes thank you letter from participated children, dolphin camp original handkerchief, Dolphin Camp/Helly Hansen collaboration T-shirts, original 2015 dolphin camp DVD, homemade honey candle and etc. 

We are sending our perks from Japan with many thanks from children in Fukushima and Kumamoto. 


Media pick

Here are some of media picks from 2015 Fukushima Kids Dolphin Camp

  • An interview with Metropolis Magazine... READ
  • An interview with Metropolis Podcast... LISTEN
  • Earth Island Institute / Save Japan Dolphins ... READ 
  • Stars & Stripes Japan ... READ 


The Impact

Raise the awareness of Dolphin capability in Japan:

  • The action is to support children in Fukushima and Kumamoto. But it is also to raise the awareness about dolphins. Japan has unique tradition with dolphins for long history including hunting them. It is very sad. We would like to use this opportunity as a good example to let people know that we can be with dolphins and educate children for good reason.  This is an opportunity to support children and also a step to save the dolphins in Japan.


  • We believe that it is highly important to CONTINUE this camp. The experience children receive from this camp can change their life.

We appreciate if you can support, share or just tell your friends this project to support children in Fukushima. 

Children are our future.  

For more information, please visit our site: Fukushima Kids Dolphin Camp 

E-mail: futurekidsadventure@gmail.com

ーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーー

Perks:

"Dolphin Tenugui" or Japanese style handkerchief


2015 FKDC documentary movie (New version):


Thank you letter from participated children



Helly Hansen x Dolphin Camp collaboration T-shirts

Handmade Honey Candle Set

story:
What is "Whole Access"?

The "Whole Access" project will make Central MN Farmer's Markets, Food Coops, and CSA Farms accessible to low-income families who have SNAP benefits (formerly known as Food Stamps). This ambitious new project is being led by the Central Minnesota Sustainability Project, a regionally-based community organization that connects people with land and with each other.

At the Central Minnesota Sustainability Project (CMSP), we seek to make sustainable living in harmony with the planet a practice we can all share. We do this by intentionally building cross-racial, cross-cultural alliances, with healthy fresh food access as the common denominator. Our transformational community work has resulted in multicultural community garden spaces, innovative food entrepreneurship programs, and Story Circle events where diverse families from immigrant, refugee, and other marginalized backgrounds come together to discuss land dis/reconnection, food sovereignty, and finding a sense of place.

The "Whole Access" Project is focused on making sure that all members of our community can access and purchase healthy fresh food, by walking area markets through the complicated process of becoming FNS-certified and accepting EBT as a form of payment. In a parallel process, we are also developing an open-source, community training about accessing affordable healthy foods while maintaining our cultural and religious food traditions.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $5000 in 3 weeks! Can we do it? Yes we can, with your help! Funding will support:

  • Cost-Share for our Americorps VISTA member, a full-time volunteer who is devoted to this project,
  • Mileage costs so that staff can travel the Central region, meeting with market managers and assisting with FNS-certification,
  • Childcare, Food, and Interpreter costs for Listening Sessions with community members and Pilot events for our Community Training. We provide childcare, meals, and interpreters for all events to ensure maximum access for families.
If we raise above and beyond our goal, additional funds will support wages for CMSP Staff who will be involved in curriculum development and facilitation. Because of the myriad grant programs from the USDA and Department of Health that support farmer's markets purchasing EBT Card Reading Technology and other related costs, we are focusing funding we receive on offering our staff as FREE CONSULTANTS to farmers and markets. 
We appreciate that you are taking the time to make a gift to support this transformative work, and we would like to thank you by offering some AMAZING perks:

  • The "Just Grow" Bumper Sticker and Decal, handmade by our gardening guru and artist-in-residence, Winston Pennington-Flax :)
  • Fancy Preserves and Handmade SustainMN Seed Packs
  • Tickets to our Annual Harvest Dinner
  • Pottery by Linda Holliday
  • A Limited-run Broadside featuring poetry by Nick Flynn
  • An original painting by St. Cloud's own Sarah Drake
  • ...and a private dinner at the home of CMSP's Director, Autumn Brown!

The Impact

One in 10 families in Central Minnesota are food insecure. These are working families, men, women, & children who are struggling to make ends meet, who have to decide between paying the water bill and buying enough food for the week. 

The families we work with face significant economic and accessibility barriers to consuming healthy fresh food: affordability, lack of available transportation to and from markets, lack of time to shop and time to prepare meals, and lack of education about how to cook healthfully using local foods. These barriers have a huge impact on the low-income families from immigrant backgrounds who are dealing with the additional obstacle of having unique cultural food needs that are not met by many fresh food markets.

On the other side of this dynamic is the farmer who is running a small farm operation, sustainable and organic. These businesses struggle to be profitable, and while the most recent Farm Bill has made some strides in supporting small farms, the decks remain stacked against these farmers who have not traditionally had access to subsidies, federal loans and the many other ways our government has supported industrial agriculture. We see an opportunity to bring two areas of need together. EBT (Electronic Benefit Transfer) is the payment option for families participating in SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program), previously known as the Food Stamp Program. One in seven Americans participates in SNAP annually. Every year, roughly $75 billion in SNAP funds are allocated to families. What better way to use these supplemental funds than to provide access for low-income families to use their food assistance benefits to purchase healthy, fresh food from their local farmers?   

If we are successful, we will see a 50% increase in Central Minnesota fresh food markets accepting EBT payments. This evolution in our markets not only makes fresh food more accessible for low-income families - it also creates a new income stream for small sustainable farmers who struggle to run profitable businesses. Through this work, we make our local food movement more diverse and accessible - we change who gets a seat at the Local Foods Table. 

    Risks & Challenges

    This work will not be easy. The primary challenge we face in helping markets become EBT-accessible is that it takes a lot of time and effort, and most farmer's markets do not have dedicated staff. We believe that with the incredible skills of our Americorps VISTA, we can make the process easier for market managers. But we know that in the end, market managers and their boards have to be 100% committed to accessibility and diversity in their customer base in order to sustain this work over the long-term.

    We are uniquely qualified to lead this work. Our track record of building successful and sustainable partnerships in the community has resulted in hundreds of low-income families growing healthy, fresh food for themselves with significant economic value. Our education program has raised the consciousness of our whole community about the importance of this work, and the possibility of its impact on our region's economic and social prosperity. 

    Change happens through relationships, and we will make change one market and farm at a time, allowing the domino effect of business owners seeing the success of this model in their community, and in their business bank accounts, to lead the way forward.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Just because you cannot give money doesn't mean you cannot help. Here are other ways you can support our project:

      • Share this campaign page with others, and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools! Promote it on facebook, twitter, pinterest, and any other site you belong to!
      • If you live in Central MN, and you know a sustainable farmer or a market manager, tell them about this amazing new resource and encourage them to reach out to us!
      • If you have experience with using EBT at a farmer's market, let us know! We are eager to hear about the benefits and challenges, for both customers and market managers. Every story we here is an education, and education is the foundation of change.

      Help us do this critical work, so that Central Minnesota can thrive!

story:
Hello and thank you for taking a few minutes to look at a very exciting idea that we are going to start with contributions from this campaign and hope to grow into something that will benefit everyone that loves to spend their leisure time enjoying everything that Lake Cumberland has to offer.  The initial idea was born out of a need to do something significant to reduce the amount of floating debris and trash in the lake, but the list of ideas about what we could do beyond cleaning the lake just keeps getting longer. 

My name is Scott Lay, I'm originally from Northern Kentucky and have been visiting Lake Cumberland since about 1976.  In fact, I enjoyed the lake so much that I moved to Somerset in 2004, however work has brought me back to the Cincinnati area as my place of residence.

In the spring of 2016, I noticed that several times each day, either in person, on social media, or a combination of the two, complaints about the trash and debris on Lake Cumberland were steadily being posted or talked about. It is the same old story year after year and seems to be getting worse. I began to wonder what it would take to make a considerable difference and began seriously thinking about this issue. I talked to several people at that time and their response was "it happens every spring and it gets better in early summer, not much you can do." While I do understand the reasoning behind these statements, I also couldn't help but wonder, if it never gets cleaned up, the problem has to be compounding with each passing year. The solution to a significant reduction is a continuous, year round effort to remove what is there. This is exactly the point that people began to think I had lost my mind. "You do know how big the Lake is, right?" was the most common comment, followed by "and there are tons upon tons of logs and sticks that hold all the plastic bottles and trash, you can't do anything with that." So maybe I was crazy, I kept thinking about it.

I'm gonna try to make a long story as short as possible. I found some commercially produced equipment that works very well on floating debris. I have posted some video of these boats in action and they are very impressive. They are also very expensive, with a sticker price of about $500,000 bucks. While these boats are awesome, I could also see how they would be limited as to what they could do and I began to think about how to build something better. I had a pretty good idea of the design and a rough estimate of what it would cost to have it built, so I went deeper into the numbers. It quickly became clear that this was going to cost alot of money, and while I was pretty confident that we could figure out a way to raise the money needed, the idea faded into everything else that was going on at the time and the issue found its way to the bottom of my to do list.

Like clockwork, spring came and again, the debris was awful, but it was a little different this year. Many long time boaters, some several decades, were talking about never seeing anything even close to the amount of garbage in the lake, so here I go again. Picking up where I left off, the cost had to be nailed down and the funding had to be seriously looked at to see if this was a possibility. So this is where we are and if the numbers look concerning, you have to continue reading to see how it makes sense. I will briefly go into more detail about the equipment and operations in a moment, but first, let's look at some numbers. The first year operating cost is estimated at about 1.2 million dollars which includes building the boat, buying the accessory equipment, four full time employees, and the operating cost. The obvious question at this point is how could we possibly think seriously about this with the cost being so high? The answer is in the numbers.

Setting an annual membership fee at $50, it would take 20,000 members to raise a million dollars. While researching the number of visitors to Lake Cumberland, I consistently found the estimated number at 4.7 million people per year. I have no clue how these numbers were generated, but assuming they are close to accurate, the idea of getting a mere 20,000 no longer seemed impossible. Feeling a little more comfortable about the question of funding, I moved on to what turned out to be the most difficult problem to solve which was what to do with the seemingly endless amount of floating debris and given the size of the lake, could it be done? I have to admit, on more than one occasion, I felt there was no good answer but I finally put it all together and I will briefly explain the plan.

First, we would locate several locations that would be suitable as holding areas. These holding areas would be small coves where we could temporarily contain the debris using containment bouys secured as far back into the cove as possible. The “boat” is really a floating conveyor belt with a 12’x40’x3’ hold which will carry a large amount of debris. The conveyor will quickly remove everything floating on the surface and load it into the hold, it will be transported to the nearby containment area, and a conveyor will quickly offload the boat into this area. Basically, we are picking it up and moving it to an area that it will be contained. Once the distance from the debris field that we are working on becomes too great, we set up another containment area and continue the process. As the lake levels begin to fall, the debris in these containment areas will be on dry land. At that point, we return to these areas and separate the trash for proper disposal, and remove the natural debris in a number of ways including chipping, hauling and burning. This is a full time year around operation and all of the debris that will be removed will be that much less to contend with when the higher water levels return the following spring. This would be clean up on a massive scale and unlike anything that has previously been done in an attempt to address this problem. The boat will be capable of picking up everything from Styrofoam cups to large logs and will swallow huge debris fields very quickly.

So, with the two seemingly impossible questions having viable answers, the ultimate question is will we get the support to make this happen. While nearly everyone that I talk to concerning this idea thinks that it is much needed and are very encouraging, will people, in large numbers, actually get out their debit card and support getting this started. That is what we are doing now with a fund raising campaign that will set this plan in motion. With enough support, we can begin the process of setting up the infrastructure needed to complete this project. First we have to legally become a non-profit organization, then set up bank accounts, get a website up and running and begin getting quotes on the various equipment needed. I am also convinced that we can get the cooperation of businesses, local governments and other organizations with similar interest and the potential for grants or other government funding needs to be explored. This is a big idea with a lot of work yet to do, however, working together, I think this could easily become a reality and Lake Cumberland will be a cleaner and safer place to spend our leisure time.

Thanks you for taking the time to look at this idea, thanks for your support, and please share with family and friends that love the lake.

By donating here to get this idea headed toward a reality, you will not only get your first year of membership, but with your $50 dollar pledge you will be known as a Founding Member of the Association and receive two window stickers that signify you as a founding member.  If you love the idea of being a member, your $100 pledge will also include a commemorative coin that you can display in your boat, home or office that signifies you as a founding member.  

I am more than excited about seeing this become a large group of Lake Cumberland boaters working together to not only make our lake more enjoyable, but also working on other worthwhile projects as a group. Thank you for your time and support and I will see you at the lake.

The “boat” is really a floating conveyor belt with a 12’x40’x3’ hold which will carry a large amount of debris. The conveyor will quickly remove everything floating on the surface and load it into the hold, it will be transported to the nearby containment area, and a conveyor will quickly offload the boat into this area. Basically, we are picking it up and moving it to an area that it will be contained. Once the distance from the debris field that we are working on becomes too great, we set up another containment area and continue the process. As the lake levels begin to fall, the debris in these containment areas will be on dry land. At that point, we return to these areas and separate the trash for proper disposal, and remove the natural debris in a number of ways including chipping, hauling and burning. This is a full time year around operation and all of the debris that will be removed will be that much less to contend with when the higher water levels return the following spring. This would be clean up on a massive scale and unlike anything that has previously been done in an attempt to address this problem. The boat will be capable of picking up everything from Styrofoam cups to large logs and will swallow huge debris fields very quickly.So, with the two seemingly impossible questions having viable answers, the ultimate question is will we get the support to make this happen. While nearly everyone that I talk to concerning this idea thinks that it is much needed and are very encouraging, will people, in large numbers, actually get out their debit card and support getting this started. That is what we are doing now with a fund raising campaign that will set this plan in motion. With enough support, we can begin the process of setting up the infrastructure needed to complete this project. First we have to legally become a non-profit organization, then set up bank accounts, get a website up and running and begin getting quotes on the various equipment needed. I am also convinced that we can get the cooperation of businesses, local governments and other organizations with similar interest and the potential for grants or other government funding needs to be explored. This is a big idea with a lot of work yet to do, however, working together, I think this could easily become a reality and Lake Cumberland will be a cleaner and safer place to spend our leisure time.Thanks you for taking the time to look at this idea, thanks for your support, and please share with family and friends that love the lake.By donating here to get this idea headed toward a reality, you will not only get your first year of membership, but with your $50 dollar pledge you will be known as a Founding Member of the Association and receive two window stickers that signify you as a founding member.  If you love the idea of being a member, your $100 pledge will also include a commemorative coin that you can display in your boat, home or office that signifies you as a founding member.  I am more than excited about seeing this become a large group of Lake Cumberland boaters working together to not only make our lake more enjoyable, but also working on other worthwhile projects as a group. Thank you for your time and support and I will see you at the lake.

story:
Use the Share This Campaign Tools link directly above to spread the word via e-mail link, Twitter, Facebook, etc.


FOR AS LITTLE AS $10 WE COULD CHANGE THE COURSE . . .


The Call for Action

Food Security is one of the most pressing issues of our time and must be tackled to stem global hunger.  Food Security is a little understood topic and rarely felt issue in the developed world, including the United States.  Nevertheless, the lack of Food Security is a pestilent and global health problem causing undernourishment and malnutrition in the most impoverished regions of the world. 

 

According to the United Nations FAO (2010), Asia and the Pacific region is currently the most food insecure region in the world where approximately 578 million people (nearly two times the population of the U.S.) experience malnutrition and lack the recommended daily caloric intake.   One of the most food insecure countries in this region is Cambodia.  The country is still recovering since 1979 from the effects of a brutal genocide by the Khmer Rouge, where an attempt at agrarian/agricultural reform led to widespread famine and death.  Today, approximately 22% of the population remains undernourished and approximately 31% remain under the poverty line.  In addition, nearly 1 in 2 Cambodian children under the age of five are malnourished (Cambodia Food Security and Nutrition government website, 2011). 


Food security and nutrition are at the forefront of discussions worldwide via the United Nations as well as Cambodian policy-makers. As part of a national strategy to combat hunger in impoverished rural areas, food security has been identified as a paramount issue to progress the country.

 

Our Story

My name is Brian Reyes and I am a recently departed environmental services professional, whom is looking to utilize my education, skills and talents to make a more magnanimous impact on the world.  I have recently been offered a fellowship with a San Francisco non-profit NGO which has conducted unique, positive and sustainable international community development work for the past 16 years in Cambodia, Tanzania and Thailand.

 

My vital work, on behalf of Global Service Corps (GSC), a San Francisco based 501(c)(3) non-profit NGO, will take me to the impoverished rural areas (Takeo Province) of Cambodia.  To battle the adverse impacts of malnutrition, a Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security Community Development Pilot Project will be established via building a community educational garden and compost center.

 

The goal of this project is to stabilize food supply in one of the most impoverished rural areas in Cambodia through community development, partnership formation, education and training.  GSC and I will build this educational and training center at an existing Orphanage Facility in Takeo province, which houses 60 children and 25 adults – many of whom are HIV/AIDS infected.  Not only will these children and adults, but, also community leaders, nearby schools, local teachers/educators, and families can gather here to learn about subsistence farming, crop diversification, feasible post-harvest (food preservation, food drying), and sustainable agriculture techniques such as bio-intensive agriculture (BIA) methods.  The training does not require any complicated machinery.  All methods and techniques are easily replicated and focuses on small-scale or mini-farming for subsistence; NOT large scale farming.  This is Sustainable Agriculture training and education at the Community Grass Roots Level, which empowers individuals and families to achieve their own food security.

 

GSC and I will educate and inspire current and future community leaders to educate their own community, which will ideally perpetuate the basic understanding and necessity of Sustainable Agriculture and post-harvest techniques to achieve Food Security. 

 

The following objectives and benchmarks are to be accomplished to meet this goal:

  1. Prior to project start date, develop existing partners and identify potential partners (accomplished)
  2. Perform a needs assessment of the region
  3. Establish a sustainable community garden (currently under construction) at the well-known and existing GSC orphanage facility in Takeo Province
  4. Utilize the garden to educate, feed and meet the caloric demands of over 60 children and 25 adults currently living in the orphanage – many of whom are HIV/AIDS infected
  5. Develop and coordinate with existing and potential partners currently working in nearby villages/communities
  6. Engage adjacent villages/communities and build relationships with community leaders/farmers
  7. Utilize the garden to conduct educational and training modules for orphanage families and children and community leaders/local farmers, which will be held year-round
  8. Increase attendance and extend the coverage of the educational and training center throughout the region
  9. Send service-learning volunteers monthly to aid staff in the training and education of orphaned children, families and community leaders/local farmers

 

This project is not without precedence.  GSC has successfully scaled up a Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security Program in Tanzania, which has now received over 1,000 service-learning volunteers since inception and employs 37 in-country staff.  GSC and I will draw from its 16 years experience in East Africa and transfer its successful community development model, Best Management Practices and techniques in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security to Cambodia.

 

Sustainable Agriculture & Food Security Techniques

The following are brief descriptions of successful techniques GSC has been utilizing for the past 16 years in East Africa and could be deployed in Cambodia.

Bio-intensive agriculture (BIA)

Bio-intensive agriculture (BIA) is a method of small-scale organic farming that involves using double-dug beds, composting, intensive planting, and companion planting.  GSC has been using this method for over 10 years in Tanzania.   Made popular by John Jeavons of the GROW BIOINTENSIVE Mini-Farming Program for Ecology Action, BIA focuses on building reusable and healthy soil and increasing the efficiency of the land used to increase crop yields for subsistence and community farmers (for more information about BIA and GROW BIOINTENSIVE Mini-Farming, visit www.growbiointensive.org).

Post-Harvest Techniques: Food Drying and Improved Grain Storage

Typical on-farm losses from field to table exceed 50% due to the lack of food preservation knowledge and methods.  GSC trainings include alternative low-cost drying structures, education about appropriate drying methods, and information sessions on how to reconstitute the dried foods for preparation and use in cooking.

 

 

GSCs grain storage training helps rural communities alter their traditional grain stores and reduce their current average food losses, which exceeds 40% from field to table. Training the local community on improved grain storage techniques and tools allows them to reduce field-to-table losses.

 

 

Rainwater Catchments

In Tanzania, they are called Hafirs.  In many areas of Tanzania, water shortage is a serious problem.  It is impossible to grow home gardens and keep livestock alive without water. Building a hafir, a 12 cubic meters water storage trench lined with plastic or clay, can collect enough rain water to maintain a garden or sustain livestock through the dry season.  This may be a useful feasible technology in Cambodia, which experiences monsoonal downpours during the rainy season (June – October), but experiences a largely rainless and dry season during the winter (November – June).

Other Methods/Techniques

Other methods and techniques may have to be developed on the ground based on a needs assessment and distinct geographic, climatic, soil, dietary and cultural make-up of the community and region. 

 

For example, Newcastle Disease kills 70% of the chicken population in Tanzania, which has an especially significant impact on poor households that rely on chickens for food and income generation.   GSC has provided and disseminated vaccination of poultry against this life threatening disease.  Chickens have lived longer, thereby, being able to produce more eggs and grow larger for eating.


Another example is a Sack Garden.  In Tanzania, GSC has trained families with limited space and resources on how to build sack gardens, which provides them with a sustainable means of growing local vegetables and improving their diets.  Sack gardens are popular in urban and limited space gardens.  They are typically made by enclosing a growth medium (soil/compost) mixed with seeds in a burlap and woven plastic bag.

 

The Impact of This Community Development Pilot Project

First and foremost, I will lead in planning and building the community garden, which will meet the daily caloric needs of the HIV/AIDS impacted children and adults currently housed at the Orphanage facility in Takeo Province.    Then, I will build relationships with nearby community leaders and/or members; encouraging them to visit the newly built Community Educational Garden and Compost Center at the Orphanage.  Since the Orphanage is a well known way point in the region, GSC and I will utilize the newly built garden to train and educate community leaders and educators in the sustainable agricultural methods and food security techniques discussed above.  The newly acquired knowledge by community leaders and educators will then be shared with other community stakeholders.  GSCs model has been successfully deployed in Tanzania.  It is expected to yield similar results in attaining long-term Food Security for rural populations as well as building local capacity.


If I do not raise the money, I will not go.  We expect malnutrition and food insecurity to continue to be a pestilent problem for this underserved rural population of Cambodia if GSC and I do not successfully launch and establish this crucial project.  Nevertheless, we fully expect to succeed because of GSCs track record in Tanzania and my educational (B.S. Soil Science, M.S. Environmental Management) and professional skills (Associate Professional Soil Scientist, Environmental Planner, Sustainable Agriculture). 

 

What We Need & What You Get

I will need to fundraise upwards of $6,800 to cover my room and board, food, a visa, travelers insurance, air fare, vaccinations and regional transportation expenses over a 6-month span.  Materials such as basic farming expenses (spade, pitch fork, shovels, seeds, etc.) will be provided by GSC.  In addition, resources such as GSCs in-country program assistant, office in Phnom Penh, administrative supplies, and the Orphanage Facility’s land, water, and other labor to build this agricultural plot will be provided by GSC.

 

100% of the money donated will go towards my basic needs and transportation costs regionally and possibly cross-country to develop partnerships with community stakeholders and like-minded partner organizations.  It sounds a bit fishy right?  But, I guarantee you that my time there, the use of my talents and skills, and GSCs model and track record will translate into getting the Community Development Project properly built so that it will feed the adjacent community and educate the region in utilizing simple and effective Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security techniques.  The following is a link to my LinkedIn Account (Note: no tax write offs will be available).

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not familiar with the worldwide Food Security crisis, especially in vulnerable regions of the world, please spend at minimum 10 minutes to research online by following this link to the United Nations Report on World Hunger: http://www.fao.org/hunger/en/ or see the following ad by UN WFP.



Please spread the word about the need for action, awareness, and how GSC and my project will attain Food Security and feed the hungry in one of the neediest regions in the world. 

 

Use the Share This Campaign Tools link below the picture above to spread the word.  Also, post and re-post this campaign on Twitter, Facebook, You Tube, LinkedIn, blogs, etc.  It would be much appreciated if you could ask your friends and family to post the links and ask them to give as well.

story:
Update:  We have another $2,000.00 in cash and checks.  Our goal is $6,000.00 between Indiegogo and cash/check donations. I think we can do this!

We are the North Linthicum Improvement Association; a group of regular middle-class home owners trying to stop a developer from rezoning (the last green-space in North Linthicum, Anne Arundel County, MD) in order to build on, what we consider to be, a piece of land that is environmentally sensitive.   

 

Background:

 

Baltimore criminal defense lawyer William R Buie III owns the Green
Space between B & A Blvd and Patapsco Rd south of Nursery Rd.  This land is zoned Resource Critical Area (RCA) and Open Space (OS).  According to county
code, Open Space zoning, “is designed to protect and preserve those open land
areas of the county used for recreation (e.g. parks) and natural areas such as
bogs, wetlands, stream/creek ravines and floodplains.”

Holly Creek (which routinely floods Nursery Rd) runs through this
property.

Mr Buie bought the land (approximately 8.5 acres) in 2006 for $15,000.00.  Acreage in the immediate vicinity of this property goes for $200,000.00 to $300,000.00 per acre.  The reason Mr Buie paid so little is because the current zoning of the property makes it unbuildable.  Mr Buie has requested the a portion of the land be rezoned to accommodated his desire to build on the land.

In February 2014 Anne Arundel County held a hearing to determine the
fate of this request. An alliance of concerned Linthicum citizens opposed the rezoning at the hearing.  We cited flooding on Nursery and B & A Blvd,
additional runoff into the Chesapeake, protection of Holly Creek, and loss of
Green Space as reasons for to leave the zoning the way it is.

The hearing officer resoundingly rejected the request to rezone.  We won!

Mr Buie filed an appeal and we are in the middle of that appeal right
now.  The Appeals Board hearings are much more formal then the initial hearing and much of our testimony and exihibits (photos of flooding, etc) has been objected to by Mr Buie’s lawyer and not allowed into evidence.

Mr Buie is represented by one of the best real estate lawyers in Anne
Arundel County, has hired an engineering firm to prepare plans, and retained numerous “experts” to testify on his behalf.

Other than a representative from the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, we have
had only ourselves to fight this fight.  None of us are lawyers, civil engineers, or zoning experts.  We are outgunned and this thing is coming down to the wire. We need help to level the playing field.

The Chesapeake Bay Foundation has referred us to a lawyer that
specializes in fighting rezoning and protecting the bay.  His rate is $300.00 per hour and he estimates that it will take between $4,000.00 and $6,000.00 to prepare for and present our case at the final hearing on 30 September. 

Here are brief descriptions of why we oppose rezoning:

· If the property is rezoned, we really don’t know what will actually be built

· More paved over land along Holly Creek will mean more flooding on Nursery Rd and B & A Blvd

· More paved over land means more polluted runoff into the Patapsco River which then runs into the Chesapeake.  The Patapsco River has recently rated an “F”
grade in reaching pollution goals.

· We believe that the purpose of the original Open Space zoning was to protect Holly Creek.  Shoe-horning houses or apartments between Patapsco Rd and B & A was never the intention of the original zoning plan.  There was no “mistake” by the zoning planners.

No donation is too small, but we have a ways to go.  Bad things happen when good people do nothing.  HELP US TODAY. For the good of all.

· We believe that the purpose of the original Open Space zoning was to protect Holly Creek.  Shoe-horning houses or apartments between Patapsco Rd and B & A was never the intention of the original zoning plan.  There was no “mistake” by the zoning planners. 
No donation is too small, but we have a ways to go.  Bad things happen when good people do nothing.  HELP US TODAY. For the good of all.

story:
Sustainability out of the past: How archaeology can save the planet

I am looking for funds to complete a book on sustainability in the past.

I have been working in Archaeology for 27 years, and I specialise in ancient agriculture. I am halfway through writing my book, entitled, ‘How Archaeology can Save the Planet: Sustainability out of the past’; I have a publisher, but my workload is such that I have no time to finish it. I am looking to raise $15,000, which would enable me to take time out to complete my book and see it through to publication. I would then like to go on to create a television series based on the book, with the help of a filmmaker friend, but that is another project!

You can read papers I have published on the topic here:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/249007184_Sustainability_out_of_the_past_how_archaeology_can_save_the_planet

and here:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/272307886_Productive_Landscapes_a_Global_Perspective_on_Sustainable_Agriculture

And you can see me discussing archaeology on the History Channel:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0tJnxs8pNtQ

The plan for my book is as follows:

There have been many books written about what we can learn from the failures of the past, but I want to take a more optimistic view, focussing on what we have to learn from past successes. This book will be about sustainable agriculture in the past, and the engineering works that supported it, but it also looks to the future. Ancient technologies are what engineers define as ‘intermediate’, which means that they are simple, low in cost and they depend on local materials. Significantly, they don’t require fossil fuels. There is now broad agreement among many governments, non-government organisations, engineers and agronomists, as well as the United Nations, that intermediate technologies are often the most appropriate way forward in developing countries. The New Green Revolution is looking to traditional knowledge, rather than to technology, to solve problems of decreasing yields and environmental impoverishment.

This subject is controversial and I have been accused of suggesting ‘pie in the sky’ ideas, but the re-introductions I’m suggesting are already being carried out in countries all over the world. Water harvesting and other dryland systems are being re-introduced in Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Libya, Morocco, Pakistan, Syria, Tunisia, Yemen, Afghanistan and Oman. Other early technologies are being put back to work in Peru, Bolivia, India, Bangladesh, Niger, Burkina Faso and many more. I would like to raise awareness of the fact that we already have the technology to make sweeping changes to the way that we grow food and manage the environment; we could be producing more food per hectare, and we could be doing it more sustainably.

As the climate changes, it is imperative that we come up with new ways of managing our environment. Deserts are spreading, wetlands will increase as the sea level rises, and we need to find ways to cope with an increasing population. There is a lot that we in the West can learn from the past and from developing countries where people still practice traditional agriculture. I am not advocating a wholesale return to past technologies, nor am I suggesting the adoption of early technology in place of modern engineering and agriculture. What I am suggesting is that we combine some aspects of early technology with new systems and inventions, to create a healthier, more sustainable and environmentally richer planet.

story:
OVERVIEW.
On June 9-17, I will be crossing part of the Atlantic Ocean (from Bermuda to Rhode Island) on a 72-foot sail boat with 12 other people to study plastic pollution that has made its way from land to the middle of the ocean.  I am raising $3000 for my spot on the 5 Gyres Institute research voyage - through this page & a fundraiser event on May 30th at Tutu’s Brooklyn (see below). Funding over $3000 will be donated to 5 Gyres Institute.

WHAT.
The 5 Gyres Institute is a non-profit organization dedicated to conducting research on plastic pollution and building public awareness around plastic pollution issues. The purpose of the expedition is to bring together scientists, ocean lovers, artists, and activists, to conduct scientific research and increase public awareness on issues related to plastic pollution in our oceans. The expedition will contribute scientific information on the density of plastic pollution in the Atlantic Ocean and increase public awareness about plastic pollution through various outlets (blogs, websites, news, art).

WHY.
I am very active in helping cities adopt laws aimed at reducing plastic bag consumption (see my bio here).  One of the arguments in favor of plastic bag reduction ordinances is that single-use plastics cause harm to the ocean, particularly when they accumulate in garbage patches. 

Here is a link to a recent presentation that I gave about how plastic bag reduction laws help address plastic pollution in the ocean (my presentation starts at 12:41):   http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iwQge2aCiG4

Plastics industry groups have filed several lawsuits in California against these ordinances and one of their arguments is that environmental groups do not describe ocean plastic pollution well enough.  One of the main reasons I want to go on this trip is to gain first-hand knowledge of exactly what problems plastic causes in the ocean, so that I can help cities and environmental groups more aptly describe the problem.

WHAT YOU CAN DO.
Become aware of your plastic consumption and learn more about plastic pollution in our oceans.

Follow my BLOG at plasticbaglaws.org.

Register your support of a plastic bag ordinance in NY at bagitnyc.org.

Come to my FUNDRAISER EVENT:

Thursday, May 30th  6:30-9:00pm

Tutu’s Brooklyn

25 Bogart Street (2 blocks from the Morgan stop off the L)

7:15pm:  screening of short film about 5Gyres voyages

7:30pm:  screening of "The Immortal Plastic Bag", a mini-documentary about plastic bags in NYC

7:45pm:  PowerPoint presentation by Jennie Romer about plastic bag laws

8:00pm:  Q&A with the mini-doc filmmakers & Jennie

8:30pm:  silent auction & raffle

Check out the facebook invite here:  https://www.facebook.com/events/412121008886699/

WHAT I WILL DO FOR YOU.
I will be writing a blog for EACH day while I am on the voyage.

For everyone who DONATES $25 or more I will send you an interesting piece of plastic debris from my voyage.

For everyone who DONATES or $100 or more, I will give a one-hour presentation about plastic bag laws and marine plastic pollution (with pictures from my voyage) at a school or community group of your choice.  The location of the presentation must be within the five boroughs.

FOR MORE INFORMATION.
Link to my website: plasticbaglaws.org
Link to 5 Gyres Website for general information: http://5gyres.org/
Link to 5 Gyres blog for most current information: http://5gyres.org/whats_happening_now/blog
Link to Sea Dragon Ship's blog (the research vessel used on the 5 Gyres voyages): http://panexplore.com/index.php...

story:
Pick A Piece Of Rubbish

Although I do not like eating Plastic Soup, I love to pick the little pieces of plastic, iron, glass, polystyrine etc. out of nature, before they are eaten by animals, or just buried in the stoney beaches.

And: I like to categorize what I find and make art out of it!

Plastic Soup, or a garbage patch, is a catchy word for the incredible amount of marine debris in our planets oceans. The longer plastic is in the water, the smaller it becomes. And in the end it's called microplastic: mostly it is said that the pieces are smaller than 5mm.
Many animals (birds, fish) often mistake these pieces for plankton.
 
I could write pages of information about details, but this place is not meant for that. More information you can find on our facebook page PickAPieceOfRubbish.
 
Plastic Soup is a global problem but local challenge: in the Pacific, but also in the fjord of Oslo, Norway. Big garbage, like bottles or fishing nets are easy to remove. But for little pieces, just before they become microplast, you need to get down on your knees. And that is exactly what I like!
 
I enjoy working in almost all weather conditions. I enjoy working hard and I enjoy making art out of the debris that I find.
 

I will work on 2 beaches in Oslo's fjord:

  • Bygdøyness is a tiny beach (behind Kontiki Museum) where many tourists take a break from visiting museums. Here I as often as possible talk with and inform people from all corners of the world. Because of the incoming tides there is always a lot of small marine debris.
  • Nakkholmen, several beaches on the island. Here are not many tourists, but lot's of birds and a lot (!) of garbage.
So I want to be on my knees this coming summer, but I also want to support my family. So I am asking for your help: not on my knees, but as someone who loves nature and strongly believes that trash is not nature's responsibility but ours!
 
My ultimate dream is that I work all year through on different beaches in the world, picking up marine debris and raising awareness prefarably with a hundred people joining me on their knees.
 

My Goal at Indiegogo

 
To have this ultimate dream is important for me, but here at Indiegogo I am aiming for a month on the beach to clean. So I took the average month salary of a cleaner in Norway: 

Cleaners in Norway -  Their salary varies depending on whether they are working privately or in the community, but in the municipality about 130 NOK per hour, ie 25,350 (€ 3,363.84) per month.
 
I decided that € 3,333 (25,126.62 NOK) was a better sound bite.
 
This includes tax (they love that here in Norway) and expenses like travelling, gloves, cleaning tools etc., marketing, administration, fees at Indiegogo and making the art works.

 

Ways To Support

First of all I think it is necessary to realize our global challenge with marine debris. Plastic that is not disposed in a correct way will often find a way to water. Through the sewage system and storm drains, creeks and rivers, it finds its way to our seas and oceans.

Birds, fishes, shrimps and even polar bears have often our rubbish in their bodies.

So the first way of support is to take care of your trash and pick up a piece of rubbish every now and then.

A second way is to take some hours to clean a beach or a river side. Or even a storm drain.

And you can support me!

On the right side of this page you see the perks.

Basically there are 2 categories:

  • I send you an image or a movie (digitally) or a physical artwork (by mail) as a thank you
  • You make an amount of time on the beach possible, without a physical artwork. Gratitude is your reward!

 

Finally, I would really, really appreciate it if you spread the word through facebook, twitter and to all of your email contacts.

I can work more than one month!


Thank you kindly...

Johan

story:
Our Story

Julie and I first heard about this rally at a community event. It instantly sparked something in us, our sense of adventure and the challenge of no GPS. As we found out more, we discovered it lined up with our passions with The Heart of the Gazelles. We desire to make a difference, and want to inspire others to do the same. That is the driving force behind us. We are ordinary women with extraordinary dreams.  Together we are determined to make this happen and to be an example to every woman that anything is truly possible if you put your mind to it.

The Impact

This is the only rally where women from all over the world can come to compete through the Moroccan desert. They only navigate via map and compass for 9 days. Thereâ€™s also a medical caravan that goes along Morocco to provide medical, education, and housing for those less fortunate. During this years rally, they will be building a school.  This rally is truly an amazing opportunity to help the benefactor of this event, The Heart of Gazelles.  Your donation does not just go to help us race, it is improving life for those in Morocco. Heart of Gazelles works in collaboration with the Moroccan Government on projects whose importance has been evaluated and analysed. 

Heart of Gazelles projects for the last 3 years:

Medical: The Medical Caravan, sponsored by TOTAL
- 20,000 consultations (General Medicine, Paediatrics, Gynaecology and Optometry),
- 3 births,
- 31 Trachoma operations,
- 3 mammograms submitted for follow-up,
- 92 doctors have provided their services, 
- 1,900 people have received corrective eyeglasses, 
- 37 handicapped people have been referred to appropriate care facilities, 

- 4 metric tons of medical equipment have been given to local hospitals (wheelchairs, consultation tables...).

We are only the 4th American team in this years event.  This event needs more recognition in America and helping us get there will further promote this cause.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this race happen, we need you!  This is a great opportunity for you or your company to have a chance for some world wide coverage and marketing.  We can showcase your gear, logo, website, and anything, within reason, your company wants to promote.  This mediatisation is international, and includes Radio-Canada, TF1, Eurosport, TV5 Monde, 2M in Morocco, Elle magazine, L'express, the Journal de MontrÃ©al, ChÃ©rie FM... Recounting the passion and the sporting exploits of all these women.  
Keep it mind that all company donations are a taxable marketing expense since we will be showcasing your company or product on our website, vehicle, and gear.
Any personal donation will get personal recognition and a big thank you on our site as well as all social media.

We are also currently in the middle of starting our own non-profit, 501 c3 to further help this cause.  We will have this accomplished within this tax year of 2012.

As of now, we have raised 13K but still need another 15K to make this happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us any way you can by simply sharing our information with anyone you think will be interested.  Please share our facebook, twitter, website, this and anything else that could help.  Thank you for making a difference in Morocco!

story:
We are the Student Environmental Association at the University of South Florida, USF's largest environmental organization. Our team of student leaders are dedicated to improving our campus and community through sustainability, education, activism, and advocacy!

The world is getting hotter, sea level is rising, and weather conditions continue to get more extreme. Climate change is happening now and affecting human health and well-being. USF Students, along with youth across the nation and world, are working to shift the power and take control of our climate futures. And we need your help!

In order to save our climate, we need a strong network of trained leaders and so SEA is traveling to National Power Shift 2013 in Pittsburgh, PA! Can you help by donating $25 to out campaign?

Power Shift is a conference where youth from around the country come together to bring a shift in priorities at all levels of society. At Power Shift 2013 we will learn how to put an end to fracking, divest from fossil fuels, demand climate justice, and build a clean energy economy that works for everyone! Leaders of the movement from across the nation will be coming together to host panels, workshops, and trainings to empower our generation to change the world!

Your donation will go toward transportation, lodging, and program fees. It will help students who otherwise do not have the money to participate, attend. Are you willing to make a contribution and help us spread the word?

THE IMPACT:

A contribution of any amount will make a tremendous difference to our team!

  • A donation of $50 will cover one night of lodging for one student and comes with a special thank you card and a Power Shift Pin to show our appreciation.
  • A donation of $100 will cover a students transportation fees for the conference and comes with the above perks plus a Power Shift Poster!
  • A donation of $200 or more will sponsor one students entire trip and comes with the above perks as well as a mention in SEA promotions for Power Shift, our unending gratitude, and a hand-made something from us to you. :)

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

  • Ask friends, family, and co-workers to donate and get the word out for SEA by sharing our campaign on your Facebook Twitter, & Tumblr!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to send emails and more easily!
  • Talk to us about in-kind donations, hosting a fundraiser for our group, or business and corporate sponsorships!

Thank you for your generosity! We couldn't do this without you!

In Solidarity,

- The USF SEA Team

Go Earth!

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Ask friends, family, and co-workers to donate and get the word out for SEA by sharing our campaign on your Facebook Twitter, & Tumblr!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to send emails and more easily!

Talk to us about in-kind donations, hosting a fundraiser for our group, or business and corporate sponsorships!



Thank you for your generosity! We couldn't do this without you!
In Solidarity,
- The USF SEA Team

Go Earth!

story:
We have reached our minimum goal of $35,000!!
THANK YOU.

Our hearts are full of deep appreciation for each and every one of you who made this possible.


We would now like to raise our goal to $45,000 for the next two days of the campaign! Making this goal would allow us to be able to provide more materials, resources, classes, plant more trees, gardens and implement more projects that would leave a big impact in each city. Any additional donations you can give to this initiative would greatly enhance the experience we can offer at each Action Day and leave a bigger positive trace.


DEEP GRATITUDE from the Permaculture Action Team



The Polish Ambassador's fall Permaculture Action Tour is bringing together permaculture educators and community organizers to inspire and educate people about how we can make a shift towards a more sustainable and regenerative way of living, and channel this energy into local project builds in each of the cities we visit--getting people to take action to build the world they want to see.

www.PermacultureAction.org


What We Need


We need to raise at least $35,000 to support the permaculture educators and community organizers to travel alongside the Polish Ambassador and provide tools, resources and experiential learning opportunities outside the shows. Your donations will keep the permaculture action tour moving across the country and the educators and organizers fed and healthy, print educational materials, provide materials for local projects, and help us document and publish everything we do so everyone can benefit.  



The funds will be distributed to these areas:

  • Materials for Project Days at urban farms, gardens, and community centers

  • Food Costs

  • Van Rental

  • Fuel Costs

  • Teaching Materials

  • Organizer Fees

  • Educator Fees

  • Reward Fulfillment

  • Documenting the Tour, Editing Video, and Creating Media

  • General Administrative Costs (Website, Media, etc)


$35,000 will enable us to actually make this tour happen at its most basic level.  Raising beyond $35,000 will allow us to provide more materials to the local sites where we build gardens, permaculture systems, and other community projects in the cities we visit.  Funds raised beyond the goal will also allow us to put more energy towards documenting this process in a way that will inspire other artists to follow suit, and spread this message further through learning materials, publications, and artistic mediums.  Your donations expand the network of transformative work that is already being done.


Anything raised above $50,000 will go toward the further development of Jumpsuit Farms Impact Center. Over the past 8 years as an electronic music composer, The Polish Ambassador has saved up enough money to purchase a small, but vibrant 10 acre parcel in the foothills of the Sierra Mountains of Northern California. The intention of the project is to establish Jumpsuit Farms, an artist residency and permaculture impact center that supports musicians, farmers, and the local community.


Confirmed Action Days:

                             Eugene, OR - OCT 11

WHEN: October 11, 2014

WHERE: Lost Valley Educational Center and Meadowsong Eco Village

81868 Lost Valley Ln, Dexter, Oregon 97431

FACEBOOK EVENT: Click Here

CLICK FOR MORE INFORMATION & DETAILS

 

Austin, TX - NOV 1

WHEN: November 1, 2014

WHERE: 161 Possum Hollow Rd, Cedar Creek, TX 78612
FACEBOOK EVENT: Click Here
CLICK FOR MORE INFORMATION & DETAILS


More TBA!

 




The Polish Ambassador working on his land at Jumpsuit Farms!



A note from David Sulgalski aka The Polish Ambassador...



“For the past 5 years I have been touring as an electronic music composer and performer. It has been a joy, an honor, and an evolution to share my music with an audience that seems to put progressive ideas and community at the forefront of it's collective consciousness. I'm fully aware that without the support and participation of YOU GUYS this project would cease to exist. It's for that reason I feel indebted to the supporters of this project to use TPA as a platform to facilitate positive impact.


In speaking with so many of you guys at shows, festivals, and random encounters in the street, it has become clear that this music scene is ripe for some change. It's also clear that you guys want to be a part of it. In fact, the type of change that we are calling for will only work if you guys ARE involved. It's a collective movement that can be accelerated through artists, but ultimately comes down to the people--YOU.


People are attending concerts and festivals by the tens of thousands yet it is rare to see this energy mobilizing for a greater cause, a cause that directly affects the local community that is hosting the event. Yep, I'm with you. The party, the celebration is awesome. Shaking booty with your friends is heaps of fun. I've been doing it for the past 4 years. I know. But now, I'm longing for something more. Are you?


Can impact and celebration co-exist in the same environment? Can community work parties and projects culminate in ecstatic dance party celebrations? Can we remember that festival culture all began with harvests where people busted their ass for a week(s), all of it culminating in a community celebration known as a festival?


I'm curious. My gut tells me that this is the evolution that we are moving toward within our music scene. Realizing within ourselves that in giving, we are actually receiving. Understanding that it can feel so, so good to build with people to create something greater than our independent selves before or after we celebrate. Remembering that before anything else comes reverence for the earth, for without the earth we would not be. Simple truths.


I've decided to dedicate this Fall tour to these ideas. Perhaps we can consider this a seed that is being planted to inspire other artists to do something similar. Maybe it's an experiment. We have a question and this experiment might be the beginning of an answer.


We're embarking on a 30 city tour and we've linked up with a team of permaculture teachers, urban farmers,  community organizers, and network weavers to add to the already growing team of musicians, lyricists, and visual artists that make up Jumpsuit Records and The Polish Ambassador experience.  We’ll be teaching permaculture at shows through spoken word, video, and resources for people to take home; bringing local groups and organizations out to put a focus on the change they’re making in each city; and hosting impact days to build community projects.  Pushing Through the Pavement is taking action to transform the places where we live.  


The money you donate to this campaign will allow us to do all of this - to bring the teachers and organizers on the road, to provide materials for audiences and local project days, to document the process and publish it online, and to keep everyone healthy and taken care of along the way - to be a first step in bringing about this transformation.


In closing, I ask that if you share and support one thing from TPA this year, let it be this campaign. Every show I've ever played, every song I've ever produced, every fan I've ever connected with, it's really all led up to this. This project has become something greater than the music that's come through it, not because of me or you, but because of an open invitation to co-create together. It's my intention to extend that invitation even further. Will you create transformational party 2.0 with us?”

-David Sugalski AKA The Polish Ambassador




Summary


This October, The Polish Ambassador partners with a team of permaculture educators and community organizers to bring Pushing Through the Pavement: A Permaculture Action Tour to venues in major cities across the United States. The tour will provide educational presentations and workshops at Polish Ambassador shows and community spaces, facilitate project builds at urban sites, and empower people with tools for bringing about a sustainable and regenerative way of life.

The tour will be connecting a network of local organizations, permaculture groups, sustainability educators, and food growers that can put the principles of permaculture into action through on-the-ground projects and re-skilling.  Audience members will be encouraged to join “Impact Days” on urban sites following each show that will be immersions focused on sustainability, food justice, ecological education, and regenerative living practices.  Along with hard skills like growing food, collecting rainwater, and building structures, the tour will introduce the equally important aspects of social permaculture: how to work in collaborative groups and organize locally, make decisions, and communicate effectively.

 



Tour Objectives


  • To teach audiences about permaculture, regenerative land practices, organic food growing, natural building, rainwater catchment, and living in community.

  • To organize impact projects on urban sites in between shows that focus on sustainability, food justice, ecological education, and regenerative living

practices; and get peoples' hands moving to build and plant together.

  • To connect people with groups and organizations doing this work in the cities they live in, so that together people can transform the urban landscape, solve local problems, and build community.  

  • To introduce and weave people into Project Nuevo Mundo’s social network that will keep people connected and allow them continue to engage with innovative permaculture projects, transformational experiences and educational programs around the world through www.ProjectNuevoMundo.org



What is Permaculture?

Permaculture is the practice of living in a balanced way on the earth; of designing relationships of mutual support between people and the ecosystems we inhabit.  Through the collection of skills and practices that permaculture teaches, people can learn to once again live in a way that fosters healthy human communities and cultivates ecologically diverse and productive habitats for all beings.  

Permaculture practices we will be sharing:

  • Regenerative Land Care

  • Organic Food Growing

  • Food Forests and Perennial Polycultures

  • Natural Building

  • Rainwater Catchment and Greywater Recycling

  • Compost and Soil Building

  • Appropriate Technology

  • Neighborhood Placemaking

  • Transforming the Urban Landscape

  • Living in Community

The Goal

The goal of the Permaculture Action Tour is to inspire and empower people with the tools and know how of co-creating a sustainable and regenerative world.  Through bridging live music with earth-based practices and collective action, we will bring a new sense of awareness, community, and personal potential to each audience member who attends The Polish Ambassador shows–offering a way to make an impact towards positive change where they live while having fun.  This tour will be one step of many in making our cities greener, healthier, and happier places to live through the action of community.

The Need

The problems we face today have surpassed controversy and uncertainty. We are seeing the effects of over-consumption and resource exploitation in land degradation and the endangerment of wildlife, ancient cultures, and soil everywhere we look.  These imbalances reverberate out into our human communities as well where we witness poverty, hunger, and disconnection in our cities every day.  It is time that everyone become part of the solution and make small changes within their local communities and it’s time for those with a microphone in hand to empower their listeners to become part of the solution. The Polish Ambassador has stepped up to the plate to be that voice and collaborate with leaders in the permaculture movement to spark CHANGE.


The Impact

The impact that this tour will have is infinite and will continue beyond the tour itself. Each individual has an immense power to change world around them.  If each audience member is empowered to lead or take on a project of their own, another entire group of people will benefit, and soon an entire city. This tour has the potential to create millions of ripples of action towards healing the planet.  We, the people, are the power behind making our cities greener, happier, and healthier places as we improve relationships between each other and the earth. Our team is ecstatic to see the immense impact this tour will have on thousands of people and the permaculture movement it will accelerate.


 

LET’S DO THIS TOGETHER

story:
Short Summary

First of all, I`d like to thank you all for visiting our campaign site. Before you keep on reading please be aware of the Perks. Don`t miss them of the side of the screen. I guess they do make more sense than getting T-Shirts. You will like them.

Secondly, I should mention that this project`s commercial part is to be local but the environmental part is to be cloned to other developing countries who are aware of the Kyoto Convention but doing nothing or less.

All of us use fossil fuels. Oil, coal or gas. Every time you work, travel, chat, cook or take a shower, this releases CO2 into the atmosphere.

You can now help compensate for the greenhouse gases you emit for a small amount of money. This way you facilitate the development of forests or sustainable energy. These projects also provide additional income for the local population and provide for the recovery of nature and the environment. You can choose this project to start with.

We all are aware of the negative environmental effects of the trucks and the cars to mother earth& nature. To be honest, I`ve been also a bad environmental protector earlier with driving V8s. I told myself, why not to start now?

After several deep brainstorming sessions with friends & supporters, I`ve noticed that actually we can still make it – I mean keeping the ecosystem alive - beside many things we can do, we need to compensate O2 / CO2.

We won`t be able to avoid driving trucks & cars today (as they are necessary for transportation) but we can at least regenerate the resources. Here is some background information how I`m planning to do it:

  • I`m an expat returned home town after nearly two decades
  • What I`ve seen first, was an“A” grade developing and constructing country from west to east and north to south.
  • As of the nature of the local infrastructure, there is near to no efficiency in terms of using the limited resources such as fuel.
  • I`ve also noticed that lack of awareness thru locals of how they damage the nature is huge. 
  • that`s why, I`m looking for all contributors who has understood the real meaning of environmental impacts of the mankind to our earth and would like to help us to change this.
  • Actually, this is not a local project and I`m dreaming of copying/pasting this to other developing countries once this one is upon running.

What We Need & What You Get

Here are some more details:

  • We are willing to acquire several green trucks to make the most important and booming sector in Turkey greener. Meaning that, we are willing to save diesel by transporting large construction equipment with our trucks. e.g. one large loader would burn nearly 100 ltrs of diesel travelling the distances between construction sites. Towing two of those loaders on a truck would save four times the fuel for the same distance & time. 
  • Of course buying some green trucks won`t save the world. What we would like to do is;

    • to buy climate bonds that supports and develops a sustainable ecosystem

    • invest in renewable energy projects

    • invest into forest projects with

      • TEMA, Turkey (The Turkish Foundation for Combating Soil Erosion, for Reforestation and the Protection of Natutal Habitats)

      • WIRIO, Kenya (Wide Rescue Initiative Organization)

      • GROW, U.S.A (Great Reforestation Organizations of Worth)

To make it more clear, we will use the financial power of  the construction companies and government to repair the damage that they give to our earth

  • Once we secure the first financial round where we makes us to acquire our green trucks, we will be able to work for construction companies, government and other related institutions directly since there is a lack of trucks doing this in this whole country.

The Impact

This campaign may seem like a commercial project but indeed we will be

  • Planting trees
  • Invest in sustainable and renewable energy
  • Support other environmental projects and organizations

to be more environmental friendly and try to save & regenerate the resources for our children.

Risks & Challenges

The main challenge is to finance the first trucks to be able to start immediately. Of course, there will be more trucks to be added to the fleet but this can be done with own financial resources combined with leasing institutions

With a solid international business management background, we have the know-how to make it happen. It will not be easy to start-up a newco but the knowledge of making the right thing will motivate all of us who are involved in the campaign.

Other Ways You Might Help

Some of you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • You can also get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • You can connect us to Leasing Companies / Organizations or Green Funds which can support us at the start-up phase

story:
My name is Dan Williams, I am a Pagan, and I am 23 years old.  Nature has always been something that I have felt very close with.  As a child I would spend hours upon hours in the forest behind my parents house just sitting quietly and listening to the birds and watching animals as they would graze or pass by me.  As I grew older I started camping out in the woods, either by myself or with a few close friends.  Something I have always dreamed about is having a chunk of land where flora and fauna was protected but was open to the public for camping and other nature activities such as hiking, walking, photography, gatherings, etc.  

So, about a year ago I was walking in the woods and I came to the realization that this dream could be a reality if I had the money to do it.  However, money is the main problem.  I do not have the funds to just go out and buy a chunk of land.  Before I divulge too much into the money situation though let me tell you what my vision of this Nature Reserve is.  

I want this Nature Reserve to be a magical place where people, animals, and plants can coexist harmoniously and where no organism feels threatened.  I want people to be able to go up and hangout but not trash the place, i.e. if someone camps there they need to make sure that the place is left the way it was found.  There also would be no hunting or weapons of any sort allowed on the land in order to make the animals feel safe.  There will be a set of very liberal rules set down such as don't chop down trees for fires if you are camping, instead use trees that have already fallen and are dead, because I am sure that there will be plenty of dead fallen trees seeing as the chunk of land will have a forest on it.  Since the land is open to the public free of charge the only payment would be to care for the area and if you see trash or liter, pick it up and leave an offering to Mother Earth such as planting seeds, or a sapling, or even start building a bridge over a wet patch of water (using only natural materials of course), just for a few examples.

I also invision this place to be a place where at some point in my life I can build a small cabin and become the "caretaker" for the area.  I would live off the land by planting a garden, having a green house, purifying my own water and possibly if I wanted electricity building either a wind turbine or creating solar panels, maybe even build a community of "nature caretakers", but that is looking very far into the future.  All-in-all I want this to be a place where people can come, enjoy, respect, and worship Nature.  

Back to the money situation though.  I simply do not have the amount of money saved up in order to make my dream a reality.  I think I have found the perfect spot to do this and It costs about $75,000 which I understand is a substantial amount of cash.  This place has a river, a waterfall, and a pond, plus a plethora of flora and fauna.  There are wild edibles as well such as mushrooms, blackberries, wild strawberries, ramps, etc.  So the land is very rich in that aspect.  So I am asking you, the lovely humans of Earth, to help make my dream a reality.  Every little bit helps, even if its only a dollar.  

Thank you,
Dan Williams

Check out my Facebook Page: http://www.facebook.com/VTWizard
