story:
We are focusing our efforts to creatively inspire those who can have the greatest immediate impact - the men and women who enforce the laws, and can put illegal shark fishermen behind bars. Before making the film, Hugo, our producer from Sea Shepherd said, "If we can't bring these environmental lawyers to Galapagos and take them diving, then we must make them a film, and bring the sharks to their offices."

We hope you can share the good news - that the spanish film has already premiered at an international congress to 130 public prosecutors and environmental lawyers representing more than 16 countries. We also gave them 900 copies to have and share, and everyone was pleased. This means the largest body of environmental lawyers in Latin America now knows why sharks are worth a lot more alive than dead.

After 2 years of shooting in 7 countries, the films are ready. This approach has never been done before. While most films are intended to A, make money and B, educate consumers, neither of these will have an immediate effect of sending more illegal fishermen to jail. Instead, we have partnered with the Network of Environmental Lawyers of Latin America, and the president of the organization shares our excitement in our innovative approach to focus on environmental law.

Today, our funding goal is required to truly put the film to work, and distribute the film to environmental law firms, environmental law schools, and film festivals. We hope to inspire a stewardship among environmental lawyers to award illegal fishermen prison sentences for ocean related crimes.

For the last 3 years, Sea Shepherd Conservation Society and I have been working on this collaborative film project.

Here you can see my recent TEDx Talk titled "Becoming the Voice of Shark Conservation." http://youtu.be/xLC8DxkLL8c    

Sharks are truly amazing creatures, yet many species like Hammerhead Sharks are on the brink of extinction because of one expensive soup ingredient – shark fins. A cold reality now faces us head on – we have already fished out 90% of many species of sharks on planet earth, and we might have as little as a decade before many shark populations go extinct.

This scarcity is now putting huge pressure on the Marine Protected Areas around the planet like the Galapagos Marine Reserve, Cocos Island National Park, Malpelo Nature Reserve, and many others. These areas are designed as a sanctuary for sharks and hundreds of other marine species, yet their peaceful waters are rushed with illegal shark fishermen every day across Latin America and the rest of the world. 

The decline of sharks will affect us all because many sharks are a keystone species in their ecosystem, which has been proven in Hawaii. Furthermore, dolphins are being slaughtered to be used as shark bait. Shark conservation not only helps the ocean ecologically, and us economically, but also for the sake of humanity.

We have been able to postpone funding until now to have a good estimate of the remaining costs to successfully finish the project within the next 6 months. This includes final post production, printing DVDs to be distributed among environmental lawyers and judicial authorities, and the cost to continue sharing both english and spanish versions across the Americas.

Risks and Challenges

 

Filming a topic as huge as the slaughter of sharks is serious and difficult.  Speaking with some shark fishermen can be fun, but on occasion the film crew was warned their lives were in serious danger. When you have someone gesturing to you by dragging his closed fist(as if with a knife) across his throat, it makes you feel much safer around the sharks than the fishermen.

A good lesson learned is that the fishermen are not all bad—they are merely players in a very bad industry. By using the law to enforce sustainable management practices, far more people benefit from a living ocean than a dead one. The shark fin industry will be stopped within 30 years, it is simply with or without the mass extinction of sharks.

The best part of the film has been the collaboration among non-profit organizations, government agencies, judicial authorities, National Park personnel, tourism companies, and countless amazingly passionate individuals.

story:
"Communication for awareness is fundamental"

 "What we should take care of... take care of the Planet"


My name is Fernando Esteban Martinez and with the support of my team  for audio and  video, I want to contribute with my grain of sand with the time that was given to me.


The best way is to keep it simple!


Project definition:

It is an international project, more specifically of an European project.
There will be made ​​recordings for the movie in 15 different European countries.

With future expectations for achieving another project in the USA.

It consists in making the largest, artistic and innovative movie in the world, by mixing rhythm, lyrics, music and videos.
With the main theme: "Taking care of our Planet". And as a secondary theme: "Let´s  take care of ourselves in order to be able to understand that we must protect our planet."


What image is promoted?

"The cultural union, by demonstrating how beautiful is the world where we live in and what should we take care of. Knowing ourselves, more internally, in order to achieve in life, more that what we intend, through struggle,  controlled patience and perseverance".
"How in reality. we all are one and we remain at the same me, but in different "universes".


Why this project?

To make the world a better place.

We will try by  using a Documentary, at an international level. We want to continue bringing awareness of the importance of taking care of the environment and for people to be conscious of this matter, communication is needed as a fundamental basis.

What we need and what you get:

We need financial support for our travels, board and lodging. We will provide the desire, art, knowledge, struggle  and the message.
 


WHAT WE NEED

Money %

FOOD

35%

TRAVELS

20%

LODGING

20%

STUFF

10%

INSURANCE

5%

LICENSES

5%

INCIDENTAL EXPENSES

5%


The result will be art for the environmental protection. It is a common good. Disclosure of the duty of the human being when it comes to take care of the planet.


Thank you so much!!!!!!!!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


"La comunicación para la concienciación es algo fundamental"


Qué debemos cuidar... Cuida el Planeta.


¿La mejor forma? Mostraros el qué, de forma simple!


Mi nombre es Fernando Esteban Martínez y con el soporte de mi equipo,  video y audio, quiero aportar mi grano de arena, con el tiempo que se me ha dado.


Definición del proyecto:

Se trata de un proyecto internacional, mas  en concreto de un proyecto europeo.
Se realizarán grabaciones para el largometraje en 15 países Europeos distintos.


Con vistas al futuro de la realización de otro proyecto en Estados Unidos.

Consiste en la realización del largometraje mas largo, artístico e innovador existente en el mundo, mediante la mezcla el verso rítmico, la música y la filmografía.
Con el tema principal "Cuidemos nuestro Planeta". Y como tema secundario "Cuidémonos a nosotros mismos para poder entender que debemos cuidar nuestro Planeta".

¿Qúe imagen se imparte?

"La unión cultural, mediante la demostración de lo bello que es el mundo en que vivimos y, lo que debemos cuidar. El conocerse mas internamente para conseguir en la vida lo que uno se propone, mediante la lucha, la constancia y la paciencia controlada."
“El cómo en realidad todos somos uno y, permanecemos a un mismo yo, pero en distintos "universos".


¿Por qué este proyecto?

Hacer del mundo un lugar mejor.
Nosotros lo intentaremos mediante un Documental de manera internacional. Queremos seguir haciendo consciencia de lo importante que es cuidar el medio ambiente y, para que la gente haga consciencia de ello se necesita comunicación, como base.

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes:

  • Necesitamos ayuda financiera para nuestros viajes, manutención y alojamiento. Las ganas, el arte, los conocimientos, la lucha y el mensaje lo ponemos nosotros.


WHAT WE NEED

Money %

FOOD

35%

TRAVELS

20%

LODGING

20%

STUFF

10%

INSURANCE

5%

LICENSES

5%

INCIDENTAL EXPENSES

5%


  • Se obtiene arte en defensa del medio ambiente. Se trata de un bien común. La divulgación de lo importante que es cuidar el único planeta que tenemos.


Muchísimas gracias!!!!


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


"Comunicarea pentru gradul de conștientizare este fundamentală"


"Având grijă de planeta noastră"


Vă arătăm lucurile simplu!


Numele meu este Fernando Esteban Martinez și cu sprijinul echipei mele pentru audio și video, vreau să contribui cu grăuntele  meu de nisip în timpul în care mi-a fost dat.


Definiție proiect:

Acesta este un proiect internațional, mai precis un proiect european.
Vor fi făcute înregistrări pentru film în 15 de țări europene diferite.


Cu perspective de viitor în realizarea altor proiecte in Statele Unite.
Acesta constă în a face cel mai mare, artistic și inovator lungmetraj  din lume,  prin combinarea ritmului, versurilor,  muzicii și clipurilor video.
Cu tema principală "Având grijă de planeta noastră". Și, ca temă secundară "Să avem grijă de noi înșine, în scopul de a fi în măsură să înțelegem că trebuie să protejăm planeta noastră."


Ce imagine este promovată?

"Uniunea Culturală, demonstrând cât de frumoasă este lumea în care trăim și de ceea ce ar trebui să avem grijă. Cunoscându-ne pe noi înșine mai mult pe plan intern, în scopul de a obține mai mult de la viață decât ceea ce ne-am propus, prin luptă, răbdare controlată și perseverență".
Cum în realitate, noi toți sunt unul și rămânem la același eu, dar în diferite" universuri ".


De ce acest proiect?

Pentru a face lumea un loc mai bun.
Vom încerca cu ajutorul unui documentar, la un nivel internațional. Vrem  în continuare să atragem atenția asupra gradului de conștientizare a importanței de a avea grijă de mediul înconjurător și pentru ca oamenii să fie conștienți de această problemă, este nevoie de comunicare ca o bază fundamentală.

Ceea ce avem nevoie și ceea ce veți obține:

  • Avem nevoie de sprijin financiar pentru călătoriile noastre, cazare și masă. Noi vă vom oferi dorința, arta, cunoștințe, lupta și mesajul.


WHAT WE NEED

Money %

FOOD

35%

TRAVELS

20%

LODGING

20%

STUFF

10%

INSURANCE

5%

LICENSES

5%

INCIDENTAL EXPENSES

5%

  • Rezultatul va fi artă pentru protecția mediului. Acesta este un bine comun. Dezvăluirea  datoriei ființei umane atunci când vine vorba să aibă grijă de planetă.

Mulțumesc foarte mult!!!!!
story_txt:
"Communication
for awareness is fundamental"
 "What we should take care of... take care of the Planet"

My name is Fernando Esteban Martinez and with the support of my team  for audio and  video, I want to contribute with my grain of sand with the time that was given to me.

The best way is to keep it simple!

Project definition:
It is an
international project, more specifically of an European project.There will be made ​​recordings for the movie in 15 different European countries.

With future expectations for achieving another project in the USA.
It consists in
making the largest, artistic and innovative movie in the world, by mixing
rhythm, lyrics, music and videos.With
the main theme: "Taking care of our
Planet". And as a secondary theme: "Let´s  take care of ourselves in order
to be able to understand that we must
protect our planet."

What
image is promoted?

"The cultural
union, by demonstrating how beautiful is the world where we live in and what should we take care of. Knowing
ourselves, more internally, in order to
achieve in life, more that what we intend, through struggle,  controlled patience and perseverance". "How in
reality. we all are one and we remain at the same me, but in different
"universes".




Why this project?
To make the world a
better place.
We will try by  using a Documentary, at an international
level. We want to continue bringing awareness of the importance of taking care
of the environment and for people to be conscious of this matter, communication
is needed as a fundamental basis.
What we need and
what you get:


We need financial
support for our travels, board and lodging. We will provide the desire, art, knowledge, struggle  and the message.

"La comunicación para la concienciación es algo fundamental"

Qué debemos cuidar... Cuida el Planeta.

¿La mejor forma? Mostraros el qué, de forma simple!

Mi nombre es Fernando Esteban Martínez y con el soporte de mi equipo,  video y audio, quiero aportar mi grano de arena, con el tiempo que se me ha dado.

Definición del proyecto:

Se trata de un proyecto internacional, mas  en concreto de un
proyecto europeo.
Se realizarán grabaciones
para el largometraje en 15 países Europeos distintos.





Con vistas al futuro de la realización de otro proyecto en Estados
Unidos.
Consiste
en la realización del largometraje
mas largo, artístico e innovador
existente en el mundo, mediante la mezcla el verso rítmico, la música y la
filmografía.
Con el tema principal "Cuidemos nuestro Planeta". Y como
tema secundario "Cuidémonos a nosotros mismos para poder entender que debemos cuidar nuestro
Planeta".


¿Qúe imagen se imparte?

"La
unión cultural, mediante la
demostración de lo bello que es el
mundo en que vivimos y, lo que debemos cuidar. El conocerse mas internamente
para conseguir en la vida lo que uno se propone, mediante la lucha, la
constancia y la paciencia controlada."
“El cómo en realidad todos
somos uno y, permanecemos a un mismo yo, pero en distintos
"universos".




¿Por qué este proyecto?



Hacer del mundo un lugar mejor.
Nosotros
lo intentaremos mediante un Documental de manera internacional. Queremos seguir
haciendo consciencia de lo importante que es cuidar el medio ambiente y, para
que la gente haga consciencia de ello se necesita comunicación, como base.



Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes:

Necesitamos ayuda financiera
     para nuestros viajes, manutención y alojamiento. Las ganas, el arte, los
     conocimientos, la lucha y el mensaje lo ponemos nosotros.

Se obtiene arte en
     defensa del medio ambiente. Se trata de un bien común. La divulgación de lo importante que es cuidar el único planeta que tenemos.

story:
I have relaunched this campaign here: http://www.indiegogo.com/BeeKeepingWorld?c=activity&a=97595 or use http://j.mp/IndiegogoSaveOurBees

 

Our Story

Back in October 2011 I watch Vanishing of the Bees and was shocked... It dawned on me in the last 6 years that I lived in Japan I had maybe seen 2 bee! I wondered how the little fuzzy fellows been affected? I was even more shocked to learn that experts think up to 50% of Japan Bees may have died. Wow! 

Because of the Tsunami this did not get much media play. I decided to start-up Beekeeping Japan startup and bought the best hive and kit with the little money the HelpJapanco Venture Fund had raised and set out to find bees... It took me a week and was shocked again that the one place I found had a 5 year waiting period! I persisted... looked and looked... and convinced our local Mikui Honey Bee Shop to get me some (they have 100 Beehives)... they are coming anyday now! I am so excited!  

I've lived in Japan for 6 years, my sons are Japanese and my wife and I want to do something for the Tsunami surviors and for the Japan's bees that have been hit hard. I am an entrepreneur trying to bring about a new paradigm for launching ideas into startups called the Open Startup. BeeKeeping Japan is an open startup. Open startups are startups anyone can join and when they launch they become "selfless" open corp. My goal is simple, I want to prove that anyone can start a beekeeping business with just a little money and have fun and eat honey!   

Our Goals

1. Get the bees in their hive and make them happy! 
2. Record the experience and learn by doing without getting stung too many times... I hope!
3. Share the experience and encourage others via Fukui International Club and hopefully share the joy and passion with others... 
4. Have recruits repeat #1, 2 and 3... until we got to 1,000 community bee hives in Fukui
5. Expand Beekeeping Japan to other Prefectures.  

Here are some of my talks on Beekeeping Japan. Here is out FB fan page where I will post updates.  

The Impact

One beehive at a time... help the bees recover, educate the locals and give the honey to kids of the Tsunami! Repeat, repeat, repeat... The impact could be massive... $500 pays for the hive and gear, and $500 the bees and supplies... If we go over goal we will use it to buy additional hives and bees. 

Why do you think you will succeed?

Determination, passion and persistence! These are the only three things I am excellent at :) Here is motivation... End of Growth is coming! Bee Keeping will be important. 

Past successes? In college I had a crazy idea of producing a Shakespeare Festival. Why? Because there was no professional theater in Tallahassee Florida... In 1994, I started working on the idea. The Southern Shakespeare Festival launched in 1996 - 20K attended. Over 100K attended it. 2 years I left to go to grad school it died. How can beekeeping be harder than doing a Shakespeare festival... :)  I am excited to find out!

story:
“Running after Routledge: Retracing an English Expedition to Easter Island”

As the schooner ‘Mana’ sailed out of Falmouth, England on February 28th 1913 bound for Easter Island, with Katherine and William Scoresby-Routledge plus their expedition team and sailing crew onboard, expectations were high - but there was tension in the air. Whilst waiting for clear conditions and final provisions to arrive, frustrated tempers had flared and threatened the already delayed departure date. However, once the course was set and the journey underway, spirits soared and the crew rallied.

Losing sight of England meant only one thing: Polynesia beckoned.

Introduction 

Exactly 100 years ago a woman from my hometown undertook a journey that would change her life and the lives of a great many people around the world. Her name was Katherine Routledge and she travelled from England to Rapa Nui (called Easter Island by early Europeans).

Routledge’s trip, the 1914 Mana Expedition to Easter Island, was a far-reaching success in terms of human endeavour and scientific research. The team negotiated the 12,000 mile marine journey to Rapa Nui and once there completed a year of ground breaking anthropological field work that when published (The Mystery of Easter Island, Katherine Routledge) introduced the rest of the world to the enchanting Easter Island’s anthropological mysteries. The enigma of the islanders and their Moai statues continue to captivate scientists today.

“Such is Easter Island… All portions of it are accessible; from every part is the wind of heaven; around and above all are boundless sea and sky, infinite space and a great silence. The dweller there is ever listening for he knows not what, feeling unconsciously that he is in the antechamber to something yet more vast which is just beyond his ken.”

Katherine Routledge, The Mystery of Easter Island.

I discovered Katherine’s extraordinary story when I travelled to Rapa Nui in 2005 to volunteer with a youth involvement programme: 'A Po. I was inspired by and fascinated that a lady from my home town, had the vision, drive and belief to undertake such an expedition to this place, half a world away studying culture so alien to her own.

A century has now passed since the Mana Expedition struck out from England. In the eight years since I first visited Rapa Nui, I have seen how important such an intrepid journey was for both Darlington and Rapa Nui. Yet these remarkable connections will untie without remembrance and celebration.

In 2014, a century after the historic expedition I will retrace the voyage of the Mana and in doing so celebrate the expedition’s achievements and trans-world ties whilst returning benefit to the people of Rapa Nui. But, without a custom built boat I have decided to do something else. 

The 2014 Expedition: "Running after Routledge"

Starting from Darlington on 14th February 2014, I will run from the north to the south of England, to Southampton - starting place of the Mana Expedition. Then I will visit a number of places and ports the Mana called into in South America, and will join the dots by cycling from east to west, from Buenos Aires to Santiago. I plan to finish the expedition by visiting Rapa Nui, and completing the island's marathon in June, completing my journey and reconnecting the places that were introduced so many years ago.

In addition to retracing the original expedition my mission is to raise awareness of an urgent subject: contamination of the island’s freshwater aquifer. Partnering with Pacific Aid Australia I’ll be working to raise funds to purchase and install infrastructure to help the island’s environment: a BioMax unit.

While the journey itself will enable me to connect with many people on the ground to fund raise, the delivery of the BioMax unit to Rapa Nui is only the beginning of the story. 

As the expedition follows the path of Katherine Routledge & the Mana, I plan to connect with as many different communities as I can, visit places the Mana Expedition explored and note changes as compared to the world in 1914 - especially the environment. I will use photography and film, and other media to record changes and document as many places and people as I travel. The long term plan is to create a body of work that will contribute to a exhibition - simple named 'Retracing Routledge', that will include works from a range of artists and travel between Darlington and Rapa Nui. 

Katherine Routledge's book, “The Mystery of Easter Island” will act as the point of reference for the main questions of the expedition:

1. How has the environment changed in the 100 years since the 1914 Mana Expedition?

2. What are the main environmental issues facing the modern day Rapa Nui population?

The Mana Expedition set out to answer some of the big anthropological questions of the time – mainly, who were the Rapa Nui people and why did they create giant stone statues? The new goal is to ask environmentally focused questions related to this time, our time – and the hope to provide an insight to 21st century life as compared to that which the Mana team experienced in 1914. As Katherine and her team travelled they couldn’t just pop into an Internet café and send an email update to their loved ones. Instead it took weeks and months for bundles of letters to arrive by boat. 

“Easter Island affords no good anchorage, and our plan was that the yacht, after disembarking the scientific members and waiting awhile off the coast, should return to Talcahuano… to collect letters and goods and then come out again to the island.”

Katherine Routledge, The Mystery of Easter Island.

The 2014 Route:

The Running after Routledge plan has been updated and will now take place over three main stages.

1. February 2014. Darlington to Southampton, UK – overland on foot.

Starting from Hummersknott Academy in Darlington, my former school, I will run this section of the route as a form of personal tribute to the work of Katherine Routledge. To complete this stage I will have to run at least a marathon every day, which will be no easy task in the winter. But I'm looking forward to following the B-roads of England, winding through villages, towns & the countryside towards Southampton. The run will end in Bursledon, on the Hamble River, close to where Katherine and William Scoresby Routledge lived whilst the Mana was being constructed. The full run route can be seen online by clicking HERE.

2.  April/ May 2014. Buenos Aires to Santiago, Chile – overland by bike.

This is where it gets really challenging! With 1500km/ 932miles to cover in roughly one month this section will be the most demanding. In order to reach Rapa Nui in time for the marathon on June 1st at least 30miles will have to be logged every day, in addition to research tasks and marathon training. This will require the utmost in preparation and planning. And then there is the small task of crossing those Andes!

3. June 2014. Rapa Nui.

The finale of the expedition on Rapa Nui will be in two parts. First, a free public presentation will be held to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the 1914 Mana Expedition - showing photos and film clips from along the route of the 'retracing' journey. This is also when an announcement will be made, with Pacific Aid Australia & BioMax, about the delivery of the sewage-digesting unit to the island. And finally... to end the fundraising challenge I will take part in the Rapa Nui Marathon on June 1st.

Thank you! 

Thank you for reading about the new plans for Running after Routlegde! With your continued support Running after Routledge will achieve it's original aims. Please read through the 'perks' of supporting this Indiegogo Campaign and if you have any questions at all about how Indiegogo works, or what it's all about please don't hesitate to contact me via the website: CONTACT HERE.

About Susie Stephen:

As an undergraduate student at Newcastle University in the UK, Susie Stephen studied marine biology and competed in cross-country running events to an international level. Then as graduate student in the Environmental Sciences & Policy program at Northern Arizona University in the US, Susie ran track and cross-country for the college’s NCAA Division 1 team. Since then Susie has been engaging with communities around the world to work on conversation and ecologically minded projects, from Darlington to Mexico, and visited Rapa Nui in 2005. In England Susie worked at the BlueReef Aquarium in Tynemouth before co-founding the clothing exchange business Magpie Swop in 2008. Now living in Hawaii with her husband Jesse, Susie has been planning ‘Running after Routledge’ in between coaching a high school cross country team, teaching yoga, running for Team Oiselle and developing the website: The Long Run Lifestyle.

And finally... to end the fundraising challenge I will take part in the Rapa Nui Marathon on June 1st.Thank you! Thank you for reading about the new plans for Running after Routlegde! With your continued support Running after Routledge will achieve it's original aims. Please read through the 'perks' of supporting this Indiegogo Campaign and if you have any questions at all about how Indiegogo works, or what it's all about please don't hesitate to contact me via the website: CONTACT HERE.About Susie Stephen:As an undergraduate student at Newcastle University in the UK, Susie Stephen studied marine biology and competed in cross-country running events to an international level. Then as graduate student in the Environmental Sciences & Policy program at Northern Arizona University in the US, Susie ran track and cross-country for the college’s NCAA Division 1 team. Since then Susie has been engaging with communities around the world to work on conversation and ecologically minded projects, from Darlington to Mexico, and visited Rapa Nui in 2005. In England Susie worked at the BlueReef Aquarium in Tynemouth before co-founding the clothing exchange business Magpie Swop in 2008. Now living in Hawaii with her husband Jesse, Susie has been planning ‘Running after Routledge’ in between coaching a high school cross country team, teaching yoga, running for Team Oiselle and developing the website: The Long Run Lifestyle.

story:
The Flambeau Mining Company, owned by Rio Tinto, one of the largest multinational mining corporations in the world, polluted a tributary to the Flambeau River near Ladysmith, Wisconsin, harming the health of the water.

My organization, Wisconsin Resources Protection Council, and our partners filed a Clean Water Act lawsuit against them and WE WON—showing they polluted the stream with copper and zinc!

But the bad news is that the decision was overturned by the Court of Appeals on a technicality – a mistake that was made by the state of Wisconsin, and not because our case wasn’t strong.

Amazingly, incredulously, all three plaintiffs together, including us, were ordered to pay the polluter’s court costs—which total over $60,000. I couldn’t believe it, the company polluted, but we had to pay! Wisconsin Resources Protection Council now owes the mining company $20,000.

Will you help us cover these costs with a donation today?

If polluters can get away with bullying citizen groups like ours for trying to enforce the Clean Water Act, it will have a chilling effect on our ability and willingness to speak up about these issues.

With your help, we’ll pay the fees. But we won’t STOP fighting to make sure mines don’t harm our state’s precious water supplies, the tourism and dairy industries, and the many Native American communities that are located near potential mine sites.

Your support today will allow us to continue our focus to keep mines accountable. Will you stick with us and help us now?

More information

I first got involved in the Flambeau mine when I was a sociology student at the University of Wisconsin-Madison in the 1970s. Little did I know that for the next nearly 40-years I would dedicate my volunteer time to helping communities protect their natural resources from the impacts of mines.

Most of that work was through the Wisconsin Resources Protection Council. Started in 1982, the Wisconsin Resources Protection Council has remained true to its origins—we continue to be an entirely volunteer-run grassroots organization and because of this it has allowed us to stay true to our mission—and not compromise.

Wisconsin Resources Protection Council has fought hard since our inception to protect Wisconsin’s natural resources and way of life from being impacted by mining. Over the years we have had some great victories, such as:

  • Our Clean Water Act lawsuit against Flambeau is truly a success—this stream is listed as impaired by the EPA due to copper and zinc toxicity.

  • The Adoption of the “Prove it First” legislation—that stated a mine had to prove it is possible to not pollute in order to get a permit.

  • The Crandon Mine—that resulted in the transfer of mineral rights to two tribes that vowed never to develop.


We won’t be silenced by a big, international corporate bully! Wisconsin Resources Protection Council is continuing our work more now than ever, by protecting Lake Superior and the wild rice beds of the Bad River Ojibwe Tribe from the world's largest proposed open pit iron mine.

We will keep working, even though Wisconsin Resources Protection Council is small and underfunded. We have always been there protecting your health and the natural beauty of our region. Will you be there for us now?

If we all pitch in a little—we can reach our goal quickly. Isn’t that what citizen activism is all about?

Don’t let Rio Tinto and the courts silence communities. Please donate today.

WRPC's Mission:

The Wisconsin Resources Protection Council (WRPC) was founded in 1982 to help counter the lack of information about the effects of large-scale metallic sulfide mining on our state’s precious water supplies, on the tourism and dairy industries, and upon the many Native American communities that are located near potential mine sites.

Our members share a common goal: to educate the public about the consequences of allowing international mining corporations to develop a new mining district in northern Wisconsin. We believe that current laws and rules regarding iron mining in Wisconsin simply do not offer the kind of protection we need in order to insure that mining operations will take place without unacceptable damage to our state's environment and economy.


More about Wisconsin Resource Protection Council's work:

Mine disaster could happen to Lake Superior (Article, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, August 21, 2014)

Wisconsin is testing ground for mining industry response to opposition (Article, The Capital Times, March 7, 2013)

Public Testimony against Wisconsin Senate Bill 278 (Video, Senate Mining Committee hearing, September 4, 2013)

Discussion of Mining, Legislation, and Resistance (Audio, WORT Madison Community Radio, November 8, 2012)

A Conversation between Al Gedicks and Steve Watrous on Twenty Years of the Wisconsin Network for Peace and Justice (Video, February, 2011)

Mining War in Ecuador (Article, Z Magazine, March 2005)

Mining Industry Targets “Prove It First” Law (Article, Z Magazine, February 2013)

New Wisconsin iron mining bill will be devastating to the environment (Article, News From Indian Country, 2013)

Resisting Resource Colonialism in the Lake Superior Region (pdf, Z Magazine, September, 2011)

Interview on Opposition to Mining in Wisconsin and El Salvador (Audio, The Progressive, December 3, 2012)

Wisconsin’s Mining Moratorium Under Attack (Article, January, 2013)

Defending a Common Home: Native/non-Native Alliances against Mining Corporations in Wisconsin (Article, August 29, 2004)

Militarized Mining in Wisconsin (Article, Z Magazine, September 27, 2013)

Repeal Wisconsin's Mining Law (Article, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, March 10, 2014)

story:
Let's get the Real News out there

With a radio background and several years reporting on renewable energy, climate change, and the environment, we decided to start an internet radio station dedicated to our cause. That cause is the survival of our only planet. 

We have a team of green builders, solar installers,energy efficiency specialists, environmentalists, radio personalities, and just passionate people wanting to get the word out that change can happen before it's too late.

With donations to CarbonFreeRadio.com, you will be helping us broadcast to the world with truly carbon free sources. Your contribution will help us purchase the components to build portable  power units to broadcast from anywhere in the world where the sun shines.

We want subscribers to pledge that they too will listen carbon free. This can be done through purchasing a portable solar power plant to run their computer or phone, installing a home solar array,or remote purchasing of community solar.

Our experience in broadcasting gives us an advantage in the business and entertainment side of broadcasting. I have reported at various energy and solar conferences in the U.S., Mexico, Central America, and China. I have been a correspondent at the UNFCCC, World Energy Forum, AREDAY, and ASIASOLAR. I have other broadcasters from four continents that will help with the programming. You can look at the list of previous interviews at earthup.podbean.com


What We Need & What You Get

Solar powered mini studios with an off grid solar array that powers a computer, camera, and audio devices to broadcast carbon free. With meeting our funding goal we can set up a mini studio on each continent on the planet.

What you get is informative podcasts and live streaming interviews from guests around the world.

As the network grows, we will have broadcasting 24-7 from grassroots sources that originate from around the world. 

    The Impact

    We intend to inform and engage our listeners through the Google Hangout broadcasting platform where we can provide programming from various parts of the globe and invite listeners to collaborate on critical change in human behavior. 

    With increased awareness of global issues dealing with energy and climate change, we will bring a groundswell of grassroots change. We want anyone to be able to add programming to our platform through submission and review of material. 

    Risks & Challenges

    Our risk is that we fail to inform the public and get them to change to a low carbon existence and we all become extinct. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you cannot donate, please spread the word and help us in the quest to build a future for this planet.

story:
Our pristine agricultural valley, the Avon Valley, is water catchment for critical Western Australia water supplies. Now it is set to become a huge metropolitan waste dump! At considerable cost we have proven that the proposed York landfill site will pollute both the Mundaring catchment and the Swan River. For the next 40 plus years this tip will leak dangerous toxins such as mercury, cyanide, lead,  arsenic and cadmium into the Avon Valley’s ground water and into the State’s water supply.

OUT OF SIGHT IS NOT OUT OF MIND!
Landfill sites on Perth’s coastal plain are now polluting Perth’s ground water so the Government has handed the problem over to the private sector. The multinational corporation SITA has proposed the Avon valley, as the next long term landfill site for Perth. For our Politicians out of sight is out of mind and the approval processes are moving unchecked through the bureaucracy. But York Shire Council has voted unanimously to reject this proposal and the local regional planning authority (JDAP ) has also rejected this prime farmland and water catchment area as a site for  polluting landfill.  

FACTS AND SOLUTIONS
Within five years this tip will see up to a million tonnes a year of toxic city waste transported by road train and dumped onto viable agricultural land. A potential road train movement every 3 minutes for 40 years is NOT responsible carbon management and will be very dangerous for commuters on precarious country roads. We propose the safe and cost effective alternative of trains with a fraction of the carbon footprint moving the waste to abandoned mine sites in the goldfields that have the infrastructure in place and no ground water pollution problems. YOUR DONATION will allow us to present professional alternatives to the decision makers.

LET COMMON SENSE PREVAIL
Western Australiahas a critically sensitive fresh water supply that is set to get even more critical with the increasing population. Jeopardising our precious water resources is wrong. The Avon Valley Residents Association (AVRA) is an incorporated voluntary group representing the people of our valley and by default the interests of the people of Perth. YOUR DONATION will help will us pay for very expensive hydrological reports and other costs of running a professional campaign against the proposed landfill in the Avon Valley.

Let’s get it right this time! We have PROVEN the potential for serious pollution of the drinking water. Don’t put us on hold, your donation WILL help! Please donate NOW!

story:
The next few years present unprecedented opportunities to activate young people — in Virginia and across the country — to take back our future from the fossil fuel industry and demand climate policy solutions that match the scale of the climate crisis. This summer, students with the Virginia Student Environmental Coalition are building out a plan to remove the energy giant Dominion Resources’ social license in our state, beat back against their narrative of clean natural gas, and build the power of the millennial generation to win stronger climate policy. We need your support to bring the heat this summer and beyond.

Context

Virginians overwhelmingly support expanding the use of renewable energy and government action on climate, but Dominion Resources — the electric utility and natural gas company — is standing in the way of progress. In the 2015 legislative session of the Virginia General Assembly, every single energy bill that the company supported passed; each bill that it opposed failed. Dominion has given money to every single politician in the current legislature, gave $160,000 to Governor Terry McAuliffe in his bid for office, and spends as much money on campaign donations as Democratic and Republican parties of Virginia. In order to get progress on climate policy in our state, Dominion must be the first domino to fall.

About us

The Virginia Student Environmental Coalition (VSEC) is working to activate youth political power to impact climate, energy, and environmental justice in Virginia and beyond. With chapters on over 15 campuses, VSEC unifies hundreds of students across Virginia in a network for advocacy, education, and action.
U.S. Climate Plan is a building a movement of people who understand that tackling the global climate crisis requires bold and visionary federal action from the United States. Young people have the moral authority and therefore the duty to ensure a prosperous future for ourselves and for future generations, and we believe the political empowerment of youth is key to  confronting the climate crisis. Future Power is about transforming the millennial generation's passive support for government action on climate change to active support for policy changes that match the scale of the challenge. 

Meet the Future Power Fellows

Laura: I am a rising second year at the University of Virginia. I first became involved in VSEC this past fall after attending the People's Climate March in New York City and a Mountain Justice summit on mountain top removal in West Virginia. I am motivated to act on climate because climate change will disproportionately affect marginalized peoples. The driving forces of climate change are also causing global inequality and violence along the lines of race, gender, class, religion, and sexuality. Growing up in the United States, I am outraged that political representation goes to the highest bidder, no more evident than in the influence of the fossil fuel industry. Young people should not have to purchase the right to a safe future. We have a unique ability to see beyond what is currently before us, and demand a more just future from our government representatives. Fossil free is absolutely possible in Virginia — it is simply a matter of political will.

Rabib: I am a senior at the University of Mary Washington. I joined VSEC after attending the 2014 Virginia Power Shift, where I was inspired to see hundreds of active youth who were putting their beliefs into action. As a member of my university's divestment campaign, DivestUMW, I've seen the power of a grassroots movement in action and the empowering effects that it can have. I believe that you do not need to be a politician or a CEO in a suit in order to make an impact, and I intend to use my time over the summer to act on that notion.

Strategy

Dominion’s influence seems overwhelming, but in reality it only has the power granted to it by the people, politicians, and institutions in our state. We can build a social movement to build up our own power — the power of young people — and weaken Dominion’s by forcing students and the public at large out of passivity through escalating tactics around four critical pillars of support:

  • News media — Demand accountability from major outlets who report on Dominion and state energy policy.

  • Public relations and advertising — Counter Dominion’s misinformation about its support for renewable energy and the environmental efficacy of natural gas.

  • Universities — Expose the ties of Dominion executives to Virginia universities and leverage our schools to remove the company’s social license.

  • Politicians — Make Dominion a toxic political ally in the lead-up to the 2015 elections by naming and shaming the politicians who accept the most campaign contributions from the company and have the worst environmental records. Register student voters to build a climate constituency that will serve as a powerful alternative to accepting support from Dominion.

Where Your Money Is Going

This strategy is moving forward whether we have the funds or not, but in order to really make a splash when school starts back up in the fall, we need organizers who can dedicate themselves fully to research, development of specific tactics and timelines, raising awareness, and planning for our big August retreat to launch the campaign with hundreds of students before the start of the academic year.

Here is our minimal budget for two Future Power Virginia Fellows to work over the summer in Richmond, VA with support from U.S. Climate Plan in Washington, DC:

Food: $250/month/fellow * 3 months * 2 fellows = $1500
Transportation costs: ~$80/trip * 4 trips a month * 3 months = $1,000
Living stipend: $500/fellow * 2 fellows = $1,000
Payment processing fees: ($1500+1000+1000)*4%=$140
Indiegogo fees: ($1500+1000+1000)*3%= $105
Total: $3,745

If we surpass our minimal budget, your money will go to support the cost of perks and campaign materials for actions, events, and our end of summer statewide retreat.

Summer timeline

  • June: Teams form around the four pillars of our strategy and research and action planning begins
  • July: Research continues, prepare for August actions around release of final Clean Power Plan rule and other key events, voter registration begins
  • August: Preparation begins in earnest for the massive convergence to kick off the school year and fully launch the campaign on campuses across the state

What have we done so far?

  • September 2014 - VSEC sends dozens of students to the People’s Climate March in New York City

  • January 2014 - VSEC meets up in Richmond to meet with lawmakers in the Virginia General Assembly to advocate for the Virginia Coastal Protection Act. Began forming relationships with state Senators and Representatives. After dropping off hundreds of letters, VSEC members met with Former Deputy Secretary of Natural Resources Evan Feinman to advocate against Atlantic Coast Pipeline and for no new natural gas infrastructure.

  • February 2015 - VSEC teams up with the Virginia Student Power Network to put on their second Virginia Power Shift -- a three day event of speakers, workshops, and trainings for youth in Virginia over 300 people in attendance. We kicked off the event with the biggest student march for fossil fuel divestment.  Read some reflections on Power Shift here.

  • March 2015 - On March 27th, students of DivestUMW at the University of Mary Washington began their sit-in for divestment. Students come from all over the state to sit together in order to demand a action for a just future from their administration. On April 16th, the sit-in ends when the University of Mary Washington’s administration facilitates the arrest of two VSEC students.

  • April 2015 - UMW divestment sit-in continues until Divestment Day of Action occurs across all VSEC campuses. VSEC members attend the New Republic's event The Next Frontier of Climate Change - State and Local Action in Virginia to question and press McAuliffe on statewide divestment

  • May 2015 - On May 6th, VSEC protests Dominion’s Atlantic Coast Pipeline at their May Shareholders meeting, joining other Virginia groups such as Virginia Sierra Club, Richmond Resistance, and organizations fighting the Atlantic Coast Pipeline such as Friends of Buckingham, Friends of Nelson, and Friends of Augusta. (Here’s Laura and Rabib). VSEC organized the Atlantic Coast Pipeline Resistance Ride, a 300 mile bike ride along the route of the proposed pipeline. Along the way, Virginia students met with community member and landowners. When the riders reached Richmond we held a press conference with local news and then held a critical mass bike ride of over 50 people to Dominion’s Richmond headquarters and then down to Dominion’s Riverrock festival. Later that evening, the resistance riders teamed up local activists to send a vivid message to Dominion - No Atlantic Coast Pipeline. See our blog here!

  • June 2015 - The summer begins! VSEC students are working this summer  with organizations such as the Chesapeake Climate Action Network, Sierra Club, 350.org’s Fossil Free Fellowship, SustainUS, and U.S. Climate Plan.

Risks & Challenges

Students have been on the forefront of almost every progressive movement in the last century. We have the ability to dedicate our time and energy while at university to push for something that goes beyond a typical career and work towards social justice. While we are in the perfect atmosphere for activism, there is one big road block that we face every year- the black hole that is summer vacation.

Students in Virginia are working to overcome this obstacle by working through their time off in order to ensure that the momentum that youth has created does not stop.

While we cannot ensure a massive body of student activists over the summer, we are doing what we can to keep things moving forward and lay the foundation for the big action in the year ahead.

Fossil free is absolutely possible in Virginia — it is simply a matter of political will.




Rabib: I am a senior at the University of Mary Washington. I joined VSEC after attending the 2014 Virginia Power Shift, where I was inspired to see hundreds of active youth who were putting their beliefs into action. As a member of my university's divestment campaign, DivestUMW, I've seen the power of a grassroots movement in action and the empowering effects that it can have. I believe that you do not need to be a politician or a CEO in a suit in order to make an impact, and I intend to use my time over the summer to act on that notion.
  Strategy 
Dominion’s influence seems overwhelming, but in reality it only has the power granted to it by the people, politicians, and institutions in our state. We can build a social movement to build up our own power — the power of young people — and weaken Dominion’s by forcing students and the public at large out of passivity through escalating tactics around four critical pillars of support:

News media — Demand accountability from major outlets who report on Dominion and state energy policy.
Public relations and advertising — Counter Dominion’s misinformation about its support for renewable energy and the environmental efficacy of natural gas.
Universities — Expose the ties of Dominion executives to Virginia universities and leverage our schools to remove the company’s social license.
Politicians — Make Dominion a toxic political ally in the lead-up to the 2015 elections by naming and shaming the politicians who accept the most campaign contributions from the company and have the worst environmental records. Register student voters to build a climate constituency that will serve as a powerful alternative to accepting support from Dominion.
   Where Your Money Is Going  
This strategy is moving forward whether we have the funds or not, but in order to really make a splash when school starts back up in the fall, we need organizers who can dedicate themselves fully to research, development of specific tactics and timelines, raising awareness, and planning for our big August retreat to launch the campaign with hundreds of students before the start of the academic year.
Here is our minimal budget for two Future Power Virginia Fellows to work over the summer in Richmond, VA with support from U.S. Climate Plan in Washington, DC:
Food: $250/month/fellow * 3 months * 2 fellows = $1500Transportation costs: ~$80/trip * 4 trips a month * 3 months = $1,000Living stipend: $500/fellow * 2 fellows = $1,000Payment processing fees: ($1500+1000+1000)*4%=$140Indiegogo fees: ($1500+1000+1000)*3%= $105Total: $3,745
If we surpass our minimal budget, your money will go to support the cost of perks and campaign materials for actions, events, and our end of summer statewide retreat.
Summer timeline

June: Teams form around the four pillars of our strategy and research and action planning begins
July: Research continues, prepare for August actions around release of final Clean Power Plan rule and other key events, voter registration begins
August: Preparation begins in earnest for the massive convergence to kick off the school year and fully launch the campaign on campuses across the state
 
What have we done so far?

September 2014 - VSEC sends dozens of students to the People’s Climate March in New York City 
January 2014 - VSEC meets up in Richmond to meet with lawmakers in the Virginia General Assembly to advocate for the Virginia Coastal Protection Act. Began forming relationships with state Senators and Representatives. After dropping off hundreds of letters, VSEC members met with Former Deputy Secretary of Natural Resources Evan Feinman to advocate against Atlantic Coast Pipeline and for no new natural gas infrastructure.
February 2015 - VSEC teams up with the Virginia Student Power Network to put on their second Virginia Power Shift -- a three day event of speakers, workshops, and trainings for youth in Virginia over 300 people in attendance. We kicked off the event with the biggest student march for fossil fuel divestment.  Read some reflections on Power Shift here.
March 2015 - On March 27th, students of DivestUMW at the University of Mary Washington began their sit-in for divestment. Students come from all over the state to sit together in order to demand a action for a just future from their administration. On April 16th, the sit-in ends when the University of Mary Washington’s administration facilitates the arrest of two VSEC students. 
April 2015 - UMW divestment sit-in continues until Divestment Day of Action occurs across all VSEC campuses. VSEC members attend the New Republic's event The Next Frontier of Climate Change - State and Local Action in Virginia to question and press McAuliffe on statewide divestment 
May 2015 - On May 6th, VSEC protests Dominion’s Atlantic Coast Pipeline at their May Shareholders meeting, joining other Virginia groups such as Virginia Sierra Club, Richmond Resistance, and organizations fighting the Atlantic Coast Pipeline such as Friends of Buckingham, Friends of Nelson, and Friends of Augusta. (Here’s Laura and Rabib). VSEC organized the Atlantic Coast Pipeline Resistance Ride, a 300 mile bike ride along the route of the proposed pipeline. Along the way, Virginia students met with community member and landowners. When the riders reached Richmond we held a press conference with local news and then held a critical mass bike ride of over 50 people to Dominion’s Richmond headquarters and then down to Dominion’s Riverrock festival. Later that evening, the resistance riders teamed up local activists to send a vivid message to Dominion - No Atlantic Coast Pipeline. See our blog here! 
June 2015 - The summer begins! VSEC students are working this summer  with organizations such as the Chesapeake Climate Action Network, Sierra Club, 350.org’s Fossil Free Fellowship, SustainUS, and U.S. Climate Plan.


Risks & Challenges
Students have been on the forefront of almost every progressive movement in the last century. We have the ability to dedicate our time and energy while at university to push for something that goes beyond a typical career and work towards social justice. While we are in the perfect atmosphere for activism, there is one big road block that we face every year- the black hole that is summer vacation.
Students in Virginia are working to overcome this obstacle by working through their time off in order to ensure that the momentum that youth has created does not stop. While we cannot ensure a massive body of student activists over the summer, we are doing what we can to keep things moving forward and lay the foundation for the big action in the year ahead.

story:
¿Qué persigue Rentik?

Queremos crear ciudades más sostenibles y habitables a través del uso de motocicletas eléctricas alimentadas con energía renovable y que además, gracias al uso de las baterías extraibles, nos permite realizar cambios rápidos sin tener que esperar durante las recargas.

Nuestro objetivo es que empresas con grandes demandas de movilidad en el entorno urbano (paquetería, reparto a domicilio, etc.) cambien sus actuales vehículos de combustión por otros eléctricos, más respetuosos con el medio ambiente y con las personas que viven en las ciudades.

Nuestro servicio ofrece un renting de nueva generación. Ponemos a disposición del cliente todo lo que incluye un renting convencional (mantenimiento, seguros, etc.) y le entregamos una motocicleta eléctrica a coste cero. El usuario paga una cuota mensual por el uso de la motocicleta que además incluye toda la energía que precise a lo largo del mes. Seleccionamos y personalizamos motocicletas eléctricas para adaptarlas a las necesidades de nuestro cliente y le brindamos un servicio de recogida y entrega de baterías siempre cargadas con energía 100% renovable y sin esperas. 


Dónde estamos y a dónde queremos ir

Hace seis meses comenzamos a sentar las bases del proyecto y en solo tres meses, conseguimos que la mayor empresa de reparto en España se decidiera a probar nuestro sistema.

http://www.europapress.es/navarra/noticia-proyectos-emprendedores-seleccionados-gobierno-probara-motos-electricas-repartir-correo-20140130155122.html

Los resultados hablan por sí solos, hemos reducido la demanda energética en un 86% y hemos eliminado totalmente las emisiones contaminantes dentro de las ciudades.

Aún así, necesitamos crecer para alcanzar el volumen necesario que haga el proyecto autosuficiente, y para llegar a este objetivo nos gustaría contar con tu apoyo.


Nuestra idea

Tenemos sol de sobra para poder mover todas las motocicletas que actualmente queman gasolina ¿por qué no lo aprovechamos?

Queremos llegar al mayor número de empresas que actualmente usan motocicletas de combustión y convencerles de que el reparto en motocicleta eléctrica no solo es un gran ahorro económico. Además, contribuye de manera rotunda a mejorar la calidad de vida en las ciudades gracias a la eliminación de ruidos, humos y sobre todo, nuestra fuerte dependencia energética.

Colaborando con nuestro proyecto estarás ayudando a crear un mundo más sostenible para tí y para todos los que vivimos en él ¿no estás harto de salir a la calle y respirar humo?

Las pruebas que hemos realizado en colaboración con el Grupo Correos, han demostrado que es viable realizar el reparto con motos eléctricas. Además gracias a las baterías extraíbles, nos aseguramos que toda la energía procede de fuentes renovables.



Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

En primer lugar, estamos muy agradecidos por el tiempo que nos has dedicado. Si no puedes ayudar económicamente, no te preocupes, siempre hay otras formas de colaborar y una muy útil, es la difusión entre tus contactos. Las posibilidades son infinitas, puedes colgarlo en redes sociales o contárselo a tus amig@s mientras os tomáis un un café.

story:
^ ^ ^ Please take just 3 minutes of your day to watch the video! ^ ^ ^

******************************MAJOR UPDATE***************************

It's happening! We reached our initial threshold in the first week!  Now, the pressure is on!  To ensure the best chance for success replacing the forest that will be destroyed, we need to raise another $1,200 to ensure we have the appropriate tools, the best soil for our babies, protection from critters, and access to the best diversity of species! Your support is more important than ever now! Please kick in today!!

With the generous support of our donors, we will be able to purchase the 1000 seedlings needed to replace the 1000 trees to be destroyed on my property, and begin to rebuild the community of millions of organisms that will be slaughtered when the pipeline goes through... but realistically, this is only the beginning of the struggle.

I want to ensure a natural diversity of species by introducing  a limited number of higher priced species and more mature saplings into the mix, and to ensure the survival of these trees which I hope to nurture over the coming years and that so many have purchased with their hard earned money. I hope to raise enough funds now (another $1000 to $1500) to be able to nourish them with a few loads of good quality compost and mulch, and protect them from critters in their earliest years with fencing and 200-300 tree tubes (which cost from $2-$3 each! wow!).  

I'm also hatching a plan that will hopefully have ripple effects from this campaign up and down the route of this pipeline, and on similar future projects across the USA. More details on that to come in the days ahead!

************************Back to our original story... ***********************

The Story:

This is my playground, Bear Foothills Farm, in the beautiful western Catskills in upstate New York.

Fulfilling a life-long dream, this spring I will begin the process of turning this abandoned farmland and forest into an organic sheep farm, a market garden and my home, using permaculture design principles and sustainable technologies.


This is the route of of the recently approved 30” Constitution Pipeline which, in spite of advertised ‘benefits’ to the New York and New England markets, will in fact transport fracked gas from northeast Pennsylvania under high pressure north to Wright, NY - near Albany, and from there on to Canada for export across the globe.


This is Moxie, my miniature Australian Shepherd, standing at the Constitution Pipeline’s gateway through thousands of acres of uninterrupted mixed deciduous Eastern Woodland forest.


This is where the Constitution Pipeline will be built this summer, clearing a 125’ permanent right-of-way across my playground and through my forest.

In October, I received a letter from a different company, Tennessee Gas, informing me that they plan to build a second, larger pipeline - the NED, with an additional 125’ right away right beside the Constitution in 2017.


These are my neighbors, just up the hill, through the forest.

These are some of the nearly 1000 trees and bushes on Bear Foothills Farm that are scheduled to be cut down sometime in the coming weeks. Alder saplings to mature sugar maples, giant white pines to dainty fragrant cedar, a stately black cherry, several shimmering silvery beech and two stands of graceful white birch. a few shaggy old hickories and the grandfather, a 250 year old red oak.


Williams & Cabot have their crews staged locally and standing by. Once a federal judge gives them the go ahead, any day now, they will strike like lightning, felling everything in their path.

The Impact:

The numbers are staggering. Over 1000 acres of New York forest will be clearcut to make way for the Constitution Pipeline - that’s over a half million trees.

A recent Stanford University study concluded that every metric ton of CO2 emissions results in economic damages amounting to $220, damages paid by society.

Clear cutting 1000 acres of forests will release 161,000 metric tons of CO2 into the atmosphere - that means this pipeline project will cost our local communities over $35,000,000 - the economic damages caused JUST from clear cutting the trees for the project and disturbing the forest soils - this doesn’t include the emissions from the machinery used to remove the trees.

50,000,000 Gallons of Water PER DAY will no longer be evaporated back to the atmosphere by the missing trees, but will instead be available to erode the slopes of the beautiful catskill mountains...

... increase the turbidity of our world-famous pristine trout streams...

... and compound the flood danger in our local communities that have already seen 5 catastrophic 100-year floods in just the last 15 years.

The Plan:

I’m committed and prepared to plant 1,000 trees & bushes this spring - to begin to restore what the callous Williams & Cabot Oil companies plan to take from me and destroy - but I need your help.

I have the place - next to, but outside the proposed TGP construction easement - right in Williams’ & Cabot’s face -

I have the nature-inspired permaculture design and detailed planting plans.

I have the time and the tools… all I need now are the trees!

The state and county tree sales are on now, and at an average $1 per tree I need to place the order right away… but even at such a bargain, 1000 trees is beyond my reach. I need your help TODAY!

Thank you for your support!

50,000,000 Gallons of Water PER DAY will no longer be evaporated back to the atmosphere by the missing trees, but will instead be available to erode the slopes of the beautiful catskill mountains...



... increase the turbidity of our world-famous pristine trout streams...


... and compound the flood danger in our local communities that have already seen 5 catastrophic 100-year floods in just the last 15 years.

The Plan:
I’m committed and prepared to plant 1,000 trees & bushes this spring - to begin to restore what the callous Williams & Cabot Oil companies plan to take from me and destroy - but I need your help.




I have the place - next to, but outside the proposed TGP construction easement - right in Williams’ & Cabot’s face - 

I have the nature-inspired permaculture design and detailed planting plans.

I have the time and the tools… all I need now are the trees!


The state and county tree sales are on now, and at an average $1 per tree I need to place the order right away… but even at such a bargain, 1000 trees is beyond my reach.  I need your help TODAY!


Thank you for your support!

story:
Unit Selam UGM

                                 

Unit Selam UGM is one of college student organization whose focus in  marine conservation in Gadjah Mada University, Indonesia.

We concerned about marine biodiversity conservation in Indonesia, and we commit to do so much thing for ocean sustainability. We did a project named Reef Covery, for monitoring fishes and reefs in some spot in Indonesia, like in Baluran marine park, and Peucang Island in Ujung Kulon marine park. We did this project since 2003. Not only that, we also do reef transplantation in those marine park.

                                 

                                  

                                  

Beside that thing, Unit Selam UGM also has other divisions, like underwater photography and videography, search and rescue, and the last athlete for fin swimming.

We consist of so much  youth member from so many background in university, like from fisheries major, social humanities major, engineering major, biological and science, and many others. So we hope this differences majors can help us to think and manage this campaign globally.

Actually this organization founded since 1987, and now is 27 anniversary of this organization.

Indonesia Archipelago

- Indonesia is one of the world largest archipelago in the world, who has 17,508 - 18,306 islands. and 8,844 that have been named according to estimates made by the Government of Indonesia, with 922 of those permanently inhabited.

- According to The New York Times scientist at works, Indonesia is located in coral triangle, that means we have the most marine biodiversity habitat, who has 590 species of reef-building coral and 4000 species of tropical fishes.


- Beside that amazing fact, as the world’s most diverse marine environment, the Coral Triangle supports the livelihoods of more than 340 million people.

- Indonesia as the largest coral reef area in Southeast Asia. Estimates of the extent of these coral reefs vary, but they likely total about 51,000 km². Indonesia’s coral reefs are among the most biologically rich in the world. 

- Depends on, STATE OF THE CORAL TRIANGLE: Indonesia book, surveys of coral reefs in Indonesia have improved slightly over the last decade. At the end of 2008, about 5% of the reefs were in excellent condition, 25% in good condition, 37% in moderate condition, and 32% in bad condition.

Banda Neira

- Banda Neira is one of few islands in the world that can proudly boast a beautiful landscape filled with rare and exotic wildlife, spectacular dive spots, coloured with exquisite corals and alive with all manner of sea creatures, and centuries of incredible history. A history both tremendous and tragic. A history of wealth and war. And the remnants remain to tell the story.


- Two of the biggest islands, Banda Besar and Naira, are covered with nutmeg trees. The third island, Gunung Api or ‘peak of fire’, is an active volcano that emerges from the deep in a perfect cone, and is entirely rugged and highly volcanic. In the waters surrounding these islands you’ll find some of the world’s most spectacular marine gardens, with bright corals and colorful fish, bustling through the crystal-clear waters, making it suitable for diving, snorkeling or even simply sightseeing.

The Plan
1. Openning ceremony in Yogyakarta, in December 2014
2. Reef and fishes monitoring with Line Intercept Transect method, in the end of January 2015
3. Reef Transplantation, in the end of January 2015
4. National Seminar about ocean sustainability, in February 2015
5. Education for local people about ocean issue, in the beginning of February 2015
6. National Exhibition in Jakarta, Yogyakarta, and Ambon, in March 2015

What We Need

1. National Seminar : $ 2500

2. Exhibition : $2500

3. Transportation (Yogyakarta - Banda Neira) for 10 person : $2700

4. Accomodation for 10 person for 5 days : $750

5. Dive Equipment 5 sets : $5000

6. Documentation Equipment for underwater
- Canon G16 2 sets : $1500
- Go Pro 2 sets : $1400
-Strobe 2 sets : $1000
7. Transplantation Equipment : $1000
8. Notebook : $1500
9. Openning Ceremony ; $1000

story:
The Project

SantElm66 is both a site and an experience. The stunning new construction is near completion and will be open to anyone who is passionate about the environmental issues facing our world, regardless of technical knowledge or qualifications. Here participants will engage together and meet inspiring innovators and artists, as well as have time to relax and enjoy nature, healthy living, and local cuisine.  

Together we will look for answers to the questions: What choices and actions should we take to improve our living environment now and for the future? How can good and thoughtful design, art and architecture contribute to better living and a healthier planet? How can we best share our living spaces and benefit from exchanges with creators and each other? 

Conceived by Charles Poisay, environmentally committed architect, and Louise Brody, curator and designer, SantElm66 began as a dream some years ago and that dream is now becoming a reality.

Multi-disciplinary sessions - group discussions, conferences, workshops, site visits, exhibitions and hands-on activities - as well as artists' residencies will provide the opportunty to collaborate and learn from one other. Join us for the space of a long weekend or a 6-day residence and benefit from these sessions that will empower you to build your own circles of influence.

Together for a Better Future

The future is not what will happen, but what we are going to do. Henri Bergson

6-DAY RESIDENCES include encounters and discussions each morning, led by a specialist. Themes offered are:  

  • 1. Architecture and landscaping: Environmental architecture and landscaping, and their implications in our lives.  
  • 2. Design: New modes of production and how we consume objects and everyday products.  
  • 3. New perspectives on artistic practices: Photographers, painters, and writers discuss how art influences our perceptions and can help us gain new perspectives.  

During the 6-day sessions SantElm66 can accommodate up to six people (three bedrooms), with half board included.

2-DAY MINI-RESIDENCES center around local resources and include at least one visit to a related site nearby. Themes offered are:

  • 1. Organic produce and wine, regional markets and cooking  
  • 2. Local artisanal and contemporary production (cork, ceramics, home construction and furnishings from recycled materials)

During the 2-day sessions SantElm66 can accommodate up to six people (three bedrooms), with half board included.

Dinner-conferences with a specialist or noted expert will be organized for small groups.

Activities and workshops at SantElm66 will be held during the months of June and July.
Further details of the workshop programs and location can be found on the website santelm66. Names of workshop leaders will be provided later. A wide range of lodgings is available in town.

 Activities will be trilingual: English / Spanish / French as needed.

The Location

SantElm66 is named after the Sant Elm hermitage close by, which has one of the most breathtaking views of the Mediterranean coastline. SantElm66 is at 66 meters altitude, between sea and forest. 

The site is less than 5 minutes walking distance from the town center. An hour from Barcelona and 30 minutes from Girona, it is easily accessible by public transport. The region, known as “Emporda”, is particularly eco-sensitive, and produces some of Spain’s finest olive oils and wines. It boasts many forests and natural reserves with great hiking trails as well as organic farms and vineyards which workshop participants will be invited to visit.

Sant Feliu de Guixols is a historic town which grew from the settlement around a Benedictine monastery built in the  10th century. By the 18th century it had developed into an important trading center thanks to its fishing port, boat-building expertise and cork production. 

Today Sant Feliu is a captivating town that functions all year round, and has preserved its authenticity - there are no fast-food chains or brand-name boutiques. Small shops and local commerce thrive. The daily market bursts with locally-grown and organic produce.

What the funds will be used for

The project is well underway and we are now seeking additional funds to complete the site for  SantElm66. 

The construction is a model of environmental reflection and will have a low carbon footprint. The design takes into account the climate, the natural site, orientation to light and shade and is respectful of local traditions. The building will be self-sufficient.  

The implementation of SantElm66 in northern Spain allows us to support a community of local builders, artisans and suppliers. All materials are locally sourced and the craftsmen are from the immediate vicinity. 

The funds will be used to

  • purchase and install solar panels and central control to produce and regulate electrical production for heating and running the building
  • complete the construction in accordance with a high level of sustainability 
  • finalize the site and prepare it to receive participants.  

Be one of the first to participate in these activities by becoming a backer of SantElm66!

Once the site is completed we can launch the first workshops and activities. Goal: summer 2020.

Project and Advisory Team

Project team
       Charles Poisay and Urko Zapirain Sarasola, architects 
       Yoel Peláez, worksite manager 
       Interdico Home Builder, contractor 

Advisory team
       Eric Amblard, film-maker and photographer 
       Boomoon, photographer 
       Chris Brody, knowledge platform designer and consultant 
       Regina Giménez and Rafel G. Bianchi, artists 
       Airyung Kim, art consultant 
       Carmen Lucini, museographer, heritage curator 
       Michel Péna, landscape designer 
       Margit Rowell, historian and art consultant 
       Pierre Ruffin, spirulina producer and consultant 
       SMAO/Sancho-Madridejos, architects 
       Patricia Smith Melton, author and photographer 
       Urko Zapirain Sarasola, architect

Risks & Challenges

As architect and designer, both seasoned freelancers, we are aware of the challenges set by a venture that needs a high level of organization and relies on multiple collaborators. We have many years of combined experience in directing and managing complicated projects, both public and private. 

Charles has a long and impressive record of delivering architectural projects to a high standard, within budget and on time. He also has many years of experience as professor of architecture and director of workshops. Louise has designed and directed numerous publications involving diverse contributors and managed a home gallery for a number of years.

We have carefully selected our team of collaborators and suppliers for SantElm66, and are confident in their capacity to finish the construction. We will be supervising progress at every stage. With the launch projected for summer 2020, we have given ourselves a sufficient margin to deal with unexpected surprises. 

Most importantly, we are committed to making SantElm66 happen - we can do this with your participation. Join us for a rewarding and inspiring experience!

 

Everyone Can Help

Check out our pledge rewards and choose from specially designed items made from recycled materials, design prints, and activities. Participate in the SantElm66 community by passing the word around and sharing on social media!

story:
Currently a state of emergency has been called for the Northern Atolls of the Republic of Marshall Islands, in response to a long drought bringing about a critical shortage of water. This is a direct impact of climate change in the Pacific that is happening now. There are 15 northern islands experiencing real threats of increased droughts, fresh water shortages, sanitation problems, food security, and increased salinity of  fresh water lenses. It is a clear and present danger.

Women United Together in the Marshall Islands is organizing a cash donation drive to purchase gallons of water, canned goods, and powdered milk.  Shark Defenders will send funds from this online drive to WUTMI so that they can purchase the goods.

Here is their website: http://www.wutmirmi.org/

The Marshall Islands are home to one of the world's largest shark sanctuaries.  Our friends there are suffering and they need our help.  Please consider making a donation.

More information on the drought can be found here:

http://www.ifrc.org/docs/Appeals/13/IBMIdrght240513.pdf
