story:
Our Story & Inspiration

George Langworthy and Rob McFarland of HoneyLove.org are joining forces to save a Million Bees in the spring of 2013. And we're putting forward this fundraising campaign as a vital first step to our efforts.

We've both been out saving bees that would otherwise face extermination and relocating the hives at Bee Sanctuaries. But the time involved and cost of equipment has been holding us back from going out and rescuing as many hives as are out there in need of our help.

Rescuing a Million Honeybees

Our plan is to rescue 50 bee colonies in Southern California. With 20,000 bees per hive – this makes for a million bees! It’s a big job and your support is crucial. By helping with donations to this fundraising drive you are literally saving the lives of honeybees – and you can choose from a host of sweet rewards. Of course the biggest reward is knowing you have done something that will truly help bees and our environment.

The use of the funds raised is very simple. The money goes to purchase equipment, pay for gas, and afford the significant time it takes to rescue bee colonies and relocate them. Our funding drive allocates $350 for every hive that we save.

Many companies charge upwards of $500 to remove bees without killing the colony. And since homeowners and other friends of the bees often can’t afford this – we'll be coming in to help and save the bees. Our beekeeping practices are strictly organic, holistic, and in keeping with the natural order of the hive. And we’ll be ensuring a healthy life for the rescued colonies by placing them on Organic Farms, at Bee Sanctuaries, and in Organic Gardens. Your support is what makes it possible for us to get out there and save bees.

With our respective track records, you can rest assured that we'll find success in our efforts and can see a fun bee rescue in our campaign video. Visit the HoneyLove.org website to find out more about Rob's non-profit organization. Or go to www.vanishingbees.com to learn about George’s documentary on the health crisis facing bees today and what we can do about it.

Helping Bees Every Day

It's easy to help bees in your every day life with simple actions that promote your own health as well as the health of our environment.

1 – Vote With Your Fork.

Buying organic produce helps nurture the food systems that take care of bees and the environment.

2 – Stop Home Pesticide Use.

Natural pest remedies are safer, more effective, and less expensive than toxic chemicals. Get rid of the pesticides in your cabinets, garages, and lawns.

3 – Plant A Garden.

Grow yummy food, delicious herbs, and beautiful flowers. It improves your health and helps the bees. Even people in apartments can grow food in planters or raise a window garden!

4 – Raise Awareness.

The first step to activate change is education. Let people know about the bee crisis and what they can do to help.

story:
Why buy local?

As a Forester for 15 years, I've seen the damage that poor Forestry practices and a lack of concern can have on the environment.  Much like mass produced food, larger scale timber companies have a grip on the market for raw products used for furniture, flooring and other wood products.  I've strived to practice Forestry in a way that provides the goods we need, while balancing our need for healthy, vibrant forests.  My goal is to extend my expertise to connect consumers with other people in the tree business who share the same passion for the environment.

If you wanted to buy a piece of furniture made by a local craftsman using sustainably harvested wood, where would you look?  Chances are, you wouldn't know where to start.  

I've met many wood artisans who have a great product and story to tell, but can't be heard over the large producers of inferior products.  

The Local Wood Hub will be a source for consumers to find high quality, environmentally conscious wood products that are made throughout the Southeastern United States.

What We Need & What You Get

The main tool of the Local Wood Hub will be a website directory of wood artisans, sorted by location, as well as products made.  Funding will go towards website development, promoting the website, as well as searching out these local folks with a product to share.  

Determining what is sustainable use of forests, and what is not, is a difficult proposition.  Not everything is black and white.  Considerable time will be spent by me developing a framework that will ensure we are not "green washing" consumers, but offering real alternatives to mass produced, environmentally damaging wood products.


The Impact

Buying local wood is beneficial in much the same way as buying local food.  You are buying a product you can feel good about.  You are buying a product that is good for the local economy.  You are buying a product built with quality and pride.  When locally produced goods become valuable to consumers, the forests they come from become more valuable as a well managed forest, not a place that is better off clearcut.


Risks & Challenges

The plan is a simple one, but one that requires lots of legwork.  I'm passionate about preserving our forests in the South and feel strongly that the project will succeed.  Momentum is the key.  If we can get the project off the ground and get noticed, I believe there is a large number of people who will use our service.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you know someone making wood products with an environmental conscience, let us know about them!  Word of mouth is a strong tool!

story:
YES! We did it! You can still donate, though!

The story
Adventurous Travellers Risking their Life for Charity! 

Hi! 
We are Pursuers of the Wild, Mathias and Jeppe from Denmark. 
In August 2015 we will be amongst 80 teams from all over the world participating the Rickshaw Run! It will be a 3.500 km journey across India in a tuktuk with no set route, no back-up, and no other information than where to start and where to cross the finish line 16 days later.


It sounds rather stupid, we know - but! There is actually much more to it than just complete stupidity. We have signed up for this Run to give back to the wonderful World! By attending the Run, we're obliged to fund at least 1000 GBP for charity. 

We Need Your Help!

Considering the quite ill-considered travelling method we have no time for such charity funding when we are on the Run. We have already spent thousands of hours and money on this project - and we love it! - but we can no longer do it by ourselves. That's why we've started this campaign. 

We need you! We need your goodwill and your shares to make this happen!

The Charity - What Would You Be Supporting?

Every single coin will go directly to CoolEarth! CoolEarth is an organisation that fights to save the rainforest. We know that there are a lot of organisations out there saving the rainforests, and thank God for that, because something really has to be done to preserve them. It is about finding the projects you believe in - we believe in CoolEarth!

CoolEarth does a quite nice job to save the rainforests in a civilised and thoughtful way:

CoolEarth doesn't just buy land, build fences, or create tourist minded reserves. Instead, they put the local people back in control! Those people who have most to lose - and those who know very best how to live and care for the endangered rainforest. 

CoolEarth provides the villages with ressources and money, and the local people then decide by themselves what to do with it. 

At least 90% of the money goes directly to the villages, the rest will be supporting the organisation's administration, paper work, and so forth.

Take a look at this video.


What We Need & What You Get

We have been working on this project in 8 months by now. We have put thousands of pounds into traveling expenses, branding, and covering lost working hours - and we've had a blast!
One major experience we've gained from this project is that people are kindhearted. They want to help - they are willing to make a difference with us! - and we would be over the moon if you would too!


We need to collect at least 1000 GBP. We hope you are already considering to contribute by now. If so, go check out our perks in the right hand side - pick one of our perks and you'll be getting nice gifts in return!  

You also got the chance of getting invited to our events where bands and dj's will put up a show that we won't forget in this lifetime! 

Pursuers of the Wild - The Team

Our team, Pursuers of the Wild, are obviously pursuing wild adventures! We went to Rosborg Gymnasium in Vejle together and graduated in 2014. Wanna know more? 


World's Best Team of Helpers

We are the utmost luckiest people in the world. Do you know why? Because we have a whole team of friends and family who help us in all sorts of ways! 

James
James is our guy! A natural helper with loads of time for you if you need him. He also happens to be quite an encyclopaedia of Cool Earth information which we definitely don't mind considering our choice of charity. Got questions about CoolEarth, then don't hesitate asking him. You might as well say hi to him in our  youtube interview with him. 

Kristian 
This crazy fellow shares our travel enthusiasm. Actually he exceeds it! Kristian is a very friendly guy, but keep in mind: Start conversing with him and your conversation will not end in the next few months because of Kristian's numerous awesome experiences and his great humour! 

Sophie
Feeling a bit down? Meet Sophie. You may have heard of numerous tips on how to get your groove on and get in the funk but nothing does it better than an hour in the company of Sophie. Besides that she is always game for some exploring and going on adventures.

Philip 
Here you go. Philip is our old classmate from Rosborg Gymnasium. A man with qualities - an energetic and enterprising buddy! He always wants you the best and is willing to give everything in order to help you reach your goals. What else do you need from a friend? 

Andreas

Oops. Did you really think things just peaked? Absolutely not, here's another top lad. Andreas is one of our old classmates, too. With Andreas around you, you can be perfectly sure that the good old karma is sky high. His positive attitude and a Helper's heart of gold are amongst Andreas' unique assets! 

Jonas 
Apart from being Jeppe's fellow fan of world's best football team Liverpool FC Jonas shares the other guys'  enthusiasm to a level above perfection. There will never be any doubt about the commitment from Jonas, and if not you already got it: WE LOVE COMMITMENT AND ENTHUSIASM. 

Nikki
Here is a great guy. Nikki is one of Mathias' old classmates from secondary school and he and Mathias goes way back. When Nikki participates in something he does it fully engaged and with his heart at the right place. Nikki knows his way around things so if Nikki is nearby nothing can ever go fully wrong.

Ways You Can Help

The very best way to help is to contribute. Nonetheless, there are multiple other ways to help us - and we deeply appreciate every piece of help that we get!

You can either

contribute,
share our campaign on social media,
spread the word,
like our facebookpage,
watch our youtube videos,
or participate in our events!

And please remember to you use the Indiegogo sharing tools at the top left. 

THANK YOU for reading and engaging  in our campaign! 

We are forever grateful!

/Mathias & Jeppe
facebook.com/pursuersofthewild

There is actually much more to it than just complete stupidity. We have signed up for this Run to give back to the wonderful World! By attending the Run, we're obliged to fund at least 1000 GBP for charity. We Need Your Help!


Considering the quite ill-considered travelling method we have no time for such charity funding when we are on the Run. We have already spent thousands of hours and money on this project - and we love it! - but we can no longer do it by ourselves. That's why we've started this campaign. 


We need you! We need your goodwill and your shares to make this happen!The Charity - What Would You Be Supporting?



Every single coin will go directly to CoolEarth! CoolEarth is an organisation that fights to save the rainforest. We know that there are a lot of organisations out there saving the rainforests, and thank God for that, because something really has to be done to preserve them. It is about finding the projects you believe in - we believe in CoolEarth!

CoolEarth does a quite nice job to save the rainforests in a civilised and thoughtful way:
CoolEarth doesn't just buy land, build fences, or create tourist minded reserves. Instead, they put the local people back in control! Those people who have most to lose - and those who know very best how to live and care for the endangered rainforest. 
CoolEarth provides the villages with ressources and money, and the local people then decide by themselves what to do with it. 
At least 90% of the money goes directly to the villages, the rest will be supporting the organisation's administration, paper work, and so forth.
Take a look at this video.


What We Need & What You GetWe have been working on this project in 8 months by now. We have put thousands of pounds into traveling expenses, branding, and covering lost working hours - and we've had a blast!One major experience we've gained from this project is that people are kindhearted. They want to help - they are willing to make a difference with us! - and we would be over the moon if you would too!We need to collect at least 1000 GBP. We hope you are already considering to contribute by now. If so, go check out our perks in the right hand side - pick one of our perks and you'll be getting nice gifts in return!  You also got the chance of getting invited to our events where bands and dj's will put up a show that we won't forget in this lifetime! Pursuers of the Wild - The TeamOur team, Pursuers of the Wild, are obviously pursuing wild adventures! We went to Rosborg Gymnasium in Vejle together and graduated in 2014. Wanna know more? 


World's Best Team of HelpersWe are the utmost luckiest people in the world. Do you know why? Because we have a whole team of friends and family who help us in all sorts of ways! JamesJames is our guy! A natural helper with loads of time for you if you need him. He also happens to be quite an encyclopaedia of Cool Earth information which we definitely don't mind considering our choice of charity. Got questions about CoolEarth, then don't hesitate asking him. You might as well say hi to him in our  youtube interview with him. Kristian This crazy fellow shares our travel enthusiasm. Actually he exceeds it! Kristian is a very friendly guy, but keep in mind: Start conversing with him and your conversation will not end in the next few months because of Kristian's numerous awesome experiences and his great humour! SophieFeeling a bit down? Meet Sophie. You may have heard of numerous tips on how to get your groove on and get in the funk but nothing does it better than an hour in the company of Sophie. Besides that she is always game for some exploring and going on adventures.Philip Here you go. Philip is our old classmate from Rosborg Gymnasium. A man with qualities - an energetic and enterprising buddy! He always wants you the best and is willing to give everything in order to help you reach your goals. What else do you need from a friend? Andreas
Oops. Did you really think things just peaked? Absolutely not, here's another top lad. Andreas is one of our old classmates, too. With Andreas around you, you can be perfectly sure that the good old karma is sky high. His positive attitude and a Helper's heart of gold are amongst Andreas' unique assets! Jonas Apart from being Jeppe's fellow fan of world's best football team Liverpool FC Jonas shares the other guys'  enthusiasm to a level above perfection. There will never be any doubt about the commitment from Jonas, and if not you already got it: WE LOVE COMMITMENT AND ENTHUSIASM. NikkiHere is a great guy. Nikki is one of Mathias' old classmates from secondary school and he and Mathias goes way back. When Nikki participates in something he does it fully engaged and with his heart at the right place. Nikki knows his way around things so if Nikki is nearby nothing can ever go fully wrong.




Ways You Can Help
The very best way to help is to contribute. Nonetheless, there are multiple other ways to help us - and we deeply appreciate every piece of help that we get!


You can either
contribute,share our campaign on social media,spread the word,like our facebookpage,watch our youtube videos,or participate in our events!
And please remember to you use the Indiegogo sharing tools at the top left. THANK YOU for reading and engaging  in our campaign! 



We are forever grateful!/Mathias & Jeppefacebook.com/pursuersofthewild

story:
A Tiny Introduction




We are (and always have been) a family in movement. 

Whether by our own choice, gypsying about to new vistas, or by the will of the planet itself, we see the world through this movement.  We lived in Manitou Springs during the Waldo Canyon Fire, were in the process of moving to Middlebury, Vermont during the floods of Hurricane Irene, and had just finalized deals to move into a cabin in Pinewood Springs, Colorado this last fall (the night before the floods that cut the town off from the outside world).

Needless to say, we're ready for a little stability in our lives, but our relationship with Mother Nature is one of constant flux and change.  We love her, but we live on her and respect her wishes when she says MOVE.  So after a year of deliberation, we decided a mobile home of sorts was the choice that resonated with us the most.

We weighed options ranging from yurts to airstream trailers, but the burgeoning trend of tiny houses caught our attention after seeing a Tiny House documentary at the Crested Butte Film Festival.  Tiny homes reflected all the rustic appeal of a cabin with the mobile flexibility of a trailer.  It would allow us to build something that had significant cultural and ecological impact, while still allowing us freedom to be creative and expressive in the building process.

While we were initially at a loss as to how we could save nearly $20,000 to build this tiny home, a growing awareness of the success of many internet fundraising campaigns gave us an idea.  We could use the internet and local outreach to bring to light the beauty of the tiny home, while simultaneously raising money by offering incentives that reflect what responsible living means to us. This Indiegogo campaign, is the product of our efforts.

Small House, Big Impact




In a world of shrinking resources, our ingenuity doesn’t have to shrink as well.  The tiny house reflects an effort to focus more on responsible living and reciprocity with the land. 

In the building process of the home, we plan on sourcing as much of the material in the form of scrap as possible.  Much of the interior fixtures, plumbing, cabinetry, wood paneling, and flooring is going to be repurposed from the wide world of waste that surrounds the Denver Metro area.  Further, we plan on using pine beetle kill wood for the paneling and siding to further lessen the environmental impact of building a WOOD HOME.

The lack of a sewage line encourages the reclamation of more traditional means of dealing with waste.  Much of our waste water (grey water) will be put to use in our garden.  And instead of allowing solid waste to fester, promoting bacteria in clean drinking water, our composting toilet will neutralize the acidity and create fertilizer especially conducive to the growth of many of Colorado's native plant species.

Certainly, a space as small as the tiny house will negate many possibilities of over consumption in the first place.  While we already live quite frugal lives, we recognize that consumer culture is directly reflected in dimensions of the space we live in.  We think that by limiting space, not only will we limit our consumption, but we will be forced to focus more on the exterior of our home. Through biodynamic gardening, composting, and an inevitable reduction in fossil fuel consumption, we see the tiny house as the next step towards living in a more symbiotic relationship with the land.

 

The Fun(d) in Fundraiser

To build this home as we intend, we require materials.  Much of the philosophy behind this house is in regard to consumption, sustainability, and thriftiness.  While we can idealize that we could build an entire home from found and free scrap, we know that we are going to have to at some point dole out some cash-money to get material.  

For example: to buy a new load bearing trailer for the home we are building, most estimates range from a $3,500 to $4,000 investment.  Certainly, this is the foundation of the structure itself (especially during transportation), but still a bit on the pricey side.  And while a cheap (or free!) trailer would be wonderful, in all likelihood, it would not be up to the weight potential of a home, so more money and time go to parts and labor to make it load bearing.   

Thus, in most of our estimates for cost, we took the middle route between buying used for cheap and new for cost. We think this is the safest and most logical way to lay out our expenses beforehand. 

And labor?  Well that's all us.  We are dedicated to building this from the ground up, minute by minute, hour by hour.  This is the ultimate labor of love, building a little baby abode we can call our own.

A rough bunch of numbers:

  • Trailer - $3,000
  • Structural Wood, and Siding - $3,000
  • Interior Wood and Cabinetry - $3,000
  • Doors, Windows, Flashing - $1,700
  • Roofing - $1,200
  • Stove/Heating - $1,400
  • Tools - $1,300
  • Plumbing, Electrical -  $1,000
  • Etc - $400
  • TOTAL - $16,000




Inventive Incentives

While we hope many people donate simply to help our cause, we recognize that incentivized donations are the best way to attract attention. But what could we have to offer those who donated that would be synonymous with many of our ideals? 

Education was the foremost idea.  To share healthy and pertinent knowledge is something we have a passion for, and while we share this knowledge freely with those around us, we thought offering a few intensive classes on what we know best would be a great way to share.  So whether you are interested in cooking, fermentation, herbal medicine, or learning more about the flora and fauna of the Colorado Front Range, we have years of knowledge and experience to share.

Other incentives include: handmade Tiny House t-shirts, sleepy-time herbal medicine packages (everyone could use a little sleep medicine), invitations to the unveiling party of the house when it’s completed (both kombucha and local beer kegs will be on hand), unique and slightly eccentric art pieces, video updates of the construction site, and even a bed ‘n’ breakfast style stay in the tiny house when it’s completed. 

If you can’t find something that piques your interest in the incentives to the right, there are also options to donate simply because you support us building our Tiny Home.







The Sum of All Parts

This project is a marriage of opposites.  New growth through old ideas, creative process through meditative reflection, tenacious outreach through resignation and patience.  We believe in our idea, and know that whatever the outcome of the fundraiser, we are more motivated than ever to continue on our trajectory towards a more sustainable way of living. 

We love your support, and we love that you are supporting the idea of change simply by being open to reading. 

Any donation helps.  5 dollars helps build our wall, 20 dollars helps warms our home, 100 dollars helps us drink clean water, and 1000 dollars helps make us mobile.  And if you can’t donate but love the idea… Spread the word, share our link, or come over and grab a hammer and nail.

We welcome any and all support, and thank you for your time.

Much love and appreciation,

Nickolas, Nichole, and Finnrys


Note: All incentives are delivered on a variable timeline.  Translation?  Ask us when you can expect the incentive you asked for.  Classes will be in July 2014, shipped packages can be expected June 2014.  They are all handmade, so patience is wonderful!



UPDATES:

At over $500, we are so thankful to those who have donated so far!  Nichole, Finn and Nickolas were able to spend the last few days in a TINY HOUSE at Horsetooth Resevoir (outside of Fort Collins)!  Great local food and a good time all around!  Watch the video tour of their tiny place they stayed in to get an idea of what the scale of their project is like!  Keep donating and telling your friends!

story:
Summary: A Hand Up, Not A Hand Out

I am William's dad and, like him, was a seasonal firefighter. Unfortunately, these young men are laid off every year and struggle to make ends meet in the off season. William had the motor to his truck blow up on the way home from Tahoe. He had worked hard all winter at the ski lifts, but the low pay and high rents meant he had few funds left over; certainly not enough to pay for the motor that blew up in his truck.

We are asking all of his friends just to LOAN him-- not give him-- a little bit, whatever they can LEND, to help Will get back on the road and to work this summer. In other words, we are seeking "micro loans" from friends, family and acquaintances, all of which will be paid back in full, with blood, sweat and hard work in the woods.

By loaning this money, you are supporting hard work and supporting the ideal of earning what you need. But unlike a Visa or Mastercard loan, this is a personal loan, a form of community giving to the individual, with the money being localized instead of going through big banks.

Micro loans or microfinance are general terms used to describe such financial services to low-income individuals or to those who do not have access to typical banking services. http://www.kiva.org/about/microfinance#I-I


What We Need & What You Get

Breaking it down: a rebuilt crate motor will cost about $2,000. The labour to install the engine will be between $500 and $800. The processing fee from Indigogo will be about $300. So, we are hoping to raise $3,100 to cover all the costs. AGAIN, THESE ARE LOANS, NOT GIFTS-- he will pay back EVERY person who helps him, starting with the top lenders, and working his way down the list.

Lenders will be paid back (after all, you are loaning him not giving him money), as Will works during the summer season and receives his paychecks from fires. Also, he will send his personal thanks for supporting him this fire season.

The Impact

William worked hard in fire academy to become a wildland firefighter and to learn the skills needed to protect the environment. Now in his third season, he and his crew continue to work hard defending our woodland areas and watersheds. By helping him-- by loaning him this money-- you are giving him and "hand up" instead of a "hand out", and you are helping support fire suppression, preserving watershed, saving houses in forested areas, and protecting valuable habitat.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t loan money, that doesn’t mean you can’t help: get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

We know there may not be a lot of money in your pocket right now. So, we ask that you consider loaning just $10 to help William-- because truly, if every one of our friends and family loaned him just $10, he would have all he needs!

But if you simply cannot lend anything right now, there are other ways you can be part of the "Help William Fight Fires" team, and we will appreciate it so much!

Share with everyone you can think of--and share often.  If you use the sharing tools at the top of the page, once a day, letting everyone know how much you support William, that will really help!  Indiegogo uses it's "GoGo Factor" to determine who gets to be on the home page, and at the top of the searches for different categories. 

Or, if you don't have money, but you know someone who has a used 1996 GMC truck motor, one that they don't need anymore and could donate, or you have the skills to install a motor and could help, that would be great! Even better, if you or someone you know owns an old, reliable truck, one that you're not using right now and could lend him to use, that would be amazing!

**NOTE: If you would prefer to help William DIRECTLY by not using Visa, you can mail a check to: William Zekas, P.O. Box 92, Veneta, OR 97487

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Brad Spanbauer and I am a graduate student at the University of Wisconsin - Oshkosh. I am studying tropical ecology and am working towards my M.S. in Biology. I am deeply passionate about conservation and sustainability. My thesis research is focused on savannah elephants as dispersers of key tree species in East Africa and their role in naturally contributing to tree recruitment. This area of research, particularly for this area of the tropics has not been studied extensively, and is extremely important in the global realm of ecosystem services provided by animals to help maintain the environment. 

What I Need & What You Get

The funds contributed to this project will go towards travel to and from where I stay in Tanzania to my field site, Tarangire National Park, a four hour drive. A day trip to the park on average costs $300 USD, and I will need to go several times to check my experiments in the field. This is one of the most expensive parts of my trip. If you contribute $20 or more you will receive a fantastic photograph from one of my previous trips to Tanzania for free! (Photographs will be viewable in an album labeled 'Contributor Photos') Let's see if we can exceed my goal!

The Impact

This project is very important to me. I had always dreamed of going to Africa and now it is becoming a part of my career. What this project means for the planet is a better understanding of how animals interact with plants in their immediate environment and how their coexistence contrinbutes to a healthier planet for everyone. If the elephants are around to consume seeds, and replant them naturally, this gives a better conservation status for the elephants and the trees - swinging the natural order of the Earth back in balance.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot help with a donation, one of the best things you can do is tell people. Share the link to my campaign and help spread the word to your friends. Thank you in advance.

story:
Summary

This fundraising campaign is to help raise money for year three of my long distance solo ride on horseback. This year's ride will take me from SW Alberta along the eastern edge of the Rocky Mountains north towards the Yukon Territory. Money raised will go towards new equipment (camping and horse related) and supplies (mostly food) while on the journey which will last 5 months. My rides become the inspiration for my art work and also make clear that there is great importance in teling the story of my travels, of the people and of the possibilities of finding another way to exist on the earth.

Equipment to be purchased include: hoof boots, tent replacement, rainwear, cooking stuff, picket ropes, maps, cel phone coverage, emergency (spot) rescue device coverage & some other items.

The amount that I am trying to raise is what I believe to be the minimum needed to get the ride going. Funds raised beyond my goal will be put towards a weatherproof video/still camera to help with better documentation and some equipment that though not essential would make life on the trail a little easier. Any donations beyond that will go towards suporting creating writing, music and other art work inspired by the ride that I will start in the autumn of 2013.

The Impact

The spring of 2013 will find me travelling from south-west Alberta following the eastern edges of the Rocky Mountains north through Alberta, into BC following foothills, grasslands and mountains north towards the Yukon Territory.  I will be starting a little earlier this year and I expect this ride to last five months. May through September. 

During the summers of 2011 and 2012, after much preparation over a number of years, I embarked on a solo long distance ride on horseback through southern Saskatchewan and Alberta on the plains of western Canada. Though my total distance was over 1700 km, the journey was about so much more than clocked distance. My goals were to find, bear witness and document remote and rare open native grass rangeland, to live as close to and simply with the land as I could; to experience this land and experience the kind of relationship with two beautiful horses that the slow mode of travel on horseback allows. These were an incredible, life changing journeys, taking me through weeks of stunning open native grass rangeland (the old growth forest of the prairies!) to seemingly endless, massive, heavily sprayed, mono crop fields. I lived through some wild weather. Massive tent flattening thunderstorms and plough winds, extreme heat, frosts early on in the ride and then again already in mid-August. I also witnessed the slow march of towering cloud formations, the calm stillness so common in the early evening, (such a welcome break from relentless prairie winds) or after a great thunderous storm had passed by, and dark sky preserves where there was no light pollution to mar the millions of stars twinkling above at me (us!) night.

I travelled, lived lightly, gathered much of my food from the land, greens mostly. Prior to the beginning of my journeys, I dry strips of meat in the sun. Some of that jerky i keep as is and some I mix with rendered fat and dried berries to make into nutrient packed pemmican. I also purchase food along the way in the occasional small town that I come across.

My relationship with my horses throughout the two summers, continued to build with each day and suddenly it became clear that we were a true team, a true herd of three. There was so much that came to that I was hoping would happen and of course much that was so very different than expected. The ride became settled in the moment, the necessary. Time changed. I can't say that it stood still exactly. Perhaps I could say that I became deeply aware of the way that time could be a flexible entity, shifting, changing, altering. Perceptions of vastness and the very intimate merge and pull apart. 

I met many people living in this sparsely populated region. Generosity of spirit and openness was the norm and oftentimes I didn't even need to say why I was on this ride. They knew, they understood.

My name is Catherine Thompson. I am in my mid 50s, a Canadian writer, composer, musician, instrument maker, songwriter and artist. My work and life seeks to find a path back to our wild, natural selves; to find a way to leave behind the destructiveness of modern industrial civilisation; to increase awareness of our place on the land and the dire situation that we find ourselves in. Ecologically, socially, spiritually. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course, financial donations are most welcome and needed but if you are not able to contribute in that way, it would be wonderful if you could pass this on to others through email, facebook, twitter etc.

Indegogo has share tools to make things easy on that front.

Perks

Unfortunately, I cannot offer much in the way of perks for this fundraising effort as there is not much produced at this stage other than experience and inspiration. However for donations of $50 or more I will mail a specially printed thank you card with my main Indiegogo image of me and my horses Dakota and Coco. I will gratefully acknowledge all contributions on my website unless otherwise requested and I shall be forever be grateful.  

Thanks for having a look at what I'm up to and I hope this finds you well and happy.

Cath

story: Agafya Lykov, alone in the Siberian Taiga has written a letter requesting helpers. This hand written letter was made known to us. Having had ongoing interest in Agafya and her life we wrote a letter back to her, telling her of our desire to help and offering to come if we can raise the needed travel funds. She eagerly welcomes us, awaiting our arrival! Now the seasons of Spring, Summer,and Fall have passed and we still hope to make it to her! Please won't you help us travel to Agafya? The helicopter expense is near 5,000. Later, in Winter, the Forest Reserve can transport us by hovercraft and this will cost less than helicopter, close to 4,000 both ways. We will be adding further details as we have them! We are very hopeful to make it to her this Winter! Thanks to all! Luchian and Emilia Marcov

story:
The Great American Adaptation Road Trip

As Americans, we pride ourselves on our resourcefulness and creativity in response to daunting societal problems. Climate change is one of our generation's most urgent challenges. Its effects are already being felt, from rising tides and more intense storms along our coasts to scorching droughts and water scarcity in our fields to melting glaciers on our tallest mountains. An unstable climate has and will create many problems, but it also creates opportunities—opportunities to develop new energy technologies, to produce less waste, to create new business models, to forge new partnerships, and to come together in our communities.

 

We are aiming to share stories about the way Americans are using technology to adapt to the felt impacts of climate change. We define technology as the tools and mechanisms through which people minimize the harmful consequences and exploit the opportunities posed by changes in climate. Technology can be a physical tool that functions on its own, such as permeable pavement or drought-resistance crops or coastal protection structures. But it can also be more of a social process, like training community members as environmental leaders or rethinking land use.

We plan to spend three months traveling the country to uncover stories about people and places adapting to climate change. We'll visit towns, small cities, rural areas, and national parks and meet with all sorts of people--city planners, natural resources managers, business owners, farmers, fisherman, foresters, insurance agents, and community leaders. Our storytelling will be multimedia, including short pieces of writing, photographs, video, and audio. By the end of the trip, we hope to have answered the question, What does climate adaptation look like? We imagine that it will look as diverse as the country we live in.

The Impact 

Many towns and cities across the United States are already planning for a new climate reality, and some are sharing their efforts in the form of city plans or in the news. However, much of the innovation that's going on is not documented or not accessible. Our road trip aims to use stories to bridge the gap between existing research on climate change adaptation planning, and the often-overlooked, practical adaptive technologies already being used by people all over the country. Closing this gap has implications for technology transfers that could increase both national and international adaptive capacity in concert with global efforts to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions.

Funding

We estimate that we will need about $12,000 to complete our three-month road trip, including gas, equipment, food, and lodging (we plan to camp or stay with friends for much of the trip). We have already raised about $8,000 through grants and support from the School of Natural Resources and Environment at the University of Michigan, where we just completed our master's degrees. We need about $4,000 more to make it all the way around the country collecting stories.

Support our trip and we'll send you a postcard (or 10!) from the road, a photograph of your choice—landscape or portrait—from our journey, or a GAART (Great American Adaptation Road Trip) T-shirt.

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow our blog: www.adaptationstories.com

Follow us on Twitter: kirstenandallie

If you have ideas of interesting places we should go or people we should meet with, email us at adpatationstories at gmail dot com.

story:
About the issue...

In December, the Alliance for Global Justice, an international solidarity organization, will be hosted by the Forum Solidaridad Peru (Peru Solidarity Forum) on a delegation where activists from around the world discuss real solutions to the ecological crisis.  At the last UN climate change summit in New York, governments made very slow head-way on this process of implementing a sustainable development agenda.  One example was the New York Declaration on Forests, which is hardly a courageous step toward progress.  The next summit will be held in Lima, Peru, and we won't be quiet there, either.  
Aside from the rallies surrounding the UN gathering, we will be traveling north to the city of Cajamarca, and the villages surrounding it, to bear witness to the destructive impact of what is currently the world's most productive gold mine.  Many with claims to the land in the area have faced repression as a result of the mining company's rapacious appetite for more land, more water, and more stolen profits, barely investing a margin into local development.  The Conga Mine (Minas Conga) is a massive project owned mostly by Newmont, a corporation based in Denver, CO, and Buenaventura, based in Peru, and is partially financed by the International Monetary Fund.  

About the activists...

My name is Dominique Diaddigo-Cash.  I have worked for several years as a grassroots environmental activist and an organizer in political movements.  I currently live in Washington, D.C., and work as a teacher at an elementary school.  I'm very committed to taking grassroots action on climate change and displacement on a global and local scale.

Graham Boyle is an arts organizer from Washington, D.C. He is the former editor of Threshold, an environmental justice publication. He also belonged to the coordinating committee for the inaugural Mountain Justice Spring Break and has worked on campaigns concerning resource extraction in Appalachia for 6+ years.  He currently works as a hands-on arts educator and activist in Washington, D.C., working on issues from Migrant Rights, Prison Abolition, Climate Justice, as well as local Affordable Housing and Public Property campaigns.

We will be going to Perú to participate in ten days of action against the corporate dominion over nature.  While gaining more developed insight into the root causes of climate change, we will publish a report based on the faces and voices present at one of the epicenters of the conflict that concerns everyone.  We will bring back the stories, skills, and momentum of the delegation to share with our community and strengthen the ties between continents.

We need to continue to pressure our leaders to sign on to agreements that will help to alleviate the challenges presented by climate change, but it is important too that their agenda does not include the displacement of communities or enable further destruction to take place.  This is why we need your help!  We want to join the communities in Peru to help develop a broader perspective of the global ecological struggle, but we can't get their without your support.

About the project...

Similar to other DIY publications, or "zines", the end result of our travel will be a resource for activists to learn about the strength of our movement, and to share the stories of some of those in the global South who have been resisting displacement for generations.

Made from interviews with organizers of the delegation, the rallies, and coordinators in the local movements, the publication will serve as a political and educational tool for communities in active international solidarity. We strive to connect with others working toward a sustainable future to learn from them and enrich the diversity of tactics available to those of us who want to realize that future.  

And of course all donors to our crowd-sourcing efforts will receive their own copies of the finished product at the end of the year!

What We Need & Why We Need It

The cost of the delegation includes all of our travel fees, lodging, and food.  The money will go to the Alliance for Global Justice, the grassroots organization that has worked since 1998 to build solidarity between disparate movements and take a stand against unjust policies and practice that originate in the United States.  
The Alliance for Global Justice (AfGJ), has built a tremendous body of work in solidarity, especially in regard to communities acting in defense of the land.  Check out their support for the Yaqui activist Mario Luna here to learn more about the issues.  

The Impact

By helping to fund our project, you're contributing to a cooperation among thousands of individuals from all over the world.  You're supporting the grass roots initiatives, not the major corporations and their insufficient top-down strategies.  

This is also a chance to help strengthen the For Earth, Against Empire campaign started by members of the Alliance for Global Justice.  This campaign is crucial because it makes demands on the most powerful world leaders (governments and corporations) to end the spread of militarism across the globe.  We believe that the crisis of the Earth living out of balance cannot be solved without first resolving the imbalance of power that presently exists around the world.  

    Get Involved!

    Even if you can't contribute, you can still be an important part of the For Earth Against Empire campaign.  Visit the Alliance for Global Justice web page.  Follow the various social movements here and abroad who are fighting for justice!

story:
Trees for Zambia Explained

Based in South Africa, Greenpop is a social enterprise dedicated to urban greening, reforestation, and spreading eco-consciousness in Southern Africa. Our aim is to inspire a fun an accessible green movement; the Treevolution. In July this year, we are kick-starting a reforestation and eco-education project in Zambia, the country with the second-highest deforestation in the world. In the initial 3-week campaign, we will plant 5000 (or more!) trees in national parks, forest concessions, at schools, and on subsistence farms in and around Livingstone. Our aims are as follows: 

  • Start a reforestation process and encourage a tree-planting culture
  • Educate children on their natural environment and improve their food security by planting fruit trees at schools
  • Promote conservation farming methods in the local communities that will stop erosion and soil degradation, and create most cost-efficient farms at the same time
  • Start a micro-nursery enterprise with local subsistence farmers, which will provide them with an additional source of income (and they can use the trees as natural fertilizer on their land!) 


Sustainability of the Project 

In order to make this project sustainable, it is essential to have the local community involved in and benefiting from our efforts. The main way of ensuring this is through education. We are working with education experts to develop the most suitable and fun educational material for both school children en subsistence farmers. Through our workshops, the local community will learn how trees can benefit them, whether it's by using them for food security reasons, knowing how to identify trees with the best shade, or using them as natural fertilizers on their land. In addition, we ensure local community members profit from the trees through our micro-nursery enterprise. After our initial three-week project, we will establish a permanent base in Livingstone so that we can continue our greening and educational efforts. 


What We Need & What You Get

We need trees! Every $15 covers for a tree, an all the logistics that are involved in planting that tree. This includes the the following costs: 

  • buying the trees from a local nursery in Livingstone 
  • transporting them to the planting location 
  • facilitation of the planting day with the local community and international volunteers 
  • a monitoring program of the trees, so that we can make sure they grow tall and strong! 


Please note that even if the goal is not reached, all the donated trees will be planted. The Trees for Zambia project is definitely happening - we would just like to plant as many trees as possible! Other sources of income are corporate sponsorship (please contact us if you're interested in this!) and private donations. 


It doesn't matter how much you contribute - every tree counts!! Check out our perks for cool things we offer you in return. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Join our Treevolution by helping us spread the message! Please share this campaign with anyone you think might be interested in helping us green Zambia! 

You can also come and volunteer with us in Zambia! We fully rely on volunteers to make the project a success, so role up your sleeves and help us out! For more information on our volunteer project, go to http://www.greenpop.org/projects/trees-for-zambia/ or send an email to zambia@greenpop.org. 

Thanks for your support!!

story:
Huge thanks for supporting us thus far! Since launching our crowdfund campaign 2 months ago, you have helped us raise over HK$120,000 (over 100%) of our Indiegogo campaign goal, and have received numerous contributions from companies and organizations around Hong Kong.


With only a 1 DAY left, we would love to have you be a part of this campaign and supporter of HK Recycles!!! As always, any amount that you can contribute would really help. Be sure to select a perk and help us spread the word.

We would like to give a big thanks to KEEN for their large contribution and being an official sponsor of our HK Recycles Van. You'll soon be able to see the KEEN logo along with the HK Recycles Van. Find our more about KEEN at: http://www.keenfootwear.com.


HK Recycles is a green social business, founded by Brian Mak and Michael Shum, that provides convenient recycling solutions for homes, offices, and whole buildings, while also providing employment and career development opportunities to disadvantaged people.

Since starting HK Recycles in 2012, we have helped recycle over 70,000kg of trash, while providing recycling services to over 100 buildings. 

Addressing the issue of waste and recycling is a group and community effort. At HK Recycles, we have began discussions with government groups (i.e. EPD, Efficiency Unit, Environment Bureau), and are working with property management and development companies to introduce and scale new recycling programs and processes in Hong Kong.


Although we have provided hundreds of homes, offices, and buildings with simple recycling solutions, we have also been doing this on a very lean budget - renting a man with a van (or men with vans).

But after being very fortunate to find reliable "temporary" vans over the last 1.5 years, we feel that it's time to take HK Recycles to the next step and make our solutions more proper, moving towards being a fixture in Hong Kong's waste system instead of a temporary solution.

Many of you ask for opportunities to donate and help us. Meanwhile, we have finally gotten enough traction to take this to the next level - working with major property companies and government divisions to see how we can help.

The timing is right now. It's time for us to take that next step. Our first step is to acquire our very own HK Recycles dedicated van.


100% of your contribution will go directly towards helping us purchase a new van. If we exceed our goal of HK$120,000, we'll put it directly back into the company to help us build capacity in other ways (i.e. hiring more workers, buying another vehicle, etc.).

Your contribution will have a huge impact on Hong Kong and has the potential to play a critical role in changing the future landscape of Hong Kong's waste situation. By purchasing our own van, we will be able to have more reliable service and explore more opportunities in expanding to other parts of Hong Kong.

The faster and more we expand, the more impact we will have on Hong Kong through recycling and employment of our workers. In addition, your contribution has the potential in changing the future landscape by enabling us to build a greater and better case for our talks with both property management companies and government divisions.

While recycling 70,000kg is great, we want to help Hong Kong recycle more and, with your help, make a significant positive impact on Hong Kong's waste situation.

What's a Stretch Goal? Basically, if we pass our funding goal of HK$120,000 (US$15,000), we will put those extra funds directly back into hiring more workers and providing recycling collection services to more of Hong Kong. Here is our commitment to Hong Kong if we go above and beyond!


We've NEVER reached out to our friends and members like this before and we can't wait to get you all involved through these perks and this campaign as a whole. Your contribution will allow us to increase our capacity and see the impact of HK Recycles not only as a social business, but as a movement!

This is a new step not only for HK Recycles as a company, but the entire community, and we're relying on you to move us forward.

Please help us spread the word to all your friends and family, and especially your neighbours! Please tweet, facebook, weibo, instagram, blog, email! Let's get as many people involved! We can't wait to help Hong Kong become a greener place!

story:
Sustainable Renewable Energy:
The only way that sustainable renewable energy will ever become a reality is if we, each of us, do something positive, if you like what you read about my campaign and you think it has a possibility of success, donate generously, help overcome the difficulties and usher in a new, less exploitative more nurturing age, where the planet is saved for our children and we can FINALLY give something back.

Energy and life style

I think Sir Richard Branson came closer to it than anyone else when he said words to the effect that renewable energy would never replace conventional fossil fuel generated energy, until it was able to offer at least something that was as good as the energy security that the grid offered OR better. Green Initiative offers the same energy security as the grid, it offers the same plug and play environment that the grid does. This means that if you decide it is too hot this summer and you need an air-conditioner, all you have to do is buy it and plug it in. ‘Home Grid’ can handle the load.  ‘Home Grid’ offers the way for an improved life style, it is a step away from exploitation and towards nurturing.

Twenty first Century Technology : Why not use it ?

Solar cells can theoretically run for 9 hours a day continuously,  although the output will vary with the amount of sun available, wind can run for even longer periods continuously, ranging from hours to weeks. It is therefore only a matter of time before a renewable energy source is found that can run 24 x 7, putting out a good density of energy regardless of climate, weather, time of day, or location, finally putting an end to the bane of intermittency.  This is what we at GREEN INITIATIVE have accomplished and we did it by fusing some of the fantastic technology and materials available in the twenty first century with naturally occurring forces of nature.

Eureka Moment !

The eureka moment for Green Initiative came when we realised that some of the first machines to be successfully invented, built and used, such as the Newcomen Atmospheric engine, were so simple and elementary in their design that they could be fitted with modern technology so that they needed no external input !  Yes, everyone says that it is impossible and that a device like that will contravene the second law of the conservation of energy.  Read on and decide for yourselves. How the ‘Home Grid’ system works: We have a thoroughly proven proof of concept model, we need to build a working model.  Look at this link http://www.vacuumelevators.com/ it says a lot about the materials used and the working of our system. The only real difference is that we use the kinetic energy of a descending counterweight to create a vacuum, this vacuum is then shared by two to three systems to operate cyclically and generate useful electrical output. We at GREEN INITIATIVE believe that we have the most practical and workable sustainable renewable energy solution found to date. It produces an amazing 10 KW (or more if needed) output of electricity 24 x7. This works out to 240 KWh a day.  This is the renewable energy solution that everybody has been waiting for, it is not intermittent in fact it offers the same kind of energy security that the grid does.  The working of the system is very similar to the working of the Newcomen Atmospheric Engine.

 The Newcomen engines were formidable, the largest ones  were used to pump upto  7 million gallons of water from the river Thames each day to supply drinking water to London. These engines could lift a counterweight weighing 35 tons using just atmospheric pressure and a vacuum. See animation: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newcomen_atmospheric_engine . The system that we have designed works in exactly a similar manner except that a pulley and cable is used to connect the counterweight and the piston. RIGHT ! you say, that won’t work !  But I think it will. The first steam engines produced by Thomas Savery used wooden barrels for the cylinder, and the first models of the Newcomen engine used crudely cast cylinders that were ovoid at best in shape, yet the engine worked!  The pistons were ‘sealed' by wrapping them with oil or grease soaked rags!

Twenty-first Century Technology:

Look at the fantastic technology that we have developed since then for instance PTFE a form of teflon has a co-efficient of friction that at 0.05 that is almost as low as ice sliding on ice! Teflon is extremely hard wearing and can  be used as a coating. Again the jet engines on a Boeing can suck in and expel 1000 cubic metres of air in one second, the ‘Home Grid’ system has to expel only about 2 cubic metres of air in one second. There are many vacuum pumps that can do this, one such pump uses just 2.2 KW,  has a pumping capacity of 600 cubic metres/hour and can produce a vacuum of 10^^-3 Torr, which is about ten thousand times greater than the vacuum that is needed for the ‘Home Grid’ system. So yes, I think it can be done, and done quite easily.  Further I am thinking of using multi-stage turbines, since they will do the job and will run for ever with little or no maintenance.  To complete the Newcomen engine story, of course when James Watt demonstrated that super heated steam could produce pressures of several hundreds of atmospheres, interest in the Newcomen engine disappeared almost instantly, the new engines, were more compact and many magnitudes of times more powerful.

Check out the physical linkage and see if you can find a fault:

The beauty of this ‘Home Grid’ system is that it is based on hard physical facts that can be checked out theoretically, it is not for instance like the over-unity  Bidini engine which claims to produce more energy than is used to run it or the numerous perpetual motion machines that can be found on the net.  By contrast, everything about the ‘Home Grid’ system can easily be verified:

  1.  Kinetic Energy of descending counterweight
  2.  Energy needed to turn generator
  3.  Energy needed to produce vacuum
  4.  energy needed to raise counterweight back to original position.

As can be seen it is a chain of physical events that can be easily verified. If that chain of events is broken at any point then you know that the system will not work, which is not the case here.  Here is a chain of events of proven physical phenomena that take place when the system is working:

  1.   Taking a counterweight that weighs approximately  150 Kg situated at a height of 10m, its kinetic energy will be 150 Kg x 10m x  9.8m/sec^^2 = 14.7 KJ.
  2.   Energy needed to run generator = 5 KW, energy available from descending counterweight = 14 KW approx.  http://www.aurasystems.com/pages/prod_exploded.html   (P.S  the descending counterweight turns a  pulley just as in the case of a car alternator.)  In case you have not noticed enough energy and to spare is available for turning of the generator!
  3.   The multi stage vacuum turbine needs 3KW , power available  =  5KW.
  4.   Lastly the open ended shuttles are sealed converting them into pistons and atmospheric pressure acting on them is enough to raise the counterweight to its original position. For instance if diameter of shuttle/piston is 30 cms, then its surface area is 706 cms and pressure available if a vacuum of 100 torrs is created beneath the sealed shuttle/piston is equal to 565 Kgs approx, more than enough energy to lift the counterweight back to its original height.
  5.  The shuttle is then unsealed and gravity pulls the counterweight down resulting in a continuous cycle with the counterweights going up and down creating 10 KW ( more if needed) electrical output.

If it can be proved that this causative chain of physical events is possible it means that there is a 90% chance that the system will work, if on the other hand a fault is found somewhere in this chain of physical events, then there is a high probability that the system won’t work. Please donate money to build a working model, we need about $100,000.  More updates to follow.

story:
The Oregon Coast Adventure Journal 

- is a ten part series.  Each episode will be twenty minutes and cover roughly 35-40 miles of the Oregon Coastline.  The Journal is a video snapshot of the trails and beaches and how they link together from the Columbia River to the boarder of California. This will be a photographic odyssey and unique as a travel guide, a valuable resource for interested coastal hikers.

The main goal of the Journal is to purvey a sense of adventure and exploration appealing to the seasoned “through” hikers as well as the daily enthusiasts.  However, the Journal can not turn away from an opportunity like this to raise awareness and draw attention to the volume of plastic and assorted garbage that regularly wash up on the beaches.

Each episode will be a unique trekking adventure consisting of two full days and an overnight either on the beach or at a coastal campground.  The episodes will explore the often overlooked and more remote regions of the Oregon Coast.

The Impact

 This Campaign is important not only for the value of adventure, but this is an opportunity for people to catch a glimpse of something truly rare and unique.  The potential to help the environment, simply by raising awareness, is perhaps the most important aspect of the Oregon Coast Adventure Journal. 

The end result will be a kind of series that’s never been done before.  It will have a continuous individual vision of the Oregon Coast as a whole.  Even condensed, this individual perspective will translate universally and be accessible to anyone.  If more people know exactly what’s out there, they may be more inclined to participate and take better care of their immediate environments.  The Oregon Coast Adventure Journal has the potential to accomplish this, even if only in a small way…and that’s Big.

My name is Nicholas Martin.  I have nearly 15 years photography and writing experience, mostly as a freelance journalist and independent semi-professional photographer. (www.ntmphoto.com)  I believe the Oregon Coast Adventure Journal has the potential to become something very special.  This is your chance to help make this project a reality and see some of the most dramatic scenery on the planet.  Walk step for step as we explore it.

 

What We Need

  • $5000 is the low-end goal. Even though I work full-time and pick up the occasional freelance gig, every penny of my existing budget is accounted for supporting my fantastic wife and two kids, who in-turn are my support crew.
  • The majority of the money will be spent on food and transportation (drop-off and pick-up) for the crew, as well as potential time away from a paycheck.  The dream is, this project will help propel me out of my “day job” status, and I’ll be able to start doing this kind of thing as a career.
  • There are always unforeseen challenges that arise in an undertaking like this.  Gear issues, web-space, emergencies (medical or otherwise) are other potential places the money will be spent.
  • Production costs have been kept to a bare bones minimum, but all the same there will be postage, DVDs, packaging material costs, etc.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps the most important thing you can do if you can’t contribute monetarily to the Oregon Coast Adventure Journal, but want to help and contribute to the spirit of the project is to get involved in your own community:

  • Get the word out! Make some noise about the Journal.  Tell your friends.
  • Start your own campaign! Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Organize a clean-up crew! Volunteer.
  • Go for a hike!
  • Get outside in the rain.
  • Look up, Look down, look all around…

story:
The Person

Hi everybody! My name is Aida Cham and I am a junior at the California State University in Northridge. I'm a radiology major with a minor in linguistics! I'm the youngest of five children as well as being the only girl! I am a lover of languages (I can speak and/or read English, Korean, Spanish, Cambodian, and Cham from the Champa people of Southeast Asia!), travel, cultures, reading, baking, sketching, knitting, baby animals, singing (badly), and dancing (badly)!

I've been chosen as an international volunteer and ambassador for this wonderful program called International Student Volunteers (ISV)!  I will be heading to South Africa on June 7, 2013! I've decided to make a change in the world, but first, I need to see the world. That's where you come in. 

 

The Perks

 To thank you for your kind donations, I've listed some perks to helping me on my journey! Because most perks contain things that I will be doing while on my trip, you can either:

  • Opt to wait until my trip ends to receive all your perks
  • Opt out of photos/videos and receive the perks that I am able to do before the trip
  • Or, have me send you the perks that I can before the trip, then send you the perks from the trip afterwards!

Just let me know in a message or a comment on how you would like your perks! :)

 

Knitted headbands! ^

Handmade thank you cards, decorated with the South African flag!

 

The Program

ISV is a U.S. based non-profit organization. ISV deals with volunteer projects in the countries of Australia, Costa Rica, South Africa, Thailand, Dominican Republic, New Zealand, and Ecuador. Volunteer projects deal mainly with community development and wildlife conservation.

For myself, after carefully looking at program for each country, I have decided that South Africa speaks to me. I've always loved animals. Ever since I could remember, I've always had some sort of pet, whether it be kittens, chickens, rabbits or fish! For me, this is a chance of a lifetime! Lions just so happen to be my all time favorite animals, and to be able to be in the same country that they are native to, just makes my heart race.

In South Africa, more land is protected through private reserves than as part of National Parks. ISV works with a number of local organizations on selected environmental management / scientific research programs.  As a volunteer you will help professional researchers to collect important data on specific flora and fauna. In reality what this means is that you will receive specialized training in data collection, why it is critical to conservation management, and in the process you will learn an incredible amount about African wildlife, conservation and scientific research. 

Non-profit, non-governmental wildlife rescue and rehabilitation centers require a lot of help to run and maintain. Buildings and fences need repairs, trees need planting, weeds need removing, grass needs slashing, animals need feeding, and enclosures need painting and “enriching” to minimize stress in animals. Eventually, those that can be rehabilitated need to be returned to the wild. For this reason, direct interaction with animals is avoided or minimized as the desire is to help them stay ‘wild’. Part of the greater goals for these centers is to educate farmers, tourists, school children and others. This too takes time, money and passionate and dedicated individuals.

Volunteers are part of the heart and soul of wildlife rehabilitation centers. Not only that, this is an incredible opportunity for you to learn about wildlife issues from inspirational conservationists, be part of the daily activities of a wildlife rehabilitation center and of course, see incredible African animals up close. Hear cheetahs purring at close quarters, chat to the resident meerkat family, listen to the unusual sounds of the African wild dog and learn more about the challenges that these incredible animals face in wild. While it is not located in the wilds it is a great opportunity to learn more about what it takes to help threatened species come back from the brink of extinction.

It is immensely rewarding to know that as a volunteer, your activities have helped critically endangered and threatened animals live out their lives in comfort or be ready to be released back into their natural environment.

Days normally start at 8am and finish around 5pm.

 

The Impact

ISV volunteers have contributed over 3,500 person hours towards assisting with animal care at the rehabilitation centers. This includes involvement in daily cleaning rounds (cleaning feeding trays, enclosures etc.), feeding rounds (feeding animals like African Wild Dogs, cheetahs, vultures, brown hyenas and more), ambassador care (helping with cheetahs that are used to educate children and adults alike to the plight of the cheetahs and other threatened species) and cheetah runs (exercising cheetahs). Without a large number of person hours dedicated solely to the care and maintenance of these animals they would be unable to survive.

Wild cheetahs are rescued from farms where they threaten the livelihood of many farmers and thus endanger their own lives. Cheetahs require comfortable and safe enclosures to spend time from being rescued to being re-released into the wild. The same is also true for the permanent residents of wildlife rescue centers. ISV volunteers have worked hard, spending over 15,000 person hours working on enclosure maintenance. This work involves manual tasks including rust removal, painting, alien vegetation removal, and cutting back vegetation. This is probably one of the single most important contributions ISV has made to wildlife care and rehabilitation centers.

 

220,000 hrs volunteering in six countries (Australia, New Zealand, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador & Thailand)

27,614 hrs teaching English, Music, Recreation, Conservation & Health programs to 4,102 children

8,570 endangered sea turtle eggs protected & relocated

220,016,265 seeds potted for planting

237,230 native trees, grasses & shrubs planted

26,773 hrs surveying & monitoring native & endangered species

2,545 hrs composting & waste management initiatives

6,292 kg / 13,871 lbs Trash materials collected

 

The Place

South Africa is renowned for its vigorous culture, sweeping landscapes, remarkable wildlife. ISV’s South African programs extend to the countries of South Africa, Swaziland, and Mozambique. Struggling communities need help with basic essential needs - education, housing, water, and sanitation. Conservation projects include game park management or wildlife monitoring.

 

The Cost

Things my program costs DO cover:

  • Project fees as required by the host volunteer organization, i.e. project materials and supervision from host organization staff
  • All accommodations during the ISV Program
  • All meals during 2 Week Volunteer Project and at least half of meals during 2 Week Adventure Tour 
  • National park entrance/user fees
  • All program ground transportation in host country

Things my program costs do NOT cover:

  • Air transportation, air taxes and ticketing fees
  • Additional in-country (domestic) transportation by air in South Africa
  • All transportation and accommodation costs in your home country to and from the designated departure city
  • Half of your meals during the Adventure Tour
  • Medical and travel/trip cancellation insurance
  • Passports, travel visas, and any vaccinations

$3,795.00 (Program Costs) - $500.00 (Non-refundable deposit)

= $3295.00 - Program Costs

$1,500.00 - Roundtrip Flight to Africa

$700.00 - Airline Taxes

$400.00 - Domestic Flights in South Africa

  

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand if you are unable to donate, the fact that you even took the time to read my story has definitely made me happy! I would also be forever grateful if you could just share my story with your friends and family, even if they cannot donate, I would like them to learn more about ISV and the wonderful opportunities that await!
story_txt:
The Person
Hi everybody! My name is Aida Cham and I am a junior at the California State University in Northridge. I'm a radiology major with a minor in linguistics! I'm the youngest of five children as well as being the only girl! I am a lover of languages (I can speak and/or read English, Korean, Spanish, Cambodian, and Cham from the Champa people of Southeast Asia!), travel, cultures, reading, baking, sketching, knitting, baby animals, singing (badly), and dancing (badly)!
I've been chosen as an international volunteer and ambassador for this wonderful program called International Student Volunteers (ISV)!  I will be heading to South Africa on June 7, 2013! I've decided to make a change in the world, but first, I need to see the world. That's where you come in. 
 
The Perks
 To thank you for your kind donations, I've listed some perks to helping me on my journey! Because most perks contain things that I will be doing while on my trip, you can either:

Opt to wait until my trip ends to receive all your perks
Opt out of photos/videos and receive the perks that I am able to do before the trip
Or, have me send you the perks that I can before the trip, then send you the perks from the trip afterwards!

Just let me know in a message or a comment on how you would like your perks! :)
 

Knitted headbands! ^

Handmade thank you cards, decorated with the South African flag!
 
The Program
ISV is a U.S. based non-profit organization. ISV deals with volunteer projects in the countries of Australia, Costa Rica, South Africa, Thailand, Dominican Republic, New Zealand, and Ecuador. Volunteer projects deal mainly with community development and wildlife conservation.
For myself, after carefully looking at program for each country, I have decided that South Africa speaks to me. I've always loved animals. Ever since I could remember, I've always had some sort of pet, whether it be kittens, chickens, rabbits or fish! For me, this is a chance of a lifetime! Lions just so happen to be my all time favorite animals, and to be able to be in the same country that they are native to, just makes my heart race.

story:
Hi there friends!,

My name is Robbie Latta and I am a senior at Purdue University.  I'll be graduating in May, 2014 with a degree in civil engineering.  I'm hoping that I can become a better engineer and steward to the environment by achieving a LEED Green Associate designation by the U.S. Green Building Council.

But, what is LEED (?) you ask.  Great question!  LEED is an acronym for Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design.  New building projects can earn LEED points for being designed with sustainably in mind.  The USBGC (so many acronyms!) also awards LEED credentials to professionals who would like to become experts in green building design.  That is why I would like to become a LEED Green Associate!

There's a catch, though.  Those who would like to earn their LEED Green Associate designation need to pass a two hour examination.  It will require a ton of studying for me to pass the exam and the study materials and course that I will use to prepare are pretty expensive.  The course and study materials combine for $200 and it costs another $200 to take the exam.  I would really appreciate your help to get me to $400 so that I can take the course, study the material and sit for the exam.

Since Indiegogo requires that I ask for a minimum of $500, I'll donate anything above $400 to the Sierra Club.

Thanks for your help!

Robbie Latta
