story:
The Problem

How can we address the threats of climate change?

How can we help the people who are most vulnerable to changing weather patterns, an increase in intense and disastrous storms, and threatened food/water security?

By helping people help themselves.

Many of us have rallied to help people in need after disaster strikes. Remember Haiti? What about helping people beforehand, so that when disaster happens the results won’t be so destructive? Let’s help before so many lives are lost, before people are left helpless.

The Solution

It’s not rocket science. People need to understand the risks and challenges they have been experiencing. Then they need to create and implement a plan to protect themselves and increase their ability to cope with these challenges. This means assessing and fortifying the resources people can draw on when disaster strikes: the people themselves, the knowledge/information they have, social networks that allow them to help each other, the integrity of their resource base, their access to financial capital, and policies that support this self-sufficiency.

What does this have to do with you?

You can make this possible. Whether you are in California, Colorado, New York, Australia, Oregon, Mexico, Vermont, Spain, Florida or anywhere in between, a little support from you can help thousands of people.

We have to start somewhere.

So let’s start with a partnership with OceansWatch, a non-profit that is doing great work with communities in the South Pacific. Formed by a core team and skilled volunteers and sailors, Oceanswatch creates relationships with communities that have requested their assistance. Since 2008, they have:

·  Run environmental education and conservation programs with adults and children.

·  Implemented the Reef Guardian Program that empowers local community members to monitor, protect and develop management plans for their marine resources, from both a scientific and a traditional perspective.

·  Assisted communities to develop sustainable fisheries management plans and establish community controlled marine protected areas to protect the fish stocks that the communities depend on.

·  Helped local women earn income to send their children to school and take care of emergencies through sustainably produced coconut oil and other sustainable livelihoods initiatives.

·  Helped protect fresh water resources through education, monitoring, and rainwater catchment.

·  Assisted local clinics and villages by bringing medical supplies and other resources such as reference books, lights, instruments etc.

·  Raised funds and equipment for disaster relief in the wake of devastating natural disasters.

But through all of this work, OceansWatch has seen that many of the problems communities face could be directly addressed with an integrated Climate Change Adaptation Program. Using their previous work as a foundation, we are looking to create and pilot this program.

Britt Basel will lead program development, working in collaboration with the OceansWatch team, local governments, other initiatives in the region, and the communities themselves. With a MS in Human Dimensions of Natural Resources, a MS in Conservation Leadership, a BA in Anthropology, Britt has worked across continents and across scales from consulting for the United Nations’ Disaster Risk Reduction Program in Chiapas, Mexico to working in the field with communities to implement their own solutions to climate change. Britt is also a photographer and writer that has taught photography for National Geographic Student Expeditions since 2008. She uses photography to tell the story of what is happening on the ground, around-the-world. www.brittbaselphoto.com

Using this knowledge base and OceanWatch’s experience and relationships, we will work together to build a Community-Based Climate Change Adaptation Program in the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu. This program will be a foundation that can then be brought to other communities in need, in different contexts and around the world.

We need your help. Time is of the essence.

As you know, it takes money to get money. We need $15,000 to launch the pilot program. Your donation will support the design of the pilot Climate Change Adaption Program, training of staff and volunteers, and its implementation during OceanWatch’s 2014 Expedition from May-November. Again, time is of the essence. We don’t want to wait another year. Disasters won’t wait for us or for slow funding cycles. We want to start building capacity now. Then, armed with the results of this pilot program, OceansWatch will be able to find funding to continue to grow this program in the years to come, helping many more communities throughout the region.

In the immediate term, your support will help more than 3200 people in ~16 communities before disaster strikes.  You will save lives, save homes, protect people from hunger and water scarcity. You will improve the day-to-day lives and futures of thousands of people, instead of trying to help them when it’s already too late.

Not only will your donation make a real impact in the lives and futures of thousands of people, but you'll get a great gift as well!

If we don’t make our goal, we will stretch every cent we are able to raise to create this program. We believe in it, know how important it is, and are determined to find any way to make it happen.

Other Ways You Can Help?

If you can’t support us with a donation, you can help us by spreading the word!

This small campaign is the seed for a much larger initiative that is taking on one of the biggest challenges of our time. It’s time to be proactive. Instead of reacting to disaster, let’s help before disaster strikes!

story:
In his book, Walden, Henry David Thoreau asserts that "the cost of a thing is the amount of what I will call life which is required to be exchanged for it, immediately or in the long run."

The system of higher education is in crisis, and we have found a solution: reclaiming private land for the public good, offering debt free, alternative off-grid higher education in the beautiful Colorado Rockies during the summers.

My name is Samantha Bankston, and with your help my collaborators and I will be able to purchase a few acres of land in the Colorado Rockies in order to make available to the public a space to live deliberately, sustainably and in accordance with the virtues of simplicity, creativity and slow time in order to construct an off-the-grid  artist/philosopher/writer/architect/construction/designer/etc. collective summer retreat.

While I am the public face of this vision, there are many others who have dedicated themselves to accomplishing it--visual and graphic artists, academics, open source programmers, and educators all with the same mission: to create a learning-and-living environment that runs counter to the current, broken educational model of specialization, competition, emphasis on assessment, bureaucracy, and the preference of profit seeking over knowledge.  Instead, we wish to create a series of collaborative summer workshops, involving experts in a variety of fields who will teach each other while literally constructing the retreat. Rather than repeat the antagonistic, unequal, hierarchical model of administrators versus faculty versus students, our summer 'retreat' is project oriented, and every student is a teacher and vice versa.  The collective of permanent, core organizers will all participate in the functioning and orientation of the summer workshops.  What this means is: no hierarchy, no bureaucracy or administration, and no bosses, but collective organization of shared tasks.

For instance, one summer session (of varying lengths, depending on participant interest and rotation) may be themed around the construction of a greenhouse.  Our educational 'school', run similarly to the La Borde clinic in France, will have an emphasis on absolute sustainability, outdoor labor, and the study of theory and artistic activism.  A typical day would involve varied tasks (e.g. an hour gardening; two hours working on a designated project outdoors, such as installing solar panels for the greenhouse; two hours learning critical theory, with the rest of the day free to work on creative projects and to collaborate with the other attendees).  The accomplishment of this vision is still a few years off, which is why the current focus is in the initial phase of acquiring the land.

It might initially seem contradictory to acquire land, private property, to alleviate the very ills that landed property has created, but buying the land enables us to reclaim it for the public, or in philosophical terms, "deterritorialize" the land for the sake of the common good, including creating an alternative educational experience (fundamentally structured like the "Rolling Jubilee" campaign).

While it would be too daunting to try to fund the entire project at once, we've decided to incrementally fund our vision in stages, rather than over-commit with money we do not yet have.

These are the stages set for our ultimate goal of running a summer series of collaborative, non-hierarchical workshops:

Stage 1. Purchase at least $10,000 worth of land in the Colorado Rockies

Much of the land we are looking to purchase has either been tracked as rural residential land, cut into subdivisions (this is where most small acreage occurs), or land afflicted by recent forest fires (where we may replant and rehabilitate the land with trees native to the area), patented mining claims, or land designated as "hunting grounds," which would be converted to non-hunting grounds. 

During this phase, individuals are encouraged to write to us and request time to spend on the undeveloped land, camping, writing, and creating.

After the acquisition of the land, the collaborators will live and work on the land during the summers, both saving money for the construction of facilities and building said facilities.  Even if Stage 1 is the only successfully funded stage, the land will, at the very least, be used to facilitate creative individuals with a vision for fully sustainable living and learning.

Stage 2. Construction of living quarters and lodge: off-the-grid, fully sustainable "tiny" houses and/or cabins, and a central building.

This step is multi-tiered and depends upon future campaigns and saving funds, working in the summer when we are not teaching, and depending on our resources could take around five years to accomplish.  The speed at which this phase is completed depends upon financial means, which is why it's crucial for us to begin spending our summers, unburdened by rent and utilities, on the land while saving money and simultaneously constructing buildings step by step. 

During this phase, a limited number of those with "tiny" houses, tent campers, and self-sustainable vehicles may come enjoy the land while contributing to Stage 2.

Stage 3.  Construction, philosophical study, artistic live-and-work summer residency

After the completion of initial structures, such as a couple of cabins and/or "tiny" houses, then we can truly begin our ongoing vision of building a sustainable community in rotation with workshop/seminar style learning, focusing on philosophy (engagement with the root of societal problems, and creating imaginative solutions), as well as getting virtually "off-the-grid", with workshops on open source alternatives to proprietary software and intellectual property.

This stage is truly the processural phase where our vision comes to life, where rotating tasks are completed in concert with collegium style studies conducted by teachers-as-students and students-as-teachers.  During Stage 3 we aim to construct a greenhouse, another cabin, canoes, full solar power, and an art studio.

Stage 4. Continued education in the outdoors and accomplishment of vision

The vision is that of rotating tasks and enjoying "slow time": gardening, building and learning, studying high theory, and other interconnected areas of knowledge, supplemented with individual or collective interdisciplinary free time for creative projects.  This step will include themed project series throughout the summer with flexible residencies for participants. 

As it is important to rescue education from the traps of debt peonage, costs to residents will be minimal (to help run a 'retreat' that will already be 100% self-sustainable, without a mortgage, without utilities, and with the use of participant labor).

This final step is a perpetual renewal of the vision in an immersive, integrative educational experience.

*The current focus is the funding of Stage 1, the acquisition of the land*

During the first stage, my collaborators and I will live on this land during the summers in a self-sufficient converted school bus while working on the land and writing books for publication.  We welcome participants at this time to contribute to our vision with their time, share the land, and slow down: to create, to finish a dissertation, to write, etc., while simply communing with nature.  This land is our land, as Woody Guthrie sings, and what is mine is yours.

  • A little bit about myself...


While I am only one piece of this campaign puzzle, I am the primary organizer of the campaign. There are many others who have pledged their time and effort to this endeavor.

I was born and raised in Boulder, Colorado where I cultivated a deep love for the Rocky Mountains.  For the past 10 or so years I have been outside of Colorado, living in New York City, where I earned a Master's degree in philosophy at The New School for Social Research, and then I moved to Indiana to complete a joint Ph.D. in philosophy and literature at Purdue University.  Since then I have lived and worked in France, Denmark, and currently, Lake Tahoe, California.  

I, like many Ph.D. graduates of my generation, have accrued the cost of an education in exchange for a deliberative life of creativity and connection to the land.  It is important that we not allow financial indebtedness to amount to an indebted existence, toiling away for survival for the rest of our lives.  This campaign seeks to construct a life as a work of art, of simple means that will afford people time...time to write, create, and reconnect with the sublime beauty of the land.  By helping one another, we are able to carve alternative, unique paths of freedom.

As many of you probably know, academia and the humanities are in peril.  While I am fortunate enough to have a job as a professor at a small liberal arts college, my small salary only covers subsistence, and I thus live paycheck to paycheck.  The elevated cost of living in Lake Tahoe, where I teach, is part of the reason I am dedicated to providing a space for others to live simply, and spend summers learning, working with the land, and forming relational bonds in the Rockies of Colorado.

Professionally, I publish essays and books in the area of European philosophy.  Currently, I am writing a book on the French philosopher Gilles Deleuze for Bloomsbury Publications entitled Deleuze and Becoming(s).  I've also published essays and translations in a variety of anthologies, and I translated the book, Deleuze and Art, by Anne Sauvagnargues from the original French for Bloomsbury/Continuum in 2013.  Unfortunately, academic publication does not pay and is a labor of love.  Yet, research and writing offers its own reward--sharing ideas with the rest of the world--and I wish to do so during my summers in Colorado.  For a more comprehensive professional bio, please see: http://www.sierranevada.edu/academics/humanities-social-sciences/faculty/ 

Personally, I care deeply for the state of the world, social and environmental justice, and animal rights.  I love the mountains most of all; art (in all its forms) fascinates and moves me; the majority of my days are filled with philosophy, analyzing theory and imagining new modes of thought and expression.  There is a sense of urgency in this one life we have to lead, and the more time passes, the more I have felt beholden to a prefabricated existence that identifies money with success, thus the greater the urgency has become for me to unplug to focus on creative ideas that offer an alternative through writing and living. For those elements of society we find unacceptable, harmful, and stultifying, we must resist and advocate a healthier path; this is why I have decided to approach you all, and the crowd-funding platform: to create the means toward a freer, more deliberative life.  I am only a part of a collaborative team of artists, professors, graphic designers, sustainability experts, sustainable gardening specialists, and open source computer programmers.

  • The funding needed is at least $10,000 to purchase the land

As mentioned, the first stage, and the current campaign, is to simply acquire the land.  While, say, 5 acres of land go for $30,000+ in the mountains of Boulder County, or 10 acres of off-grid land go for $20,000 in Gunnison County, there are 1-4 acre parcels of land (in a variety of counties in the Rockies) that can be purchased with $10,000; fire stricken land may be substantially cheaper.  We thought it better to start lower in hopes of meeting our goal.

The only risk in not meeting the goal is insufficient funding, and if this is the case, any money received will go toward the purchase of a smaller parcel of land, and I will contribute all of my birthday/holiday money that I have saved over that last several years (~$7,000) to ensure that the goal is accomplished.  As stated above, at the very least, this land will be used as a respite for others who share our vision.

  • The significance of this campaign

This campaign extends globally.  If successful, it proves that we can all band together under one goal, which is often made materially impossible by student debt, and forge deliberative lives in communion with the land.  We can show that despite our relative positions of poverty, while supporting one another, even in small ways, we can create a sea change in the organization and values of society. 

Furthermore, this land provides the space for individuals who could not otherwise afford it--space to slow down, unplug, and work on all the creative projects they've set aside while struggling to make ends meet.  This campaign takes a hammer and smashes Sisyphus' rock!

And while the immediate, first goal is to acquire land for sustainable living and writing, the ultimate goal is to revolutionize education, replacing it with the aforementioned model--a residential school that focuses on a well-rounded, outdoor education, creativity, philosophical theory and critical engagement with the greatest problems our world faces.  This educational vision is one where those with expertise lead various workshops, and the line between student and teacher converges.  

Our core values include:

*100% sustainable, solar powered living

* Pursuing knowledge for its own sake

* Defining success by communal action, relations, and creative production

* Offering a high level of education without recourse to student debt

*A holistic approach to creative education that involves diverse activities, from tending the land, to learning philosophical and political theory, to performing acts of art

* Empowering the people

* Absolute equality for all living systems

* Respecting others' skills and eliminating hierarchical forms of organization and their subsequent, unequal power structures

* Physically grounded, face-to-face educational experience

*Recognizing the global ecological and labor crises and finding an alternative to the socioeconomic system that deadens us, exploits others, and exploits the biosphere

*Collaboration with like-minded individuals and other groups

* Creating a revolutionary educational experience that is light, that dances


  • Ways you can help!
Thank you for reading this far.  The best way to help is, of course, to donate money.  I understand that many of us cannot donate large sums of money, but it is the number of individuals who donate that counts. 

"Liking" our campaign on Facebook is a great start, and taking a moment to donate only a few dollars truly helps build the campaign's momentum.
 
https://www.facebook.com/coloradocollectiveretr...

Even if you can only afford a $5 donation, forgoing a cup of coffee or glass of wine for the day, I urge you to please do so.  There's no donation too small, and every penny is met with profound gratitude.

Please spread the word--email, share the campaign on social media, talk to your friends.  Again, thank you.

Indiegogo has sharing tools to enable you to share the campaign with ease.

Thank you in advance for helping us realize our dream for a just education, and for helping us all live a more deliberative and contemplative life. 

Love,

Samantha and Team

P.S. All "perks" (postcards, polaroids, etc.) will be sent out immediately after our campaign ends :)

story:
"No one can do everything but everyone can do something"

Stamp Green project.

Please watch the video above for a clear description of this project.

The history of plastic cards

Plastic cards are an important part of a business or organisation's image. 

They are used as loyalty cards, gift cards, ID cards and badges, access cards, membership cards, credit cards, and even as business cards!

They have become a part of many people's daily routines. You might use them to pay for your shopping, or your bus trip. The swipe card that lets you into the office or the gym is probably also made of PVC plastic. 

Tens of billions of plastic cards are made all over the world every year. How many have you only used once or twice before your wallet got so crowded that you threw them away? PVC plastic is very hard to recycle, so many end up in landfills. As landfills are growing, this is becoming a real problem. 

The future of digital cards on smartphones

Stamp Green offers an environmentally-friendly solution by allowing you to keep your cards digitally on your smartphone.

We are currently working on a web app to hold stamp, membership, and VIP cards digitally. Scan the QR codes below from your smartphone to try out our demos.

The Stamp Green web app works smoothly with 3G+ or WIFI connection.


Scan qrcodes with your smartphone:

Take Away Pizza stamp card

http://euw1a1.webapp.to/pizza

Club Vip Card

http://euw1a1.webapp.to/club

Timelines

The Stamp Green cloud software will be launched toward the Mid of April 2014.

Funds

All funds will be used for development, marketing, and promotion for the Stamp Green web app.

Perks

*Your support will be visible on the stampgreen map within 12 hours!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, there are other ways you can show your support:

Tell your family, friends, favorite shops, restaurants, cafes and clubs about us. Or spread the word on social media websites such as Facebook or Twitter.

Thanks for funding and supporting a cleaner planet.

story:
CHI SIAMO?

Siamo giovani ragazzi e ragazze, attivisti di Fridays For Future Firenze e Pistoia.

COSA CHIEDIAMO E COSA OFFRIAMO?

Organizzare uno sciopero richiede impegno mentale ma anche economico, aiutaci a rendere questo 24 settembre memorabile!

Il 24 settembre si terrà lo sciopero globale per il clima. Per garantirne la riuscita abbiamo bisogno di fondi e, quindi, del vostro aiuto. 

Ogni donazione, anche la più piccola, è fondamentale per la buona riuscita della manifestazione. 

In cambio del vostro aiuto potrete ricevere adesivi e termoadesivi per creare le vostre magliette personalizzate di Fridays For Future. 

Il VOSTRO IMPATTO 

L'aiuto di ognuno di voi è fondamentale. Lo sciopero del 24 settembre, infatti, sarà importantissimo per far sentire la nostra presenza e l'interesse di tutti, soprattutto dei più giovani, nei confronti della questione ambientale. 

L'importanza della manifestazione è ancora maggiore in vista dei summit internazionali che si terranno quest'anno, in particolare la PRECOP di Milano e la COP di Glasgow. 

Con una piccola donazione ci aiuterai a: 

- Stampare volantini, poster, locandine 

- Reperire il materiale per creare dei bellissimi striscioni 

- Reperire impianto audio 

- Noleggiare camioncino elettrico 

Se ti sta a cuore supportaci donando ora!

COME DONARE?

Per fare una donazione libera è necessario CLICCARE sul tasto "BACK IT" e seguire le indicazioni. Per ricevere gli adesivi e/o i termoadesivi dovrete scegliere il pacchetto con l'assortimento di adesivi e/o termoadesivi che preferite e seguire le indicazioni.

ALTRI MODI PER AIUTARCI 

Una donazione non è l'unico modo in cui ci puoi aiutare. 

Parlane con i tuoi amici e invitali a partecipare alla manifestazione! 

Grazie

COSA CHIEDIAMO E COSA OFFRIAMO?
Organizzare uno sciopero richiede impegno mentale ma anche economico, aiutaci a rendere questo 24 settembre memorabile!
Il 24 settembre si terrà lo sciopero globale per il clima. Per garantirne la riuscita abbiamo bisogno di fondi e, quindi, del vostro aiuto. 
Ogni donazione, anche la più piccola, è fondamentale per la buona riuscita della manifestazione. 
In cambio del vostro aiuto potrete ricevere adesivi e termoadesivi per creare le vostre magliette personalizzate di Fridays For Future. 
Il VOSTRO IMPATTO 
L'aiuto di ognuno di voi è fondamentale. Lo sciopero del 24 settembre, infatti, sarà importantissimo per far sentire la nostra presenza e l'interesse di tutti, soprattutto dei più giovani, nei confronti della questione ambientale. 
L'importanza della manifestazione è ancora maggiore in vista dei summit internazionali che si terranno quest'anno, in particolare la PRECOP di Milano e la COP di Glasgow. 
Con una piccola donazione ci aiuterai a: 
- Stampare volantini, poster, locandine 
- Reperire il materiale per creare dei bellissimi striscioni 
- Reperire impianto audio 
- Noleggiare camioncino elettrico 
Se ti sta a cuore supportaci donando ora!
COME DONARE?
Per fare una donazione libera è necessario CLICCARE sul tasto "BACK IT" e seguire le indicazioni. Per ricevere gli adesivi e/o i termoadesivi dovrete scegliere il pacchetto con l'assortimento di adesivi e/o termoadesivi che preferite e seguire le indicazioni.
ALTRI MODI PER AIUTARCI 
Una donazione non è l'unico modo in cui ci puoi aiutare. 
Parlane con i tuoi amici e invitali a partecipare alla manifestazione! 
Grazie

story:
CLIMBING4RHINO - EVEREST BASE CAMP; THE LONG WAY ROUND!

Following the success of past endeavors in support of rhino protection, this year’s trek will see students team up with conservationists to hike up to Everest Base Camp in branded full-bodied rhino costumes. As global awareness of rhino poaching has increased, we are happy to be joined by interested parties and conservation scientists. This diverse group hopes to stand at the base of the World’s highest mountain, making a bold statement against rhino poaching.

Everest Base Camp via Gokyo lakes and the three high passes is no ordinary hike. The group will have to ascend three passes over 5 000m, with the final destination being 5 545m above sea-level. This is a challenge to any hiker as one is confronted with the ever-changing weather conditions and high altitude.


The Impacts:

Most of the world has become aware of the dangers the rhino species is facing. Rhinos are being driven to the edge of extinction and we want to make a difference!

Our goal this year is for Climbing4Rhino to raise over R100 000 for rhino related projects under the wing of the Lawrence Anthony Earth Organization. One of their key projects is the Fundimvelo Thula Thula Rhino orphanage, which is the only such facility in KwaZulu Natal. This state of the art facility sees to the rescue, rehabilitation and release of orphaned rhino.

SUPPORT NEPAL! After the devastating earthquake that struck Nepal and surrounding regions this year the people of Nepal are in desperate need of support. Since their main source of income come from tourists it is crucial that we get as many as possible hikers on this years trek. The Rhino Trekkers are personally responsible for covering all costs relating to their trip and the funding needed for a trip of this magnitude is quite a lot. YOU CAN HELP MAKE THIS HAPPEN!

We hope to achieve all this through the climb participants as well as fundraising events held in the build-up to the climb.

So where is the money going?

The funding goal for this campaign is to raise funds for rhino projects. In addition we also want to help sponsor hikers who can not completely afford the funding of the trip.

Other Ways You Can Help!

  • Spread the word about our campaign and help raise awareness for rhinos.
  • Tell everybody that you can! 
  • If you have any other ideas we could use for raising funds let us know in the comments.

story:
OPEN STREETS CALGARY

Shifting Calgary's Energy to Pedal Power 

In Alberta energy represents 70% or our exports. 40% of our electrical power is from coal burning. In Calgary 1 out of 12 jobs are in the fossil fuel industry. Not surprisingly Calgary is seen as the Cowboy oil and gas centre of Canada. But, did you know that:

  • The C-Train system is wind powered? 
  • Since 2009 city-wide recycling grew 71%?
                          That's 208 Million Kgs less in the landfill!
  • There are 2,000 community gardens in the City? 
  • Over 1 Million people visit our 20 free street festivals? 
  • Calgary just approved the most ambitious Urban Cycle Track commuting system in Canada?


We at Open Streets have been along for this ride, advocating for local sustainable transportation, energy and public spaces. Our roots grew from a Street Festival / Cyclovia that focused on bikes and people power, and in using public roads for more than just traffic. In 2012 we launched Open Streets Calgary and have brought our pedal powered activities and message to Calgary's street festivals, Community Centres, Businesses and homes. In 2013 we had 2,000 people ride our electricity generating biker bar and blender bike, and 250,000 people saw our booth, heard pedal powered music and watched bike related fun.

We are about

  • Changing the conversation about cycling and transportation.
  • Demonstrating the meaning of energy use (by engaging people in creating pedal power).
  • Showing that energy conservation does make a difference.
  • Demonstrating that the creative use of public spaces builds community spirit and engagement for developing local solutions to issues  that seem too big to face, such as the environment  and the economy.

      How do we work?

      We bring our bike systems to the public. People get on the bikes, and power sound, bands, lighting systems and more. They experience the effort that it takes to power a fan, stereo, game system and more. We link the pedal generating experience to energy conservation and sustainability. Visitors to our tent meet volunteers from our partner cycling advocacy groups, learn about bike commuting, community bike shops, get bike tune ups and have fun making buttons, riding penny farthings and more. Our booth makes the issues of energy, cycling and public use of public spaces personal and accessible to our visitors. 

      What's the plan for 2014?

      We will be returning to to the streets for festivals and other events. We are also putting on our own 2 day Re-localization Fair. RE-Localize will be a celebration of food, energy and transportation combined with a market of local food and goods, a guest presentation by Rob Hopkins (Founder of theTransition Town Movement) as well as workshops for people wanting to learn how to be-local. We will be premiering our expanded pedal power system at the Fair.


      Our Pitch

      ~ We need new equipment.

      Our present system of the biker bar and blender bike has pedalled thousands of miles. Its getting worn out. At the same time we are getting requests to be a part of more and larger events. The current setup has enough pedal power to run a 250 W system, power a live band and make smoothies. An expanded system will give us 1000 W of power, more smoothies and most importantly, double our equipment, and triple our impact by increasing the size and number of events we visit. And we would be able to double book our gear!

      What We Need

      We need a new blender bike, power system and speakers. We need to develop a volunteer training program and activity guide to spread our message of cycling, energy, green and engaged public spaces. We are asking you to help us raise $9,000 to support these important purchases and expenses:

      • Electric Fender Blender Pro - $2,125
      • Pedal Power Utility Box - $1,975
      • Fender Blender Universale - $249
      • Fender Blender Universale (Vitamix Upgrade) - $499
      • Pedal Powered Spin Art - $600
      • 2 Tablets with lobby pad stands for registering participants - $1000
      • Program Development and staffing - $1,552

      ^^ awesome perks!

      What You Get

      Most importantly you will have our gratitude for helping us continue to transform Calgary from an Oil town to a vibrant city of public cycling infrastructure, local food gardens, and diverse widely used public spaces. We also have some seriously nice perks for you. For fun we've organized our perks in a Tour de France theme, there is a perk for every donor level from Fans to Mountain Racers to Rookies and Tour winners. Check out this link for the full range of Perks, or look over there to the right of the screen to see them listed.

      Perks include; membership in the Arusha Centre; custom button and fridge magnets; bike lights; custom T-shirts; and draw entries to win a MEC Sihloutte Bike. Everyone that gives will also get a download of our Cycle-Active community action manual with volunteer training, activity programming and templates for posters, emails and social media.

      We have a number of generous perks for larger donations, including deluxe hotel accommodation or full passes to either the Calgary Folk Festival or Sled Island Music Festival. Donors can also receive the use of our full Street Festival setup at a Calgary location of their choosing. For the seriously philanthropic, there is also a sponsor perk that will put your name in lights at Open Streets for a full year!


      The Impact

      If we get full funding we will:

      • double our equipment
      • triple the number of participants using our gear
      • quadruple  our power
      • put on Calgary's first RE-Localization Festival
      • continue to shift Calgary's energy towards cycling, localization and support of sustainable energy.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      We know that not everyone has the bucks to share, and that's cool, we're on a tight budget too! You can help us out as volunteers, by sharing the word about this campaign, by asking your work to pitch in, or book us. 

      • Share our campaign by email, Facebook, Twitter and by telling your friends.
      • Volunteer to help us during the campaign by putting up posters and handing out info cards.
      • Call us up if you have other ways to help, we're at 403 270-3200.
      • Use the awesome Indiegogo share tools!

      You can also stop in and say hi when you see us around Calgary this summer!

      Thanks!

      We are already working hard to make this year's program a rocking success. We want to share our message and the tools for creating it with everyone. We hope that this year we'll increase the number and quality of our open street events making it an even better year then 2013. Thanks to our past supporters, those who continue to do so and and to those of you who have joined us through this campaign!

      We invite any ideas and/or thoughts that could help make our events even more special and fun.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Patrick Clark, I am 17 years old and I am a Boy Scout in Troop 180. I am currently the rank of Life Scout, and to become the rank of Eagle Scout I need to complete an Eagle Scout Project. An Eagle Scout Project is usually a community service project that is planned and organized by the scout. The project that I have planned will be the reconstruction of a class garden at a local elementary school. This campaign is to raise the funds so that I can complete my project and become an Eagle Scout.

 

What We Need & What You Get

For my project we will need around $500. The funding goes to project materials, such as the PVC we will be laying down, the planters we will be adding, the hoses we will be replacing, and other materials of that nature. Some of the funding will also go to food and water for everyone that will be helping me do the project, since it is expected to take most of the weekend.

After the project is finished, there will be some sort of commemorative sign or plaque put on site, to recognize everyone who helped. Everyone who donates will be recognized.

 

The Impact

This project will not only help me but it will help the community as well. Since the garden is located at a school, the students will be able to learn about gardening, the plants and the environment.

story:
Dog Talkie – Our Story


Dog Talkie is an iPad and iPhone app that allows dogs to communicate their wants and desires with their human companions.  Dogs "nose touch" the pictures on the iPad screen with the activity they are interested in, and Dog Talkie will do the rest.  You and your dog will then hear in English and other languages what the dog has communicated.  It will even send you a doggie text message to your iPhone (very nice when your dog absolutely has to go outside right now!)  Imagine fussing around in the kitchen or in the garage, when you get a text on your iPhone that your dog is requesting a walk.  Wow!

How we came up with Dog Talkie

My name is David Kahan, founder of Azymous Interactive, husband, father, and imperial servant to two little dachshunds named Ashley and Willow.  We also care for Molly, my parents rescue dachshund. 

One thing one learns very quickly with having dogs in the family is just how extraordinarily intelligent they are. Many of you may have heard that recent studies have shown some dogs can understand vocabularies of several hundred words, and have intelligence comparable to a 2 year old human child.

One evening, while surfing the internet on the iPad, little Willow sauntered over to say hello, and touched the iPad screen with her nose, triggering the web browser to play a video.  Light bulbs went off…Hey, if dogs can touch their nose on the iPad and trigger events, why not design an app to help them communicate with us? 

Thinking further on this, I remembered many years ago seeing a tv show about Lana the Chimpanzee, who in the 1970’s communicated with people via Emory Universities' symbolic language Yerkish. To communicate, Lana would touch pictures of the appropriate Yerkish symbol on what was then a modern computer screen. Well, if Lana the chimp can communicate by touching pictures, I bet our dogs can as well!  And so Azymous Interactive set out to engineer a tablet based app that would facilitate canine to human communications.

Dog Vision

Dogs do not see the same as we do, and it would not do any good for Dog Talkie to display graphics for dogs if they could not see them clearly. Dogs do in fact see colors, but differently then we do, with less detail and muted clarity.  One wonderful tool we found was on Andras Peter’s Dog Vision website, which is very helpful for looking at graphics from a dogs point of view. 

For example, the human view of our prototype screen for Dog Talkie looks as follows…

                  While most dogs will see the screen as follows…

The "Treat", "Outside", and "Affection" graphics provide reasonable contrast, while the "Play" graphic in the top right corner could use improvement.  We will be working on providing as clear as possible graphics from the canine point of view for the released product.

OK, what happens when a dog’s nose touches a Dog Talkie graphic?

First a voice file is played, clearly stating what the touched graphic symbolizes, such as “Let's Play” or “Go Outside”. Playing the voice response is very important, as it both reinforces for the dog what has been selected and lets nearby humans know as well.

After playing the voice file, Dog Talkie, depending upon its configuration, will send a doggie text message their companions iPhone, such as “I need to go outside!” or "I'm lonely, let's play!" 

When we first tested the prototype, some dogs would "nose touch" the graphics two or three times in a row, causing repetitive responses.  We subsequently reprogrammed the graphics code to ignore additional touches for few seconds, preventing these inadvertent "multi-nose" touches.

The most important things...

Dog Talkie is a lot of fun for both you and your dog. A little patience and interaction will give your dogs a wonderful experience and an enhanced ability to communicate with their human companions.

Azymous Interactive will be donating 10% of all proceeds from Dog Talkie sales to Franklin's Friends, a wonderful animal welfare group that benefits the SPCA of Central Florida. Every single copy of Dog Talkie sold will benefit homeless dogs and other animals, and that really motivates us!

Who we are at Azymous Interactive

Azymous Interactive is a small iOS and Android app company based in Apopka Florida, just north of Orlando.  Principal Engineers are David Kahan, Ron Bakerian, and Tim Holt. We have worked together since 1988, and have been good friends since college, which for us was back in the early 1980s.  David founded a software development company in 1988 which went on to create retail Windows and Mac applications such as Scientific American’s The Planets, The Way Baseball Works with Tim MacCarver, and large scale videoconferencing applications such as iPhysicianNet.  In the spring of 2012 we released, to high reviews, ShelfLook and ShelfLook for iPad, unique apps that allow physically challenged patrons to view library and bookstore books without having to tilt their heads or crouch downwards.  Early this year David’s son Zachariah Kahan joined the group to provide video and media support. Like most engineering groups, Azymous Interactive is empowered by creativity, friendship, and very, very strong coffee.

What will the Indiegogo funds be used for?

We will be utilizing Indiegogo funds for ...

  • Software engineering
  • Quality Control
  • Basic Foreign Translations
  • Promotions
  • All resulting in the release of Dog Talkie v1.0 for iPad and its companion iPhone app to receive doggie text messages.

How will funds beyond our goal be used?

Funds raised over and above our goal will be greatly utilized, allowing us to...

Create Android releases, including versions for...

  • Nexus
  • Kindle Fire
  • Barnes & Noble Nook
  • Galaxy Tablets
  • Professionally developed Dog Talkie training guide

Significant Additional funds will also enable us to provide...

  • Additional foreign language support
  • Advanced versions including user controlled graphics,
  • Significant promotion of Dog Talkie

Frequently Asked Questions

  • Q: Can I record my own voice for the commands so my dog will recognize it right away?
  • A: Yes, the Dog Talkie app will support customers recording their own voice for buttons.
  • Q: Won't my dog just nose touch "Treat" all day long?
  • A: Dog Talkie allows you to place limits on how often a graphic can be touched.  So you won't have a long list of doggie text messages that say "Treat", Treat", "Treat"...
  • Q: Will there be an Android Tablet version of Dog Talkie
  • A: After the release of the iPad version, we will commence work support for Android tablets such as the Nexus, Kindle Fire, Barnes & Noble Nook, Samsung Galaxy, and more. 
  • Q: Do I need an iPhone or iPod Touch to receive text messages from my dog?
  • A: Yes, as part of the Dog Talkie release, its companion version of Dog Talkie for iPhone and iPod Touch will be posted on the app store, which is dedicated to receiving dog messages.
  • Q: Will the iPad have to have 3G support?
  • A:No, it will not be necessary, but to support the sending of doggie txt messages, the iPad will have to have wireless access,
  • Q: Do you see versions for other creatures besides dogs?
  • A: The app has the potential to be redesigned for any intelligent animal that can trigger a tablet computer screen
  • Q: Do you have a vision for future versions?
  • A: Yes, we plan to have a “Genius” edition which will have many more pages of selections, and allow for additional training screens to be downloaded from the internet.  We also plan a “Dog Talkie Teacher” edition that will allow users to create their own screens.
  • Q: Who are some of the professionals advising you in your development?
  • A: Franklin’s Friends, a wonderful animal welfare group based in Maitland FL with Dr. Monisha Seth, the Piedmont Animal Hospital of Apopka FL with Dr. John Burton DVM and Dr. Kathy Metzger-Smit DVM, and our canine experts, Ashley, Willow, Molly, Juliette, Franklin, Katie, Annie, Trinity, Ajax, Mac and Maggie

                         THE REWARDS

             $5 Reward - Sponsors Listing

  $15 Reward - Dog Talkie iPad & iPhone apps

   $25 Reward - Your Dogs Personal Web Page

         $50 Reward - The Dog Talkie T-Shirt

$75 Reward - Your Dog Immortalized on the main Dog Talkie Screen! (Limited Edition)

$175 Reward - Executive Producer (Limited Edition) - Listing on Splash Screen, Credits, and the Dog Talkie Website

$250 Reward - Group Sponsor - Your groups dedicated web page with links to your organization on the Dog Talkie web page

Dogs do in fact see colors, but differently then we do, with less detail and muted clarity.  One wonderful tool we found was on Andras Peter’s Dog Vision website, which is very helpful for looking at graphics from a dogs point of view. 
For example, the human view of our prototype screen for Dog Talkie looks as follows…

                  While most dogs will see the screen as follows…

The "Treat", "Outside", and "Affection" graphics provide reasonable contrast, while the "Play" graphic in the top right corner could use improvement.  We will be working on providing as clear as possible graphics from the canine point of view for the released product.
OK, what happens when a dog’s nose touches a Dog Talkie graphic?
First a voice file is played, clearly stating what the touched graphic symbolizes, such as “Let's Play” or “Go Outside”. Playing the voice response is very important, as it both reinforces for the dog what has been selected and lets nearby humans know as well.
After playing the voice file, Dog Talkie, depending upon its configuration, will send a doggie text message their companions iPhone, such as “I need to go outside!” or "I'm lonely, let's play!" 
When we first tested the prototype, some dogs would "nose touch" the graphics two or three times in a row, causing repetitive responses.  We subsequently reprogrammed the graphics code to ignore additional touches for few seconds, preventing these inadvertent "multi-nose" touches.
The most important things...
Dog Talkie is a lot of fun for both you and your dog. A little patience and interaction will give your dogs a wonderful experience and an enhanced ability to communicate with their human companions.
Azymous Interactive will be donating 10% of all proceeds from Dog Talkie sales to Franklin's Friends, a wonderful animal welfare group that benefits the SPCA of Central Florida. Every single copy of Dog Talkie sold will benefit homeless dogs and other animals, and that really motivates us!

Who we are at Azymous Interactive
Azymous Interactive is a small iOS and Android app company based in Apopka Florida, just north of Orlando.  Principal Engineers are David Kahan, Ron Bakerian, and Tim Holt. We have worked together since 1988, and have been good friends since college, which for us was back in the early 1980s.  David founded a software development company in 1988 which went on to create retail Windows and Mac applications such as Scientific American’s The Planets, The Way Baseball Works with Tim MacCarver, and large scale videoconferencing applications such as iPhysicianNet.  In the spring of 2012 we released, to high reviews, ShelfLook and ShelfLook for iPad, unique apps that allow physically challenged patrons to view library and bookstore books without having to tilt their heads or crouch downwards.  Early this year David’s son Zachariah Kahan joined the group to provide video and media support. Like most engineering groups, Azymous Interactive is empowered by creativity, friendship, and very, very strong coffee.

What will the Indiegogo funds be used for?
We will be utilizing Indiegogo funds for ...

Software engineering
Quality Control
Basic Foreign Translations
Promotions
All resulting in the release of Dog Talkie v1.0 for iPad and its companion iPhone app to receive doggie text messages.

How will funds beyond our goal be used?
Funds raised over and above our goal will be greatly utilized, allowing us to...
Create Android releases, including versions for...

Nexus
Kindle Fire
Barnes & Noble Nook
Galaxy Tablets
Professionally developed Dog Talkie training guide

Significant Additional funds will also enable us to provide...

Additional foreign language support
Advanced versions including user controlled graphics,
Significant promotion of Dog Talkie

Frequently Asked Questions


Q: Can I record my own voice for the commands so my dog will recognize it right away?


A: Yes, the Dog Talkie app will support customers recording their own voice for buttons. 



Q: Won't my dog just nose touch "Treat" all day long?
A: Dog Talkie allows you to place limits on how often a graphic can be touched.  So you won't have a long list of doggie text messages that say "Treat", Treat", "Treat"...



Q: Will there be an Android Tablet version of Dog Talkie

A: After the release of the iPad version, we will commence work support for Android tablets such as the Nexus, Kindle Fire, Barnes & Noble Nook, Samsung Galaxy, and more.  



Q: Do I need an iPhone or iPod Touch to receive text messages from my dog?

A: Yes, as part of the Dog Talkie release, its companion version of Dog Talkie for iPhone and iPod Touch will be posted on the app store, which is dedicated to receiving dog messages. 


Q: Will the iPad have to have 3G support?
A:No, it will not be necessary, but to support the sending of doggie txt messages, the iPad will have to have wireless access,


Q: Do you see versions for other creatures besides dogs?
A: The app has the potential to be redesigned for any intelligent animal that can trigger a tablet computer screen



Q: Do you have a vision for future versions?

A: Yes, we plan to have a “Genius” edition which will have many more pages of selections, and allow for additional training screens to be downloaded from the internet.  We also plan a “Dog Talkie Teacher” edition that will allow users to create their own screens.



Q: Who are some of the professionals advising you in your development?

A: Franklin’s Friends, a wonderful animal welfare group based in Maitland FL with Dr. Monisha Seth, the Piedmont Animal Hospital of Apopka FL with Dr. John Burton DVM and Dr. Kathy Metzger-Smit DVM, and our canine experts, Ashley, Willow, Molly, Juliette, Franklin, Katie, Annie, Trinity, Ajax, Mac and Maggie

                         THE REWARDS
             $5 Reward - Sponsors Listing

  $15 Reward - Dog Talkie iPad & iPhone apps

   $25 Reward - Your Dogs Personal Web Page

         $50 Reward - The Dog Talkie T-Shirt

$75 Reward - Your Dog Immortalized on the main Dog Talkie Screen! (Limited Edition)

$175 Reward - Executive Producer (Limited Edition) - Listing on Splash Screen, Credits, and the Dog Talkie Website

$250 Reward - Group Sponsor - Your groups dedicated web page with links to your organization on the Dog Talkie web page

story:
Our Story

My close and personal friend, Mike, and I began hiking in the Brooks Range in 2007 when we both landed seasonal work in Coldfoot, AK.  Coldfoot is a small truck stop North of the Arctic Circle on the lifeline between Fairbanks and Prudhoe Bay, the Dalton Highway. A summer full of short three- and four-day trips culminated with a 12-day trip into the Gates of the Arctic National Park. We finished during the first week of October, and had not seen a temperature above freezing the entire time. As the ice formed and the season ended we were made aware of the immense respect this indomitable land required of its visitors. We returned the next spring, in early 2008,

My close and personal friend, Hyme, and I thus began our annual summer backpack hikes through the Brooks Range.  We chose to start from the West, where the Brooks Range first emerges out of the ocean.    Summer 2008 began on a 50ft strip of hard ground between Iliad Lagoon and the Chuckse Sea 70 miles above the arctic circle.  We walked, swam and crawled east for 40 days and about 200 miles.  Northwest of the village of Ambler a rock smashed Hyme's middle-left toe, our hike ended and amended my hiking partner's name to Hyme-9 Toes.  Summer 2009 we flew into Ambler and hiked approximately 100 miles to the Reed River. Summer 2010, we parked the support vehchle at Galbraith Lake and hiked to the Sagavanirktok River headwaters east  of the Dalton Highway along the western edge of America's largest wildlife refuge.  ANWR.

As the miles beneath our boots accumulated through the Brooks Range, our most commonly shared sentiment was respect.  A deep and serious respect for perpetual time and the truely wild. 

We are walking across ANWR to confirm why ANWR should always remain a quiet place without human control.  We believe humans should be visitors and guardians of ANWR for our benefit and enjoyment and a bequest to the future generations.  

 

      

Mike

Mike is a North American tour guide (guide name is Shaggy) and is currently guiding small groups on cross-country camping/lodging tours across the United States and trekking Zion, Big Bend, Grand Canyon, Bryce, Joshua Tree National parks  He shows travelers the magnificense of the North American landscape as well as the great diversity of North American cities.  Mike can be found somewhere between Manhattan, NY, and Venice Beach, CA.


Hyme-9 Toes

Hyme-9 is currently volunteering for his second conservation corps, this time in Nevada. He maintains and beautifies public lands.  His first stint with the conservation corps was 2006 in the Pacific Northwestern region of the United States maintaining King County trails and eradicating (battling) feral blackberry thickets.  Hyme-9 is working in the deserts of the American Southwest and can be found within 500 miles of Winnimuca, Nevada.

Both men are high ranking members of the Ancient and Honorable Order of E. Clampus Vitus.

Journey Well Hobos!


We are working hard for this journey.  Every dollar earned is going to this expedition.    It will happen- ANWR or Bust.  We practice excellent hiking ethics and honor the earth.


What We Need & What You Get

Transportation in the remote Brooks Range, especially ANWR, is costly and our backpacks in the past have weighed a crippling 87lbs.  We need funds for an Alaskan Bush pilot to drop us off near the Alaska/Yukon Border and make two food drops between the International Border and the Dalton.  

Dehydrated foods, energy bars and peanut butter are costly.  Even though funds raised for this journey are for transportation, we must give a shout-out to CORE Foods.  CORE products will be in the backpacks.  We are impressed with the quality of ingredients and the essential nutritional value CORE bars provide.  A big healthy "Thanks!" to the team at CORE for their support!        


The only electronic devices we carry are two Spots and two cameras.  The Spot is a small orange box, about the size of a deck of cards, with four buttons and a little blinking light.  When activated, the Spot emails our current coordinate location to receivers. The Spot can also be used as an emergency beacon.  It has never failed us. We would be honored if you were a receiver of our Spot messages, enabling you to track our progress on a map at home.  Allow yourself, friends and family to experience a real life- real time- slice of adventure, adventure into the wild.    
 
The Impact

A dream of ours is to see Arctic National Wildlife Refuge evolve into Arctic National Park.  National Park status would place even stricter restrictions on the future development of this pristine environment.  First, we must make the uniqueness of ANWR known.  ANWR is the last truely wild area protected by law.   As guests walking across this last remaining wilderness, a true passion the wild and all that entails is paramount to a successful journey.  ANWR should not spoil due to the tempoary needs of a tempory generation.  Through video, photographs and eye witness accounts we will offer a multi-media testimony to the power of wilderness and evidence for it's preservation.

   

We have the responsibility and are able to keep timeless the wild.

story:
Hi Friends

   I'm Aron D, many of you  already know me but for those who don't, I'm worthy of this good cause. Yes, this is a first world problem, my budget, my accountant and my girlfriend all cannot justify the cost of the car I have a crush on, and already own a perfectly reliable 2005 Toyota Camry.... BUT I believe dreams can come true, and I'm sure many of you have dreamt of that car you would love to own and will help buy mine. 

   All I need is $100 from 690 people, I have 500 friends on Facebook, besides birthday greetings once a year on my Facebook wall, how about $100 just this once! :D 

For those people visiting from the FJ Cruiser Forums, $100 is less than the cost of a tank of petrol but 690 people donating this could allow me to be a member of this esteemed forum which I have been checking out since July 2011 back when Australia had a 6 month wait for supply of a FJ Cruiser. (I went to place an order but finance knocked me back!)

What I Need & What You Get

So why do I need $69000 for a car that car that sells for $45,990? Accessories, my friends, accessories! 

For those who have been to a new car dealer, we all know that those accessories  can add up pretty quick. And this is a 4wd I'm talking about. You can't have a 4wd without roof racks for the petrol jerry cans, floor mats for those muddy camping trips, rock rails, well rock rails are self explanatory but for those who don't know, they help protect the underbody of the car. And that's just the beginning of the accessories list, tow bar, nudge bar also known as the roo bar down under in Australia.. Snorkel to help the Fj cruise tread deeper water, 2" lift and shocks for better ground clearance and the list goes on!

As I'm not looking for a free ride, that's what your donation will buy you, a free ride in my  4wd. Donations under $50 will earn a quick ride in my car, donations of $50-$100 will  allow you to test drive my car, anything over $100 will allow you to go off-roading with me. Donate $1000 or more for a full off roading weekend getaway including have a turn driving on the 4wd trails. 

If I don’t reach my entire goal, I will simply use the raised funds as a deposit for the car and finance the remainder of my balance.....  oh and  also flowers and an 'I love you' card for one upset girlfriend who says my hard earned money shouldn't be spent on financing a  sixty thousand dollar car (with accessories) but should be spent on my son, even though I know he would much prefer going camping and fishing in one cool Tonka Truck, just look at that picture, this is one sexy car!

Feel free to share the link or repost on Facebook to your friends! Thank you for your time and generosity!

story:
Land Energy Clearing

I am a Wellingtonian, born and bred. I love this city, especially the energy our "windy" weather brings. One of the great things about Wellington is that negative energy doesn't stick around. It's not only that the wind won't let it. The people here are not destined to be stuck in one place either.

During the earthquakes in Wellington, July 2013, it was not only the physical structure that took a hit. The land energy started to shed its negativity. In a behavior that looked very similar to liquefaction, the land poured out a black energy of past pains.

It is the belief of many that this land was once part of Lemuria. The downfall of Lemuria was energetically vicious. Many of those we work with have past life memories of this time. The consciousness of the civilization was infected with the intention to lower self worth and increase destructive behavior.

This is what we started to see exhibiting in the behavior of Wellingtonians post earthquake.

We have been asked by those we work with to clear the land on a deeper level than the normal meditation that most practitioners do each day. 

What we feel will help most is to clear quartz crystals and program them to lift and clear the land and group consciousness of the greater Wellington region.

We will start this with 70 crystals in high density areas.

Each crystal will be highly charged and Programed. We will then send energy to them each day. We will also be hold regular groups to send energy to them and clear the energy of Wellington over the next year.

Our time will be gifted in service to the process and to Wellington, however we are unable to cover the cost of the crystals.

If you can financially support, even a small amount, please give what you can. If you want to join us in the meditations, please add me on Facebook or visit Wisdomtrader.co.nz for details.

story:
Hello! I am a middle school student from Tucson, Arizona, and I am here to help raise funds for my class immersion trip.  This immersion trip is no ordinary field trip. It is a “Me to We” retreat, which is a week-long intensive leadership seminar and community service project wrapped into one. The retreat is being held this spring at the Windsong Peace and Leadership Center in Patagonia, Arizona. Sustainable farming practices, conservation, leadership and public speaking skills, social responsibility, and how to become effective agents for change are just some of the things we will learn during this exciting retreat.  My personal goal is to raise $500 to contribute towards the expenses for my class’s participation in this retreat.

Should you choose to help support this endeavor, I have developed several perks as a means of thanking you for your generosity:

  • For a $5.00 donation, you will receive a handmade thank you card.

  • For a $10.00 donation, you will receive a handmade bookmark.

  • For a $15.00 donation, I will be sending out seed packets to help promote the idea of helping the environment.

  • For a $20.00 donation, you will receive a calendar with nature themed pictures.

  • For a $35.00 donation, you will receive a hand painted birdhouse and a thank you card.

  • Finally, for a donation of $50.00 or more, you will receive a package which includes all of these perks.

Your generous support in helping me and my classmates attend the “Me to We” retreat is deeply appreciated. Thank you so much for listening.

story:
Hi everyone,

In 2010 I went to Haiti with All Hands to work on the earthquake response. What a great experience that was, and more importantly, what an impact we had. Huge! There's now a beautiful town (Leogane) where a giant pile of rubble used to be, in no small part to the many fantastic people at hands.org and of course, my good self!

In 2014 I'll be teaming up with them again in the Philippines, to help rebuild after Typhoon Haiyan. By donating you'll be helping me, and helping hands.org to clean up, and rebuild. Get them back on their feet.

We all know what a tragedy these events are so I won't dwell on that side of things too much. Suffice to say I'm lucky with my job timetable: it's very flexible so I can up and leave to do things like this whenever I want, but I understand that while many people would like to come and help they just don't have the time.

No need to stress though...you can still contribute! Donate-you'll be helping people who really need it. I've seen it with my own eyes-we aren't saving the world but we do make a big difference for some people. It means something. So, get involved! And, for those who read last time, I promise I'll write another blog on the whole experience ;)

So, enough mucking around...get your purses/wallets out and click the button-and thanks very much in advance!

Tim

story:
Short Summary

The Foundation for IT Sustainability (FFITS.ORG) is a global, non-profit organisation established in 2008 whose mission is to engage with, and educate individuals, government and corporations on the environmental footprint of technology, as well as promote the sustainable use of technology to help solve environmental problems.

Our largest awareness campaign was launched in 2010 and has fast become the world’s largest Virtual Green IT event: International Green IT Awareness Week (IGITAW) in 2010.

IGITAW (www.greenitweek.org) runs from the 1 - 7 June each year and brings together the global network of Green IT professionals, including thousands of tech journalists, CIOs, CTOs, IT Managers, sustainability professionals, carbon managers and more under one virtual roof. IGITAW comprises of over 30 live and pre-recorded tactical and practical learning sessions, international keynotes, Q&A panels and more.

During this week our panel of leading international speakers will present a series of engaging, pragmatic and thought-provoking conference-style presentations. The aim of the presentations will be to equip attendees with a range of skills and the knowledge necessary to take action on Green IT, however big or small.

As a 24 hour global virtual conference, attendees of IGITAW can learn from the world’s leading Green IT experts, network, chat directly with other attendees, speakers and sponsors in the comfort of their own home or office.

The week of education and action was developed to encourage individuals and organisations to demand more from themselves and their partners, holding each other to account for our impact on the environment. The initiative also aims to encourage those individuals and organisations to bring together their CIO, IT Directors along with their business managers, CFO and COE’s to start the discussion around what their organisation can do to green their IT infrastructure.

What We Need

To assist with building the awareness of IGITAW we need your financial support to help us reach more individuals and organisations across the globe through the development of educational and motivational multimedia campaigns (similar to ‘Our Vision’ video above), social media initiatives, advertidsing campaigns and global press engagement. 

FFITS.ORG relies on generous financial supporters to continue our important work in building awareness of Green IT issues, and with your help we can continue to spread the message across the globe and to remain the largest Green IT conference in the world!

The Impact

The production of empowering and inspirational multimedia is a proven method of building rapid global awareness on an issue. Mobile marketing, live casting and podcasting, and sharing of photos and videos, can spread the word about our campaign and help us build awareness in very unique and powerful ways. Our particular type of social media marketing will also provide us with the potential to go viral quickly.

When we launched IGITAW in 2010, with the generous backing of our financial supporters, we produced three Green IT themed viral videos to assist with raising the awareness of the IGITAW campaign in a light-hearted and engaging way. The comical viral videos comprised:

  • Naked Tuesdays
  • Recycled Envelopes
  • Water Boy

 View the Channel Ten Environment Award Nominee Video here.

HOW the funding will be spent:

$25,000 will allow us to produce another three cutting-edge, viral campaign videos to help build greater awareness of this global campaign.

$15,000 will provide us with the funding to engage a global marketing company to assist with our press and media strategy.

$10,000 will give us the ability to engage with a social media marketing firm to develop a global social media strategy.

Any surplus funding will be allocated to generating additional awareness of both IGITAW and www.FFITS.ORG over the coming 12 months.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don’t have the ability to provide financial support we can still use your help!

You can:

  • Like us and share our page to your friends on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/greenitweek to help get the word out and make some noise about IGITAW (www.greenitweek.org).
  • You can follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/greenitweek 
  • You can record a video on what you will do during IGITAW to help reduce your personal impact on the environment.
  • You can ask your company to take some time during IGITAW to think about ways to reduce the impact your organisation has on the environment.
  • And of course, register to attend IGITAW http://www.greenitweek.org/index.php/green-it-week/attendee-registration 

Quote from our founder:

“It’s the simple actions that can make a big difference if we collectively commit to reducing our impact on the environment.  I shut down my PC when I go to lunch and when I leave the office.  I shut down my home PC when I’m finished using it.  It’s such a simple action but makes such a big difference”.

Mark Winter
Founder and Board Member
The Foundation for IT Sustainability
story_txt:
Short Summary
The Foundation for IT Sustainability (FFITS.ORG) is a global, non-profit organisation established in 2008 whose mission is to engage with, and educate individuals, government and corporations on the environmental footprint of technology, as well as promote the sustainable use of technology to help solve environmental problems.
Our largest awareness campaign was launched in 2010 and has fast become the world’s largest Virtual Green IT event: International Green IT Awareness Week (IGITAW) in 2010.
IGITAW (www.greenitweek.org) runs from the 1 - 7 June each year and brings together the global network of Green IT professionals, including thousands of tech journalists, CIOs, CTOs, IT Managers, sustainability professionals, carbon managers and more under one virtual roof. IGITAW comprises of over 30 live and pre-recorded tactical and practical learning sessions, international keynotes, Q&A panels and more.
During this week our panel of leading international speakers will present a series of engaging, pragmatic and thought-provoking conference-style presentations. The aim of the presentations will be to equip attendees with a range of skills and the knowledge necessary to take action on Green IT, however big or small.
As a 24 hour global virtual conference, attendees of IGITAW can learn from the world’s leading Green IT experts, network, chat directly with other attendees, speakers and sponsors in the comfort of their own home or office.
The week of education and action was developed to encourage individuals and organisations to demand more from themselves and their partners, holding each other to account for our impact on the environment. The initiative also aims to encourage those individuals and organisations to bring together their CIO, IT Directors along with their business managers, CFO and COE’s to start the discussion around what their organisation can do to green their IT infrastructure.
What We Need
To assist with building the awareness of IGITAW we need your financial support to help us reach more individuals and organisations across the globe through the development of educational and motivational multimedia campaigns (similar to ‘Our Vision’ video above), social media initiatives, advertidsing campaigns and global press engagement.  FFITS.ORG relies on generous financial supporters to continue our important work in building awareness of Green IT issues, and with your help we can continue to spread the message across the globe and to remain the largest Green IT conference in the world!
The Impact

Our particular type of social media marketing will also provide us with the potential to go viral quickly.
When we launched IGITAW in 2010, with the generous backing of our financial supporters, we produced three Green IT themed viral videos to assist with raising the awareness of the IGITAW campaign in a light-hearted and engaging way. The comical viral videos comprised:

Naked Tuesdays
Recycled Envelopes
Water Boy

HOW the funding will be spent:
$25,000 will allow us to produce another three cutting-edge, viral campaign videos to help build greater awareness of this global campaign.
$15,000 will provide us with the funding to engage a global marketing company to assist with our press and media strategy.
$10,000 will give us the ability to engage with a social media marketing firm to develop a global social media strategy.
Any surplus funding will be allocated to generating additional awareness of both IGITAW and www.FFITS.ORG over the coming 12 months.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you don’t have the ability to provide financial support we can still use your help!
You can:

Like us and share our page to your friends on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/greenitweek to help get the word out and make some noise about IGITAW (www.greenitweek.org).
You can follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/greenitweek 
You can record a video on what you will do during IGITAW to help reduce your personal impact on the environment.
You can ask your company to take some time during IGITAW to think about ways to reduce the impact your organisation has on the environment.
And of course, register to attend IGITAW http://www.greenitweek.org/index.php/green-it-week/attendee-registration

“It’s the simple actions that can make a big difference if we collectively commit to reducing our impact on the environment.  I shut down my PC when I go to lunch and when I leave the office.  I shut down my home PC when I’m finished using it.  It’s such a simple action but makes such a big difference”.Mark Winter Founder and Board Member The Foundation for IT Sustainability

story:
Welcome!

Thank you for stopping by, and for taking an interest in our dream!  This project is the brainchild of wayward explorers, passionate educators, writers, and photographers who have traveled 15,000 kilometers by human-power across three continents, and now need your help to put the last and largest piece of an around-the-world journey into place.

Take a look around, head over to the website, and, if you can, take a minute to offer your support.

Please, whether or not you can spare a few dollars to help us make it to the Pacific, share this page on Facebook, Twitter, and by e-mail.  Text your friends.  E-mail your dentist.  Tell... everybody.  Spread the fire, and you can help make our dream a reality!

Zand & Bria

 

The Project

Our route begins in central Mongolia, on the edge of the vast endorheic basin of Central Asia, where rivers disappear into deserts and dying seas. We will travel by canoe through the canyons of the Chuluut into the rushing waters of the Ider, to the major flow of the Selenge, to Baikal, the biggest lake by volume on Earth. From there, we will move into the Amur watershed, moving east towards the Sea of Okhotsk. Human-powered expedition travel is our means, canoes are our craft, and our goal is to move across the land in the best style possible, gathering stories as we go to share with those unable to visit this last, best place, and perhaps inspire them to further river conservation there and at home.

We will travel by canoe through a landscape of superlatives: towering peaks, endless steppe, the largest forest and largest lake on Earth, through whitewater canyons and past peaceful wooden villages set on crumbling riverbanks.  It'll take four months of constant human-powered travel to make the route, but that is just the start of our journey.

The Bigger Picture

We want to tell stories.  We want to tell the story of this journey to lend an inspiring voice to conservation and education efforts, and we want to tell it in as many different forms as possible.  Young people need stories to inspire them to think about natural resources, and to move from in front of the screen to the out-of-doors.  The world's rivers - "...the chords that bind the world together." - are in danger today as never before.  Energy exploration, climate change, hydroelectic development, antiquated management practices, and population growth all threaten these key resources; we know in our hearts that an untamed and undeveloped river flowing through wilderness holds incredible power, and is worth exploring, and worth protecting.

The distant watersheds this expedition will traverse and the high style this team plans to  use helps set this journey apart.  While the Asia River Expedition stands alone, it does continue a theme first set out four years ago when Zand Martin set off from Portland, OR to paddle across North America.  Since then, he has moved east 15,000 kilometers across three continents, and if successful, this project will bring him back to where he began: the Pacific Ocean.  

 

The Team

Zand Martin

A native of New England, Zand Martin is an educator, writer, and explorer.  He paddled across North America solo at age 22, and Europe at age 25.  He is a senior faculty member at the National Outdoor Leadership School, and is most alive teaching or writing on the banks of wild rivers surrounded by conifers.  Full bio

 

Bria Schurke

A native of northern Minnesota, Bria Schurke is an avid outdoors woman, traveler, and humanitarian. If she's not out nordic skiing or climbing or playing with sled dogs, you might find her attempting to play the fiddle or keep herself from lighiting on fire while spinning poi.  She'll be joining the expedition in Mongolia after volunteering in Somalia and mountaineering in Nepal.

Her first trip to Siberia was at age four. Full bio

 

Our Needs

We are seeking $11,000 in funding to cover the substantial costs of executing an international expedition.  The vaccines we need cost $1900 alone, not to mention flights, visas, gear, food, and communication technology.  Anything you can give is much appreciated, and rewarded with lots of cool stuff!

 

With the generous support of the Polartec Challenge Grant, our fundraising got off to a great start.  But it can't end there.  The team will be paying for one-third of the cost of the trip, with the rest made up by individual donations.  About 9-10% of the cost will be in gear, which we hope to have donated by reputable outdoor companies.   

 

Thank You!

Thank you for taking an interest, and for supporting a spirit of adventure and exploration!  Even the smallest contribution makes us feel loved and supported, and gives you a stake in our success.  Stay tuned here and on the website for more details as the trip gets closer!

 

Expedition Website
