Expedition Website

story:
CHANGE OF PERKS: TO SHOW MY GRATITUDE EVERY DONOR WILL GET THEIR NAME ON THE TUK TUK! 

 

An exploration of the environmental and cultural  impacts of a global world on Central and South America, in a tuk tuk.

The Idea

In terms of both cultural and biological diversity, Central and South America are at the top of the list.  However, these amazing people and the beautiful places are under threat.  We've all seen the headlines - deforestation for cattle, indigenous communities threatened, rivers polluted and running dry.   But we never get to see the full stories.  

I want to tell the 'what happened nexts?' and the stories of the people, communities and projects seeking to protect and improve the natural environment.  I will be capturing images and creating short documentaries to tell these tales. 

I have been volunteering in Guatemala working with rural farmers for the last three months, learning about their lives, hardships and opportunities.  I want to continue hearing these stories and telling them to the world to raise awareness, and hope!

The Vehicle

It would be very easy to travel in a four-wheeled, air conditioned bubble, a nice reliable, weather proof vehicle.  One with space for luggage and maybe even a bed.  But this bubble wouldn’t leave much opportunity for interaction with the landscape and their people. 

I am forgoing the comfort of the aforementioned bubble in favor of something a bit more open.  I am trading in one of the wheels and the luggage room for space for a couple of passengers.   I am swapping the weather-proofness and security of doors and a solid roof in favor of the chance to connect with more people.  And I am swapping the air conditioning and powerful engine for a 8.5 bhp 0.17 l engine. I will be travelling by tuk tuk, a slow and ridiculous vehicle.  

The Driver/Story Teller


That'll be me (the one with glasses in the photo).  I am Matthew Harris.  I am a conservationist and soil scientist by training and photographer and videographer by passion.  I have a keen interest in environmental sustainability and the part food production plays in this.  I am currently based in Guatemala volunteering with Semilla Nueva, a sustainable agriculture NGO.  You can check out some of my work about their work here, here and here. 

Working with Semila Nueva has given me a glimpse of some of the issues that are felt by small scale-farmers in Guatemala and no doubt echoed around the world.  I am eager to find out more about where food comes from, and explore what farming and the environment mean to different people. 

The Route

I want to keep this project focused on the journey rather than the destination so my route is not going to be set in stone.  I know that I want to go South(ish), and I will stay of the Pan American Highway as much as possible.  Inevitable, I am going to get lost and I am going to be detouring all over the place in order to tell interesting and inspiring stories of people making a difference to farming and the environment. 

If you're considering choosing someone for me to serenade from my tuk tuk, or suggesting a place to visit, please stick to Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicoragua, Costa Rica, Panama, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Paraguy, Chilie or Argentina as these are coutries I'll feasably (or maybe infeasably, considering the vehicle) be able to get to.  

The Impact

Central and South America are among the most cultural and environmentally places on the planet.  However, it is under threat on a range of fronts - Global warming threatens both the crops of small farmer well as the balance of unique ecosystems.  Unfair land distribution endangers the lively hoods of local people and leads to previously untouched areas to be turned over to agriculture, the list continues.

However, there are also infinite untold positive stories of environmental protection and stewardship.  It is so important for these stories to be told.  For the people involved, knowing that people are interested, that people care about their plight is such an important thing and will help people carry on the good they are doing.  Add to this the awareness that will be raised back where you guys are from, the potential for exerting political and social pressure to bring positive changes is real and enormous too.  

How Your Money Will be Spent:

First off, I'm going to need a tuk tuk

The tuk tuk will need a few modifications.  I’m going to add a roof rack and some extra storage so I have room for passengers along the way.  

I will also add a sound system (a little more reserved than that illustration suggests however!) to keep me bopping/along the way.  

As fuel efficient as tuk tuks are, they still need fuel.

Perhaps the biggest obstacle on this route will be getting round the Darien Gap.  This is the 70 mile stretch between Panama and Columbia where there’s no road.  Instead, there’s thick jungle, guerrilla fighters and drug runners!   The tuk tuk and I will need to get on a boat and sail from to South America.

What you get in return 

I will be creating a series of photo stories and short videos telling the tales of the people I meet along the way and the places I visit.  So in addition to the perks, you will get to watch and learn about the lives of all sorts of folk in Central and South America. 

I am turning to the crowd sourcing community for help funding this project as I would much rather have a tuk tuk adorned with your motifs and messages rather than those of corporate sponsors.  Although, if there are any like minded businesses that are interested in supporting me I would love to hear from you.

Another way of thinking about your donations:

A tuk tuk does about 60 mpg (or 25 km per l or 100 km per gallon or 4 l per 100 km) at about 20 mph.  So, with the price of petrol at about $5 a gallon in Central and South America.  Every $10 donation will see me fuelled for nearly 7 hours of driving! And even going 25 mph in my tuk tuk, that’ll still get me 175 miles! 

That’s like, from New York to Baltimore.  Or Los Angeles to Mexico. Or Bristol to Snowdonia.  Or from the Caribbean Sea to the Pacific Ocean in Costa Rica.  For $10!  Now that’s value for generosity! 

Perks

My goal is to have a tuk tuk covered in all of your lovely names rather than the stickers of a couple of big sponsers so everyone who donates $25 (thats a mere £16.50 for my british compatriots) or more will have their name painted on the tuk tuk.  And whenever your name is in a picture on facebook, I'll do my best to tag you.  

 

I've put the delivery date as the very latest date they could posibly be, you can expect your perks much sooner, I just don't want to dissapoint!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don’t want to donate with money I’d love it if you could donate nice words on the comments up the top and with like/shares on/of the facebook page.  The more popular Indiegogo think we are, the more likely we’ll make the front page and cool things like that. 

If you're a music maker, I'd love to here from you - every good story needs good music!

Thank you thank you thank you!

story:
J'apprends en jardinant!

Craque-Bitume est un collectif en écologie urbaine dont la mission est de développer et promouvoir des actions écoresponsables favorisant l’engagement citoyen et l’adoption d’un mode de vie durable. L'organisme oeuvre dans trois volets différents: le compostage urbain, l'agriculture urbaine et la formation écocitoyenne.

L'organisme est présentement en train de mettre sur pied un programme de démarrage de jardin pédagogique dans les établissements scolaires du Québec : aide à la planification, fabrication du matériel, ateliers pédagogiques, entretien du jardin et service-conseil sont au menu! En 2013, Craque-Bitume souhaite assister l'École St-Fidèle, une école de niveau primaire située à Limoilou, un quartier de la basse-ville de Québec, à développer son propre projet de jardin pédagogique.

Mais pourquoi jardiner dans les cours d'école? Celles-ci sont bien souvent de tristes îlots d'asphalte sans verdure ce qui augmente considérablement la chaleur ambiante. En sachant que les enfants sont une population particulièrement vulnérable aux effets de la chaleur, on devine que les récréations n'ont pas le même attrait pour tous les jeunes! Or, non seulement un jardin permet-il de verdir la cour d'école et ainsi de pallier l'effet d'îlot de chaleur, mais il est aussi un vecteur de sensibilisation, et ce, sur une foule de sujets comme l'importance d'une bonne alimentation, la biodiversité et la gestion de nos ressources naturelles. Il est donc l'outil idéal pour amener les jeunes à s'approprier leur milieu dans le respect de l'environnement!

 

À quoi servira votre don?

L'an dernier, c'est un jardin pédagogique de 16 bacs qui a été installé en façade de l'école. Cette année, nous aimerions équiper l'école d'une étagère à semis et d'outils de jardinage, doubler le nombre de bacs et évaluer la possibilité d'installer des bacs permanents dans la cour d'école. Notre objectif est d'aller donner cinq à sept ateliers dans la classe de 5e année pour initier les jeunes au jardinage et à la saine alimentation. 

Votre contribution nous permettrait de faire tout cela en plus de consolider un projet porteur pour l'ensemble de la Ville! De plus, cela vous donnerait accès à des prix spéciaux offerts par Craque-Bitume comme un ensemble de fabrication de balles de semences, une belle activité de jardinage à réaliser en famille, des boucles d'oreille faits à partir de haricots, une vermicompostière ou même une pièce de théâtre portant sur la gestion des matières résiduelles pour l'école de votre choix!

Dans le cas où nous n'atteindrions pas 100% de notre objectif de financement, nous devrions revoir nos ambitions à la baisse, mais le projet tiendra toujours. Nous devrons par exemple réduire le nombre de bacs fabriqués.

 

Pour un milieu de vie plus beau et plus sain!

Aidez-nous à faire de l'École St-Fidèle une école verte et jardinée afin d'améliorer le cadre de vie des élèves ainsi que celui des résidents environnant. Cette école pourrait ainsi devenir un modèle exemplaire inspirant pour les autres écoles de la ville qui souhaitent se lancer dans le verdissement de leur cour d'école. Elle serait la preuve de l'intérêt que porte les citoyens à voir ses enfants grandir en santé et en tant que jeunes responsables et engagés!

N'HÉSITEZ PLUS: SEMEZ UNE GRAINE EN CONTRIBUANT AU PROJET ET FAITES-LE CONNAÎTRE DANS VOS RÉSEAUX!
story_txt:
J'apprends en jardinant!
Craque-Bitume est un collectif en écologie urbaine dont la mission est de développer et promouvoir des actions écoresponsables favorisant l’engagement citoyen et l’adoption d’un mode de vie durable. L'organisme oeuvre dans trois volets différents: le compostage urbain, l'agriculture urbaine et la formation écocitoyenne.
L'organisme est présentement en train de mettre sur pied un programme de démarrage de jardin pédagogique dans les établissements scolaires du Québec : aide à la planification, fabrication du matériel, ateliers pédagogiques, entretien du jardin et service-conseil sont au menu! En 2013, Craque-Bitume souhaite assister l'École St-Fidèle, une école de niveau primaire située à Limoilou, un quartier de la basse-ville de Québec, à développer son propre projet de jardin pédagogique.
Mais pourquoi jardiner dans les cours d'école? Celles-ci sont bien souvent de tristes îlots d'asphalte sans verdure ce qui augmente considérablement la chaleur ambiante. En sachant que les enfants sont une population particulièrement vulnérable aux effets de la chaleur, on devine que les récréations n'ont pas le même attrait pour tous les jeunes! Or, non seulement un jardin permet-il de verdir la cour d'école et ainsi de pallier l'effet d'îlot de chaleur, mais il est aussi un vecteur de sensibilisation, et ce, sur une foule de sujets comme l'importance d'une bonne alimentation, la biodiversité et la gestion de nos ressources naturelles. Il est donc l'outil idéal pour amener les jeunes à s'approprier leur milieu dans le respect de l'environnement!
 
À quoi servira votre don?
L'an dernier, c'est un jardin pédagogique de 16 bacs qui a été installé en façade de l'école. Cette année, nous aimerions équiper l'école d'une étagère à semis et d'outils de jardinage, doubler le nombre de bacs et évaluer la possibilité d'installer des bacs permanents dans la cour d'école. Notre objectif est d'aller donner cinq à sept ateliers dans la classe de 5e année pour initier les jeunes au jardinage et à la saine alimentation. 
Votre contribution nous permettrait de faire tout cela en plus de consolider un projet porteur pour l'ensemble de la Ville! De plus, cela vous donnerait accès à des prix spéciaux offerts par Craque-Bitume comme un ensemble de fabrication de balles de semences, une belle activité de jardinage à réaliser en famille, des boucles d'oreille faits à partir de haricots, une vermicompostière ou même une pièce de théâtre portant sur la gestion des matières résiduelles pour l'école de votre choix!
Dans le cas où nous n'atteindrions pas 100% de notre objectif de financement, nous devrions revoir nos ambitions à la baisse, mais le projet tiendra toujours. Nous devrons par exemple réduire le nombre de bacs fabriqués.
 
Pour un milieu de vie plus beau et plus sain!
Aidez-nous à faire de l'École St-Fidèle une école verte et jardinée afin d'améliorer le cadre de vie des élèves ainsi que celui des résidents environnant. Cette école pourrait ainsi devenir un modèle exemplaire inspirant pour les autres écoles de la ville qui souhaitent se lancer dans le verdissement de leur cour d'école. Elle serait la preuve de l'intérêt que porte les citoyens à voir ses enfants grandir en santé et en tant que jeunes responsables et engagés!
N'HÉSITEZ PLUS: SEMEZ UNE GRAINE EN CONTRIBUANT AU PROJET ET FAITES-LE CONNAÎTRE DANS VOS RÉSEAUX!

story:
You can help us directly to our paypal account  https://www.paypal.com/cr/cgi-bin/webscr?SESSIO...In the last 25 years we have lost 90% of the leatherback in the ocean, hawksbill and green turtles are in critic conditions. 

I'm Luis Solano,  turtles are my passion and my life.  I have been working with turtles since 2009 and 2 years ago I decided to start with my own turtle conservation project without money, but eager to protect and save them from poachers these defenseless, but amazing animals. 
The project is a very basic house where the volunteers around the world come to help us in this task 
The house here we are living it's in very bad conditions and the place where we are located it's not electricity service,  is the reason because I started this campaign to collect $15 000 and repair the showers, toilets and buy more beds for the volunteers and  a solar panel. 

With your help our dreams to save many turtles will come true.  With the help of the volunteers through this project we have given a job to many locals from this poor community. That people were poachers and now, they are helping us to save turtles. 
Share this campaign and be part of this awesome task.

story:
I'm an Italian 28 years old man. I have a job, but I have a very expensive dream: buying an electric car. I have always been aware of the environment, consumption, CO2 emissions: indeed part of my job consists in dealing LEDs.

I could buy a cheap electric car, but these cars have little autonomy, only useful in the cities and for short ways. My job makes me travel a lot and I couldn’t use a “classic” electric car… so my dream is buying a Tesla, that, at this moment, is the only car with sufficient autonomy and zero emissions.

This car is very beautiful and… very expensive. It's my dream! Some people think I am crazy because I prefer a Tesla to a Ferrari, but I believe we must change our world with little things… and I really want to do my little in order to help the environment, but I need your help!

 I'm here to ask for funds in order to realize my dream.

With your help I could be able to save money and, one day, install solar panels on the roof of my house, so I would be self-sufficient al CO2 neutral… but this is another dream!

Every little help can be useful to realize my dream: I would like to thank everyone, in his little, decides to make my dream come true.

PS: Sorry for my terrible English. I really made my best to write it!

story:
All About ESTC14 and Us!

The Conference

The International Ecotourism and Sustainable Tourism Conference, ESTC14, brings together government, private companies, NGOs and other stakeholders in the tourism industry from all over the world to share best practices and facilitate opportunities for collaboration to support positive and effective changes in tourism for development and conservation. 

The Panelists

We are four graduate students from the Monterey Institute of International Studies in Monterey, California. We also founded the project “Sustainable Tourism as a mechanism to preserve the ecological and cultural heritage of Minca, Colombia” as a collaborative effort with an NGO from Minca, Colombia, Mision Gaia. The project was conceived almost a year ago, and after months of hard work, we spent three weeks in Colombia executing our project, getting to know the everyday challenges of tourism development and building lifelong relationships. 

 We were selected by the International Ecotourism Society to present at ESTC14-- and we are ready and honored to share our motivating story in Bonito with our international colleagues. The opportunity for us to share our experiences by presenting at ESTC14 is not only important for our own professional development and future careers; we believe that it represents a critical moment for us to bolster the momentum of ecotourism and sustainable tourism for development that is creative and strategic.

As we are all in still in graduate school, financial constraints are a constant burden. we refuse to let that prevent us from pursuing opportunities that could potentially be life-changing--and that is why we are asking for your help. Between the conference fees, flights and accommodations for our trip to Bonito, our conservative cost estimate is $2,200 per person. We are asking you to help us cover those costs so that we can contribute to the advancement of effective sustainable tourism and ecotourism worldwide. 

Our Request

We started this campaign to ask you to make a donation to our group of panelists to speak at ESTC14 this year. Our funding is strictly for flights, our hostel, and traveling expenses. Here is the cost estimate breakdown per person: 
Flights-                        $1400 
Bus/ground travel-        $165
Conference Fee-          $300
Hotel-                            $240
Total-                          $2105


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can always help us out by making some noise! Use your social media prowess to help us get to Brazil-- a quick share on Facebook, through email or a retweet could make all the difference for our campaign! 

That is all there is to it-- thanks a million!

story:
We Did It!  The Localize This! Great Lakes Basin Action Camp was a huge success, and...  

WE DID NOT TURN ANYONE AWAY FOR LACK OF FUNDS - AND - we assisted with travel.  The result of that is that Backbone Campaign is short $6,000 for this effort and we need your help to make sure we can keep providing these movement building opportunities in the future.

Camp was AMAZING!  We replicated our Pacific NW Localize This! Action Camp model and produced an extremely successful week long training camp in the Great Lakes Basin.  Sixty activists, organizers and trainers worked intensely together to share skills, develop common practices, and evolve a shared lexicon for harmonizing the work of change agents working in many environmental and economic justice movements. 

These front line activists took time away from work, family, and the causes that they work on passionately to deepen their capacity and broaden their alliances. We closed with a strategic and timely action at the Michigan Capitol in Lansing to expose a corporate sponsored trojan horse bill to redefine industrial waste (including petroleum coke from tar sands oil) as a renewable energy! 

But these camps do not NOT pay for themselves.  We need YOU to pitch in to make sure Backbone Campaign & Circle Pines Center can do this again next year.   THANK YOU!

Article about Camp in EcoWatch HERE 
MORE Photos from Camp HERE
More about what was offered at camp below these photos.






The skills, workshops, panels included:

  • Grand Strategy for Building Movement Power
  • Nonviolent Direct Action 101
  • Deescalation training by Meta Peace Center
  • Beginning and Intermediate Climb Skills
  • Blockades training that spanned soft to hard blockades and even a tripod training
  • Water safety and kayak skills for water actions
  • Theater of the Oppressed based process for imagery design
  • Puppet and imagery creation
  • Flash mob design
  • Media and Messaging skills
  • Know Your Rights training
  • Panel on jail solidarity, prisoner support, and lessons from engaging in arrestable action
  • Light Projection as Protest
  • Giant Banner Building
  • Action Planning, Scouting and Internal Media
  • Co-op history and organizing
  • Relational organizing and the one-on-one organizing conversation
  • And also we had a couple blocks of time for participant offerings

Here are some of the practices we engaged in at Camp:

  • We began camp with an intensive (Fantastic) Anti-Oppression training by the Chicago Freedom School.
  • We modeled respect for First Peoples by engaging with local tribe and were ceremonially welcomed and our actions blessed on the first dinner by drumming, song, and smudge by local tribal leader. 
  • This was complimented by a recognition ceremony at the end of camp for 4 women who had spent a month in jail for their blockade of Enbridge Pipeline.  They were given feathers by another local tribal leader. 
  • The food that was served was organic and locally sourced and we ate family style with musical offerings before each meal.
  • Every day's activities began and ended with a community circle. 
  • Every night there was at least one camp fire for people to gather at and decompress. 
  • After the final action, debrief and return to camp, we held a final dinner and camp closing circle, followed by a music and dance filled party.  

About Backbone Campaign & Circle Pines Center:

Backbone Campaign has been criss-crossing the country for over 10 years doing progressive movement building work by inspiring and amplifying citizen engagement.

Backbone Campaign is known for their use of creative imagery and spectacle, innovative messaging, and political theater. Most of their work involves Artful Activism, in which they engage progressive activists and organizers in the strategic use of creative tactics such as festival arts, flash mobs, music and other theatrical forms of nonviolent direct action to make our shared values visible, earn media attention, and build power. Backbone Campaign offers workshops, trainings, consultation, and action support.

Circle Pines Center is partnering with Backbone to host Localize This! Great Lakes Basin Action Camp. Circle Pines has a rich history as a regional hub for movement building, cooperative education and culture, community building and more. It has existed as a folk school, a farmers co-op. People of different ideologies and religious beliefs are able to find common ground and work together for their mutual benefit in a non-judgmental environment where the dignity and worth of each individual is respected and valued.

story:
Who are we?

Hi, we are a small group of students studying conservation at the Rural College in Ayr. In March we set up a student society to enable us to carry out practical work for local organisations, develop projects to enhance the biodiversity of our campus and gain practical skills which we can then pass on to others.

The members of our group all have different backgrounds and experiences but we all share a passion for the outdoors and want to work to help our environment deal with the pressure that modern life is putting on it.

In donating to our cause you will be helping to the improve green urban spaces such as the college's riverside campus, local country parks and nature reserves; all of which are vital to the health and well-being of their surrounding communities.

As we will be donating half of what we raise to the John Muir Trust you will also be contributing to the protection of areas of wild land that are vulnerable to  development.  It seems fitting that we have chosen to walk our challenge along the new John Muir Way, a new long distance trail that opened just this year in honour of the Scot who inspired the creation of our national parks.

http://www.jmt.org/


    What We Need and Why

    In order for us to plant trees to replace out lost woodlands, remove invasive plants from our river banks, improve the paths on our much loved mountains, pick up litter from our beautiful beaches, carry out surveys in our local parks to see where bats are roosting and many more tasks we need to be able to pay for;

    -  insurance so that we can work on our own.
    -  first aid training so that we are safe when working in remote areas.
    - equipment and supplies to create a wildlife garden on our campus to improve the habitats for urban species.
    -  transport to get us to out-of-reach places.


    What We Are Doing

    Starting at 9am on Sat 6th of September we are walking from Helensburgh to Falkirk, all 50 miles within 24 hours.

    No sleeping, no hitch hiking, no lying under the trees if it all gets too much!



    Risks & Challenges

    Instead of just asking for money we want to prove our commitment to the cause by doing something that will test our resolve. Walking for 24 hours straight is not an easy undertaking and we are going to need good camaraderie, a great deal of stamina and lots of sandwiches to get to the finish line!

    We have training plan and with 7 weeks to go we are on the way to getting fit and ready for our challenge.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    We hope that you can contribute but if you can't all we ask is that you please share this page with your family and friends. Any donation will be gratefully received and put good use!

    Also please check out our facebook page. You'll be able to see what we've been up to so far and our plans for the future.

story:
Short Summary

A soul searching trip from the south of Portugal to the Austrian Alps: this is the story of my great escape.

I am João Saraiva, a 38 year old biologist living in Portugal and passionate about traveling. I decided to let go of the daily routine and search for the essence of life above freezing level. Destination: the snowy peaks of the Alps of Tirol, Austria. This is my discovery of the The Perfect Winter.

Leaving Faro (southern Portugal) in early January, this road trip will cross the two great mountain ranges of Europe (the Pyrenees and the Alps) heading towards Gerlos, a small village at 1300m high, nested in the Ziller Valley deep in Tirol. This will be the base for my discovery of the hidden gems, the highest peaks and the best slopes of the Austrian Alps throughout the winter. The snow, the Nature, the people, the food and life in the high mountains off the beaten track, all of this will be experienced and documented first-hand through the blog theperfectwinter.org, on the Sul Informação Portuguese newspaper and through our facebook. A weekly radio show will be aired on RUA FM - Rádio Universitária do Algarve 102.7 - and podcasted at RUA FM's website so you don't miss one minute of this adventure! Check out the recent interview explaining the project and the official presentation video.

What Is Needed

Funding will be needed for three main purposes:

The road trip

Winter tyres, snow chains and general car preparation for the winter are mandatory for a safe journey. The sunny south of Portugal is blessed with mild winters, but the roads of the Pyrenees and the Alps are a whole different story. These preparations for the van will amount to 400€.

Fuel and toll costs to cover the circa 6.000 km roundtrip from Faro to Gerlos (crossing Spain, France and Switzerland until Austria) and the exploratory travels throughout Tirol in 3 months that can sum 1.000 km will amount to 800€.

The riding and exploration

The pass for mechanical lifts to access the Tirolean summits and slopes costs 737€. A standard insurance for mountain sports for the duration of the trip costs 160€. Avalanche transceiver, probe, shovel and other general snow safety gear will amount to 400€

The lodging

The housing and related costs for the 3 months of The Perfect Winter in Gerlos will amount to 1000€.

All other technical gear, cameras, protection, etc, are already present. So in the end the magic number is... 3500€!!!

Trouble contributing? Issues with your credit card?

Drop me a line and we'll figure it out: theperfectwinter [at] gmail.com


What You Get

This trip will deliver a traveller's point of view on the magic of the Tirolean mountains. The objective is to stay off the beaten path and discover the essence of Alpine life. A dedicated blog and facebook page (in english and Portuguese) will document every step of the trip. Weekly chronicles, on topics ranging from snowboarding to food, from nature to nightlife, will be published in Sul Informação newspaper and will be aired weekly at RUA FM 102.7, and stored in a podcast if you couldn't catch it live.

Contributors will receive exclusive materials, not for sale anywhere else (depending on your contribution, see the perks section for details):

Malaca red wine

The Perfect Winter exclusive hoodie


The Perfect Winter exclusive t-shirt


The Impact

The internet is riddled with superficial remarks on immensely rich places. The Perfect Winter, on the other hand, is all about true discovery, exploration and experience. 

I have been writing about nature for most of my professional life, and in recent years I started to create radio shows following snowtrips around the Alps. With this experience I am more than ready to tackle this new challenge.

The Perfect Winter will be an excellent independent cross-platform travel journal - let's make it happen!

Risks & Challenges

When making such an ambitious project, especially one that involves the natural environment, several challenges arise. Being honest and up-front with you, who will make this possible, is the best way to overcome them.

Unfavorable weather

Maybe there is too much snow and moving around is impossible. Maybe there is too little snow and the landscape is uncharacteristic. You know what? That is actually part of the charm! The postcard-like scenery we have been fed by mainstream media as being there all the time is not true, and we know it. There is fog. There is rain. There are big, scary, grey clouds. All of these as beautiful as sparkling blue skies! The essence of the beautiful Alps lies beyond one-color photographs. 

Uncharted territory

That is actually what this project is all about! Forget the big resorts, hordes of tourists, never mind the highways and the big parking lots. With local knowledge, the hidden gems with be documented and treated with the respect they deserve. Magic forests, impressive ridges, untouched slopes, real people - that's what the Perfect Winter feeds on.

The language issue

Sprechen sie Deutsch? Ja, naturlich! Preparing for this trip, I went through an introductory course of German language. Not perfect, but I am a fast learner!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask friends to get the word out and make some noise about The Perfect Winter.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Ready to hit the high road?
story_txt:
Short Summary 
A soul searching trip from the south of Portugal to the Austrian Alps: this is the story of my great escape.
I am João Saraiva, a 38 year old biologist living in Portugal and passionate about traveling. I decided to let go of the daily routine and search for the essence of life above freezing level. Destination: the snowy peaks of the Alps of Tirol, Austria. This is my discovery of the The Perfect Winter.
Leaving Faro (southern Portugal) in early January, this road trip will cross the two great mountain ranges of Europe (the Pyrenees and the Alps) heading towards Gerlos, a small village at 1300m high, nested in the Ziller Valley deep in Tirol. This will be the base for my discovery of the hidden gems, the highest peaks and the best slopes of the Austrian Alps throughout the winter. The snow, the Nature, the people, the food and life in the high mountains off the beaten track, all of this will be experienced and documented first-hand through the blog theperfectwinter.org, on the Sul Informação Portuguese newspaper and through our facebook. A weekly radio show will be aired on RUA FM - Rádio Universitária do Algarve 102.7 - and podcasted at RUA FM's website so you don't miss one minute of this adventure! Check out the recent interview explaining the project and the official presentation video.
   What Is Needed Funding will be needed for three main purposes:
The road trip
Winter tyres, snow chains and general car preparation for the winter are mandatory for a safe journey. The sunny south of Portugal is blessed with mild winters, but the roads of the Pyrenees and the Alps are a whole different story. These preparations for the van will amount to 400€.
Fuel and toll costs to cover the circa 6.000 km roundtrip from Faro to Gerlos (crossing Spain, France and Switzerland until Austria) and the exploratory travels throughout Tirol in 3 months that can sum 1.000 km will amount to 800€.
The riding and exploration
The pass for mechanical lifts to access the Tirolean summits and slopes costs 737€. A standard insurance for mountain sports for the duration of the trip costs 160€. Avalanche transceiver, probe, shovel and other general snow safety gear will amount to 400€
The lodging
The housing and related costs for the 3 months of The Perfect Winter in Gerlos will amount to 1000€.
All other technical gear, cameras, protection, etc, are already present. So in the end the magic number is... 3500€!!!

story:
What Is That? 

Green Feet is a mobile bicycle garden that is designed to educate and engage.  It will be built and operated in Chicago (for now!).  Green Feet will be ridden across town to schools and local community events in order to educate kids and communities on the benefits and ease of organic gardening, as well as on the complexities and importance of ecosystems.


Green Feet is going to be built on the back of a bicycle and will include a small compost bin, organic edibles, and an aquaponic set up [aquaponics is a type of gardening that incorporates the mutually beneficial relationships (or symbiotic relationships) that are present between fish and plants.]  Green Feet will be a fully functional garden and interactive classroom.  It will provide a place where kids can get their hands dirty learning about ecosystems from the plant life cycle to the living organisms that make soil.  Green Feet will also function as a community platform where we can host seed giveaways and bring-your-own-compost parties.  It is designed to be interactive and educational, with the operating mission of getting more people educated about the environment that surrounds us.


What Does Your Money Do?

100% of donations will go toward buying the materials needed for building this mobile garden.  Green Feet will be a top to bottom eco-friendly project, (or as much as I can make it).  Which means that I will primarily try to reuse / repurpose materials and buy Eco-friendly products.  I will also take great efforts to transport materials using only bike, public transportation, or another environmentally sound means of movement.


Items to buy include:

  • soil
  • seeds
  • bike trailer
  • recycled wood
  • burlap
  • nails
  • plants
  • tools to build
  • bike maintence
  • rear bike rack
  • bins


Why Donate? 

Donate to help bring an educational  hands on environmental experience to urban kids and the Chicago community in general ! This project is going to be built and run by one lovely lady (me) but I cannot finance it all by myself!  Green Feet is addressing a global issue: Global Warming.  If we are serious about changing our relationship with the environment, first we need to know the environment we have been so cut off from.  We are facing a huge environmental crisis of food and water shortages. I believe that projects like this one, where community engagement and education are emphasized, will go a long way to help shape a future where we are no longer trapped between the conscientious consumer and the corporation.  This is a grassroots campaign dedicated to community involvement and education. 


Who Am I?

Hello potential internet friends! My name is Mey Lee. I was born and raised in San Francisco before moving to Chicago four years ago to attend college.  I am a now a graduating senior at Shimer College.  This project is a part of my Senior Thesis, a graduation requirement that allows students to choose a topic of their own and conduct an in-depth inquiry. My actual Thesis topic is EcoFeminism, and I have chosen to physically engage with my topic by building a small, educational mobile garden!


I have several years of experience working with kids and designing educational plans.  Including, but not limited to, being a Girl Scout Leader in a local troop, running and designing programming for several summer camps and working as an Explainer at the Exploratorium (an innovative and interactive art and science museum in San Francisco).  I have been invested in environmental restoration for years, working as an Intern at International Bird Rescue and helping to build and begin my high school’s garden.

Building Green Feet will hopefully be just a step in a longer journey of education and environmental engagement.  

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you have no money, but would still like to help please SHARE my campaign! Actually if you have money, but would like to help beyond donations please SHARE this page! If you don't want to help but are really bored, also SHARE! in effect, I would love it if everyone reading this could link this page to any and all listeners! The more people who know about it, the more people can help!  

 If you are in the Chicago area and want to help out with build days, please hit me up! Alternatively, if you have an organization in mind that you think would get along well with Green Feet please let me know who they are! 


Thank You!

story:
Our Story

My name is Stephen Granger and I am trying to transform the way people commute! Introducing the one-person commuter vehicle, CV1. The Granger Motor Sports CV1 is uniquely designed to eliminate the wasted space and expense of a conventional commuter car or SUV. This technologically advanced, environmentally friendly vehicle will dramatically limit damaging emissions and traffic congestion! And best of all…reduce the overall costs of commuter transportation! I am trying to get the prototype build to unveil at the Austin Auto in May of 2012.


The Impact

My dream began several years ago. I was driving home from work…the same 10 mile route I took every day…and noticed that every car on the road around me only had 1 person in it! There had to be a better way! We are all doing this every day! We lug an empty car with us to and from work. What a waste…not to mention what this is doing to our environment! The CV1 Is designed to reduce congestion and be environmentally conscious! I have talked with lots of venture capitalists and angel investors. Everyone says the same thing; “Brilliant idea…BUT I need to see a prototype!” This is where you can help! This effort is to raise the $30,000 needed to build and promote a prototype.


What We Need & What You Get

This money will go to complete the CV1 prototype. The following is the break down of where that $30,000 will be going: *Motor Cycle $4,000 *Company that Builds Race Cars to build Vehicle Components $20,000 *Wheels / Tires $500 *Paint / Body Work $2,000 *Interior $2,000 *Misc.(cost over runs) $1,500


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about the CV1. Go to http://www.grangermotorsports.com and send people you know there so they can see the idea and spread the word.


This is my second attempt to raise the funds needed to build the prototype. So in this season of thanksgiving AND GIVING I am thankful for the vision I have been given and ask you to think about giving. I thank you for reading about my vision and being part of my journey

Love and Light, Tania and family.

story:
Patagonica Vol. 7, 2015

Parties4Peace, in collaboration with Peace Boat and CODEFF Chile will be embarking on its seventh journey to Patagonia to raise awareness about environmental sustainability and conservation in the region. The Patagonica tour brings together international youth and local artists in Santiago, Valparaiso, Concepcion, Punta Arenas and Puerto Natales to hold music events raising money and campaigning for the recognition of Patagonia as a protected World Heritage Site by UNESCO. 

We need your help to make this edition of the Patagonica Tour a success. On our past editions we have personally aided reforestation efforts, collected thousands of signatures encouraging the Chilean government to protect the nature of Patagonia, and brought international artists to experience the wonders of the southern region of Chile first-hand in order to spread the message of its unique importance abroad. Join us in our continued efforts to raise awareness and support  the conservation of the pristine nature in Patagonia!

story:
We are Carol and Andy, we left  Bristol in the U.K. 25 years ago and moved to a small farm in a community called Cigarrones ,in Spain, South of Granada ,with the aim of becoming more self sufficient. We  have learnt how to grow our own food  and medicine, rebuild our  house, use solar panels, solar heaters and firewood for our energy ,keep animals ,deal with our "waste", work together within a community and many more things! We would now like to share our knowledge with anybody who might be interested, and as such are starting week long courses here at Cortijo Vera in successful off-grid living , and herbal medicine, where people will come, relax in the beautiful surroundings, eat delicious food from the farm and learn ...

To make this happen by next spring we need financial support to buy appropriate tents,bedding etc.  and complete the kitchen/teaching space.

We are offering very cheap deals on our upcoming courses for anyone who contributes via this campaign.

For further information on our courses check our website : http://cortijovera.wordpress.com

story:
Are you aware that the world's wildlife populations are half what they were 40 years ago, and within the next 40 years in the U.S. alone it's been projected that future development will result in a loss of 38 million acres (an area the size of Florida) of forest habitat alone?  Are you concerned about our natural world and looking for a way to help fight back these losses and prevent further listing of threatened and endangered species? If so, I urge you to make a donation to The Habitat Institute a nonprofit team of environmentalists, conservationists and scientists dedicated to helping organizations take into consideration all species—not just one or two—potentially affected by development or habitat restoration plans.   

I am Thomas O’Neill, Founder and Director of The Habitat Institute and my life’s work has been devoted to developing a patented process that takes into consideration and quantifies all wildlife so that their needs are represented and valued in aquatic and land acquisition and restoration projects.  The Habitat Institute is a (501(c) (3)) scientific and education  organization that believes promoting biodiversity is key to the sustainability of our lives and planet.  The Institute is unique in its approach in that many land-use planners use 25+ years old methodology that evaluates habitats for only a few animals.  Our approach has been through several independent scientific reviews including a National Academy of Sciences review process.

Previous successes include: 

* Our multi-species approach involving 251 species and our alternative assessment  technique    was used to address sea-level-rise in the San Francisco South Bay;

* Our multi-species approach was the only method capable of assessing the downtown 9 miles stretch of the Los Angeles River.  Our analyses led the Los Angeles City Council to vote unanimously to raise $1 billion for restoration, which would be the largest civil restoration project in U.S. history; and

* Our multi-species approach was used by the state of Oregon to obtain a $150 million settlement to mitigate for 25-year-old wildlife habitat losses caused by construction and operation of federal dams; and

* Our single species approach helped delist the first endangered & threatened fish species in U.S.

Based on the success of these and other projects over the past 18 years, The Habitat Institute is ready to move forward to expand its reach to help other public agencies, tribes, companies and organizations take into account the impact of their land planning on native species populations and their habitat.   We need your financial support to help increase awareness that we live in a multi-species world and each species counts.   Your support can make an immediate and real difference!  

With your donation, we can together focus on significant issues that ultimately can create jobs and a better quality of life for everyone.  Our approach also has the ability to start a whole new industry of appraisals to value nature, help develop and support new markets for carbon and biodiversity trading, and expand our approach to a national system for habitat valuations to be as wide-ranging and complete as possible. 

If you have any questions or would like to discuss this further or want more information, please let us know by contacting habitat@thehabitatinstitute.org.  I hope to hear from you soon, and thank you in advance for your consideration and generosity.

Thomas O'Neill ~ Director

story:
Resumen/ Summary

 

Soy María Mejía, bióloga investigadora y apasionada por los insectos, con maestría en ciencias-entomología en progreso. Desde hace varios años he estado trabajando con insectos en diferentes áreas que van desde el enfoque médico, agrario y biotecnológico.

Actualmente la preocupación por la progresiva desaparición de los polinizadores y su correspondiente consecuencia agraria nos ha incentivado a mi compañero de laboratorio y a mi a trabajar principalmente con abejas nativas para aportar al estudio de ellas y reducir los riesgos de su desaparición. Específicamente en este momento nos queremos centrar en un grupo de síntomas que están presentando algunas colonias de abejas sin aguijón en Colombia y que tiene un alto impacto sobre las poblaciones por las altas tasas de mortalidad. 

---

I´m María Mejía, a biologist researcher and very passionate about insects, finishing my MSc in entomology. Since some years ago, I´ve been working with insects in different areas like medical entomology, crop insects and biotechnology.
Currently the concerns about the gradual disappearance of pollinators and its correspondant agricultural concequence, has encourage my laboratory partner and me to work mainly with native bees to contribute their study and to reduce the risk of their disappearance. Specifically at this time we want to focus on a group of symptoms that are presenting some stingless bee colonies in Colombia and that have a high impact on populations by high mortality rates.


Lo que necesitamos / What we need

 

Nuestro interés es recaudar fondos para que nosotros dos como investigadores podamos permanecer durante un año en Medellín y trasladarnos ocasionalmente a Santander, lugares en donde estaremos realizando las diferentes actividades de la investigación que incluyen:

  • Observar detalladamente el funcionamiento de cada abeja pertenecientes a una colonia para crear un modelo de la estructura de las colmenas de abejas sin aguijón.
  • Identificar en las colonias sanas qué microorganismos se encuentran normalmente conviviendo con estas abejas
  • Evaluar si en las colonias con síntomas existe algún microorganismo diferente o falta alguno de los encontrados en las colonias sana
A partir de estas actividades podremos identificar si el causante de esta enfermedad es un microorganismo  y si no lo es, poder continuar evaluando otras posibilidades.
Lamentablemente lo más difícil de conseguir es dinero para que los investigadores puedan mantenerse a flote durante el período de investigación, pero es una necesidad. Confiamos en que tu nos puedas ayudar. Cada dolar cuenta!!
 -----

Our interest is to raise funds for the two of us as researchers, to stay for a year in Medellin and ocasionally move to Santander, places where we will be conducting various investigative activities including:

  • To observ closely how is the operation of every bee of one colony to build a model of the structure of the beehive of stingless bees
  • Identify healthy colonies which microorganisms are usually living with these bees
  • Assess whether there is in the colonies with symptoms a different organism or missing from those found in healthy colonies
  • From these activities we can identify whether the cause of this disease is a microorganism and if it is not, to continue to evaluate other possibilities.

Unfortunately it is hard to get money for researchers to stay afloat during the investigation period, but it is a necessity. We hope that you can help us. Science is grant-driven, so every dollar counts !!

 

El impacto/ The Impact

 

Encontrar la causa de la enfermedad de estas abejas puede facilitar no solo el salvar las abejas de la zona de estudio, sino también en otros lugares del mundo donde estos síntomas se esten presentando. De esta manera aseguramos que las abejas nativas no desaparezcan y puedan continuar polinizando los cultivos que producen productos para la alimentación del ser humano entre otros. 

También significa que le entregaremos al mundo conocimiento invaluable sobre este tipo de abejas, que, a diferencia de las abejas mieleras, no tiene tantos estudios conocidos.

Es un aporte no solo para la biodiversidad, sino para la crisis alimentaria que se está dando, que será publicado en una revista científica internacional de alto impacto y presentado en un congreso internacional.

---
Finding the cause of the disease of these bees may facilitate not only save bees from the study area, but also in other places in the world where these symptoms are appearing. This way we ensure that native bees do not disappear and can continue pollinating crops that produce food products for human and others. 
It also means that we will give the world invaluable knowledge about this kind of bees, that is not well spread, as the knowledge about honeybees.
It is a contribution not only for biodiversity, but also for the food crisis that is taking place, and that will be published in a high rated international scientific journal, and presented in an international Congress.
 

Riesgos y desafíos/Risks & Challenges

 

En este momento ya tenemos los permisos y convenios tramitados para dar inicio con la investigación en las dos zonas. Lo único que nos dificulta el inicio de la investigación es tener el dinero para los investigadores. 

En cuanto a los resultados, el riesgo es que no encontremos una relación entre los microorganismos de estas abejas y la enfermedad. Esto no es del todo malo, pues es un resultado valioso que nos permitirá acercarnos a la respuesta y a salvar estas especies nativas.

---

All permits and agreements have been processed in order to start our research on both zones.The only inconvenient holding us down is having money to pay the researcher's work.

About the results, the risk would be that we may not find a relation between the bees microorganisms and the desease. This, of course, is not completly bad, since it's a vaulable result that will allow us to come closer to an answer to save this endemic species.

 

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar/Other ways you can help

 

No siempre es fácil aportar dinero, pero puedes ayudar circulando este proyecto para que llegue a más manos que posiblemente nos puedan ayudar. 

I know it isn´t always easy to give money, but you can help us sharing this project to reach more hands that can possibly help.

If you want to reach me, please contact @mejiamaca on Twitter or mariacamila30@gmail.com
story_txt:

Actualmente la preocupación por la progresiva desaparición de los polinizadores y su correspondiente consecuencia agraria nos ha incentivado a mi compañero de laboratorio y a mi a trabajar principalmente con abejas nativas para aportar al estudio de ellas y reducir los riesgos de su desaparición. Específicamente en este momento nos queremos centrar en un grupo de síntomas que están presentando algunas colonias de abejas sin aguijón en Colombia y que tiene un alto impacto sobre las poblaciones por las altas tasas de mortalidad. 
---

story:
Water Crew is an educational project of the Istituto per l’Ambiente e l’Educazione Scholé Futuro (not for profit organization of Turin-Italy), selected by the Foundation Tender to Nave (www.naveitalia.org) for the year 2014.

The Institute wants to offer a unique experience of sustainable tourism, study, participation, exchange, and fun in contact with nature and with educators and trainers with expertise in the socio -educational and water sectors.

With Water Crew the Istituto intends to promote maritime culture and stimulate the interest of a group of young people  (disabled and not) that will be gathered for five days on a ship to share an experience of navigation and exceptional training, through the activation of an original educational approach (Edutainement) which includes water activities, audio-visual interactions with the seabed, creative workshops (e.g. biogeographic and evolutionary history of the Mediterranean, interactions with marine organisms for behavioral analysis, climate change and awareness consumerism, seamanship techniques ) .

Water Crew is part of a training process far more extensive, started by the Istituto  in 2003 with the birth of Blue Planet - Pianeta Azurro, an integrated project that aims to spread environmental education to water resource in schools, among scholars, athletes, in Italy and in the world, through various activities and initiatives.

We believe in alternative forms of learning, able to encourage youth to interact, to be part of a project and contribute to the sustainable development of their daily actions.

The project is structured in three phases that involve alternating moments of analysis and reflection with moments of navigation and water sports in order to make everyone responsible in its relationship with the environment.

The use of snorkeling as an inclusive and open to all practice is a response to the needs of movement, mental and physical wellbeing. Plunged in water the disabled not only can facilitate the passage of emotional flows but they also rediscover a different motor activity which is facilitated by the ability to move with a strong reduction of the weight.

The Institute sees as a priority the need to change the relationship between man and nature, a process by which the role of environmental education becomes crucial as a vehicle to promote the value of diversity, be it biological, cultural, social or disability.

The proposed action aims to develop skills and activities that allow interaction between the participants and the value of people with disabilities, especially as individuals and in relation to the natural environment that surrounds them.

It is more and more evident the need for raising awareness among the younger generation on the sustainable use of resources and on a reorientation of current lifestyles and learning process. This is even more true for people with motor, mental or sensory impairment who are often excluded from the process of growth that fosters the perception, analysis and understanding of the changes.

The navigation is a break with the everyday life and allows the participants to put into practice an educational program aimed at the development of the autonomy and awareness of their abilities.

We are looking for funding to support our work and give youth the possibility to experience an unforgettable educational project. 

The boarding is scheduled for May 13 in Genoa and the disembarkation on May 17 in Livorno.

We invite our members, readers, friends, citizens active in the field of education and/ or environment and all those who believe in the power of non formal education to support our effort.

With this project we want to stimulate, through the sailing, the pleasure to share, learn and create change!If you feel the same please give a contribution to our cause!

Every little counts ...


Thanks for your cooperation !

The staff of the Istituto per l'Ambiente e l'Educazione Scholé Futuro and the Blue Planet

For information about our projects and activities please visit:

www.educazionesostenibile.it/portale/pianeta-azzurro.html

www.educazionesostenibile.it/portale/pianeta-azzurro/iniziative/water-crew.html

www.educazionesostenibile.it/portale/weec-italia.html

www.environmental-education.org

_______________________________________________________________________

Water Crew é un progetto di educazione marina dell'Istituto per l’Ambiente e l’Educazione Scholé Futuro onlus di Torino,  selezionato dalla Fondazione Tender to Nave Italiadi Genova per l’edizione 2014. 

L'Istituto vuole offrire un'esperienza unica di turismo sostenibile, studio, partecipazione, scambio e divertimento a contatto con la natura e con educatori e formatori esperti nel settore acquatico e socio-educativo. 

Con Water Crew Scholé promuove una cultura marinara consapevole stimolando l’interesse di un gruppo di 12-14 ragazzi (normodotati e disabili) che verranno riuniti per cinque giorni a bordo di Nave Italia per condividere un’esperienza di navigazione e formativa eccezionale, tramite l’attivazione di un approccio educativo originale (Edutainement) che comprende attività acquatiche, interazioni audio visive con i fondali marini, laboratori creativi (es. a storia evolutiva e biogeografica del mar mediterraneo, interazioni con organismi marini per analisi comportamentali, cambiamenti climatici e sensibilizzazione al consumo consapevole, tecniche marinaresche).

Water Crew rientra in un processo formativo ben piú ampio, inziato nel 2003 con la nascita di Pianeta Azzurro, un progetto integrato che si propone di diffondere l’educazione ambientale alla risorsa acqua nelle scuole, tra gli studiosi, gli sportivi e gli appassionati, in Italia e nel Mondo, attarverso attività ed iniziative, anche multimediali, tra cui il progetto “Sport e Natura”.

Crediamo in forme di apprendimento alternativo, capaci di incoraggiare i ragazzi ad interagire, a far parte di un progetto, ad aprirsi verso il nuovo e contribuire allo sviluppo sostenibile delle proprie azioni quotidiane e come cittadini.

Il progetto è strutturato in tre fasi che prevedono l'alternanza di momenti di analisi, riflessione con momenti di navigazione e sport acquatici orientati alla responsabilizzazione di ognuno nel suo rapporto con l’ambiente.

Ad esempio l'utilizzo dello snorkeling come pratica inclusiva e aperta a tutti è la risposta appropriata ad esigenze di movimento, di benessere psicofisico. Immersi in acqua i diversamente abili non solo facilitano il passaggio di flussi emotivi ma riscoprono anche una differente attività motoria poiché la deambulazione è agevolata dalla possibilità di muoversi con una forte riduzione del proprio peso.

L’Istituto vede come prioritaria la presa di coscienza della necessità di modificare la relazione uomo-natura, processo per cui il ruolo dell’educazione ambientale diventa fondamentale, poiché veicolo per promuovere il valore della diversitàsia essa biologica, culturale, sociale o disabilità.

L’azione proposta mira a sviluppare competenze e attività che consentano l’interazione tra i partecipanti e la valorizzazione dei disabili, soprattutto come persone e in relazione al contesto naturale che li circonda.

E’ sempre più evidente la necessità di una crescita della consapevolezza nelle nuove generazioni sull’uso sostenibile delle risorse e su un riorientamento degli attuali stili di vita e di apprendimento. Questo è ancora più vero per persone affette da deficit motorio, psichico o sensoriale, spesso escluse da quei processi di crescita che favoriscono la percezione, l’analisi e la comprensione dei cambiamenti, al fine di diventare cittadini consapevoli e responsabili nei confronti di sé, dell’ambiente e della comunità, intesa non solo come società di appartenenza, ma anche come pianeta.

Lanavigazione rappresenta un momento di rottura con la quotidianità e consente di mettere in pratica un programma pedagogico volto allo sviluppo dell'autonomia e della consapevolezza delle proprie capacità.

Siamo alla ricerca di finanziamenti che ci aiutino a realizzare il progetto e che diano la possiblità ai ragazzi di vivere un'esperienza indimenticabile dal punto di vista formativo e personale.

L'imbarco é previsto per il 13 maggio a Genovae lo sbarco il 17 maggio a Livorno. 

Invitiamo i nostri soci, lettori, amici, cittadini attivi nel settore educativo e/o ambientale e tutti coloro che credono nell'educazione non formale e nello sviluppo sociale a supportare il nostro sforzo e a fare una donazione.

Con questo progetto vogliamo suscitare, attraverso la navigazione, il piacere di comprendere, imparare e creare cambiamento!

Every little counts...

Grazie per la collaborazione!

Lo staff dell'Istituto per l'Ambiente e l'Educazione Scholé Futuro e Pianeta Azzurro

Per informazioni sui nostri progetti e attivitá vedere: 

http://www.educazionesostenibile.it/portale/pia...

http://www.educazionesostenibile.it/portale/pia...

http://www.educazionesostenibile.it/portale/weec-italia.html

story:
L'homme saccage sa planète et mène une guerre contre la nature, s'il la gagne... il sera perdu!  -  Hubert Reeves

Plus besoin de convaincre, le monde entier sait que nous vivrons d’importants changements climatiques – et tout ce qui s’y rattache – si nous ne changeons pas nos habitudes de consommations. Ceci incluant évidemment la façon dont nous nous procurons notre nourriture. L’utilisation de serres 4 saisons devient une alternative intéressante puisqu'en plus de nous procurer de la nourriture complètement biologique, elle réduit l’impact environnemental créé par les distances phénoménales que notre nourriture doit parcourrir avant de se retrouver dans notre assiette.

Pour ces raisons, l’Université de Moncton (Campus de Moncton) a comme ambition de construire une serre pour les étudiants.

 

But primaire

Tout d’abord, les étudiants auront l’opportunité de développer des habiletés de jardinage, tout en étant sensibilisés aux bénéfices d’un mode de vie autosuffisant et d’une alimentation saine. Il y aura différentes activités organisées, comme des ateliers de jardinage ouverts à tous les étudiants et membres de la communauté.

 

But secondaire

La serre pourra être utilisée à des fins pédagogiques et permettra de bâtir des liens entre les étudiants et la communauté. Par exemple, les étudiants en nutrition pourront entretenir une partie du jardin dans le but d’y faire pousser des aliments utiles à leurs laboratoires. De plus, nous avons l'intention d'ouvrir une partie du jardin à la communauté. Il serait en effet possible de mettre sur pied un projet de récréation thérapeutique avec les étudiants en récréologie pour les personnes à besoins spéciaux. Des opportunités de bénévolat seraient ainsi créées pour les étudiants voulant s'impliquer.

 

But tertiaire

Enfin, la serre sera un projet écologique exemplaire qui utilisera un minimum d’énergie et d’argent pour son fonctionnement; elle sera approximativement dix fois moins coûteuse à entretenir qu’une serre typique. Elle sera principalement chauffée par l’énergie solaire et utilisera une technologie innovatrice spécialement conçue pour les températures extrêmes du Canada. Des serres semblables ont été implantées au Yukon, en Ontario et en Angleterre et elles ont toutes démontré une grande efficacité. Étant donné que ce sera la première serre de ce genre construite au Nouveau-Brunswick, elle suscitera certainement l’intérêt des membres de la communauté et des entreprises environnantes. Par cette initiative, l’Université de Moncton pourra augmenter sa visibilité tout en démontrant son leadership au niveau écologique.

 

 

Voici un tableau présentant les dépenses nécessaires à la construction de la serre:

Dépenses prévues                                                                 Coût ($)

 

Plan détaillé de la serre                                                                  300     

2 cadres et 2 vitrages                                                                   5 000   

2 générateurs de mousse commerciale                                        6 000   

Pompe, réservoir et contrôles                                                      2 000   

Câblage, plomberie et préparation du site                                   3 000   

Murs (en avant et en arrière, avec porte)                                     2 000   

5 litres de solution de bulles (isolation)                                          250    

Outils de jardinage                                                                          200     

Dépenses diverses (clés pour la serre, etc.)                                    100     

Main-d'oeuvre professionnelle                                                    5 000   

Énergie par année pour alimenter la serre                                      150     

Total                                                                                         24 000

 

Pour les entreprises désirant avoir leur logo affiché à l’intérieur de la serre, nous allons procéder par categories de commanditaire:

BRONZE : 500 $

ARGENT : 1 000 $

OR : 2 000 $

Aidez-nous à bâtir pour l’avenir!

Pour plus de renseignements, contactez le conseil étudiant de la Faculté des Sciences de la Santé et des Services Communautaires de l'Université de Moncton: cefsssc@umoncton.ca
